		<div id="columns" class="clearfix">
			<div class="hg-container">
				<div id="content-column" role="main">
					<div class="content-inner">
					  <div class="breadcrumb"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/" >HOME</a> <span>&#47;</span> </div>
													              <a name="main-content"></a>
															<header id="main-content-header">
									<a name="main-content"></a>
                    <h1 id="page-title">
                      About                    </h1>
                </header>
														
															<!--front panel regions beg-->
								<div id="content-panels" class="at-panel gpanel panel-display content clearfix">
									<div class="region region-content-top"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-os-pages-main-content" class="block block-os-pages no-title"  module="os_pages" delta="main_content"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><article id="node-56666" class="node node-page article clearfix" role="article">
  
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p><img height="250" width="655" alt="About" title="About" class="media-element file-default file-os-files-xlarge" src="//static.hwpi.harvard.edu/files/styles/os_files_xlarge/public/religion/files/barker-banner.jpg?m=1508252522&amp;itok=eGIxn7Hf" /></p>
<p>Religion is a dynamic and powerful force in shaping cultures and complex civilizations, so understanding religion is critical for many areas of study from art, literature, and music to history, politics, and public health. Studying religion is exciting and demanding. The history of religions is global in scope and invites us to study the languages and cultures of the world. The currents of religion today are swift and often turbulent and require the very best analysis of scholars in the humanities and social sciences.</p>
<ul><li>For undergraduates, we offer an array of courses introducing the Study of Religion. These lead to more specialized work in areas of the students’ own interests.</li>
<li>For graduate students, the Committee on the Study of Religion offers the Ph.D. in a range of specialized areas. All graduate students take two common seminars, one on the history of “religion” as a subject of critical inquiry and one on contemporary conversations in the discipline of religious studies. As they move on to more specialized work, we expect our graduate students to continue thinking about how their areas of research contribute broadly to knowledge in the field.</li>
</ul><p>Harvard’s programs in religious studies are distinctive for the intensive study of historical religious traditions and the insistence that such study is always, in some sense, comparative. Religious traditions have not developed in isolation, but in constant interaction with each other and in ever-new contexts.</p></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
</div>
  </div></div></div></div>																																			</div>
								<!--front panel regions end-->
													
											</div>
				</div>

				
								  <!--sidebar second region beg-->
				  <div class="region region-sidebar-second sidebar"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-boxes-os-pages-section-nav" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_sectionnav section-nav no-title"  module="boxes" delta="os_pages_section_nav"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-os_pages_section_nav' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><ul class="menu clearfix"><li class="first last expanded active-trail active-trail menu-depth-1 menu-item-31281"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/about"  class="active-trail active active">About</a><ul class="menu clearfix"><li class="first leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-31286"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/contact" >Contact</a></li><li class="last leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-32816"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/historical-overview" >Historical Overview</a></li></ul></li></ul></div></div></div>
  </div></div><section id="block-boxes-1414172146" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_html"  module="boxes" delta="1414172146"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
      <h2 class="block-title">Donate</h2>
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1414172146' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><p>For alumni wishing to make gifts exclusively to the Study of Religion:</p>
<p>Gifts by credit card, please click <a href="https://secure.www.alumniconnections.com/olc/pub/HAA/onlinegiving/showGivingForm.jsp?form_id=60847">here</a> (for general University gifts) and follow the instructions.  When selecting a school/affiliate to donate to, please choose “<strong>Other”</strong> from the dropdown menu and enter a note in the “<strong>Comments/Other Designation”</strong> box with instructions that this gift should go to the “<strong>Committee on the Study of Religion</strong>”. You may include a program too (AB or PhD).</p>
<p>Gifts by check:  Harvard University, Recording Secretary’s Office, 124 Mount Auburn Street, Cambridge, MA  02138.  Please make checks payable to “The President and Fellows of Harvard College” and include a note in the memo line of the check that this is for the “<strong>The Committee on the Study of Religion</strong>”.</p>
<p>Thank you! Please contact us if you have any questions: <a href="mailto:csrel@fas.harvard.edu">csrel@fas.harvard.edu</a></p></div></div></div>
  </div></section></div></div>				  <!--sidebar second region end-->
        
			</div>
		</div>
		<!--footer region beg-->

		<div id="columns" class="clearfix">
			<div class="hg-container">
				<div id="content-column" role="main">
					<div class="content-inner">
					  <div class="breadcrumb"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/" >HOME</a> <span>&#47;</span> </div>
													              <a name="main-content"></a>
															<header id="main-content-header">
									<a name="main-content"></a>
                    <h1 id="page-title">
                      Academics                    </h1>
                </header>
														
															<!--front panel regions beg-->
								<div id="content-panels" class="at-panel gpanel panel-display content clearfix">
									<div class="region region-content-top"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-os-pages-main-content" class="block block-os-pages no-title"  module="os_pages" delta="main_content"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><article id="node-56816" class="node node-page article clearfix" role="article">
  
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p><img height="250" width="655" alt="Academics" title="Academics" class="media-element file-default file-os-files-xlarge" src="//static.hwpi.harvard.edu/files/styles/os_files_xlarge/public/religion/files/academics.jpg?m=1372183231&amp;itok=fm3k3NXC" /></p>
<p>Religion is a dynamic and powerful force in shaping cultures and complex civilizations, so understanding religion is critical for many areas of study from art, literature, and music to history, politics, and public health. Studying religion is exciting and demanding. The history of religions is global in scope and invites us to study the languages and cultures of the world. The currents of religion today are swift and often turbulent and require the very best analysis of scholars in the humanities and social sciences.</p>
<ul><li>For undergraduates, we offer an array of courses introducing the Study of Religion. These lead to more specialized work in areas of the students’ own interests. More.</li>
<li>For graduate students, the Committee on the Study of Religion offers the Ph.D. in a range of specialized areas. All graduate students take two common seminars, one on the history of “religion” as a subject of critical inquiry and one on contemporary conversations in the discipline of religious studies. As they move on to more specialized work, we expect our graduate students to continue thinking about how their areas of research contribute broadly to knowledge in the field. More.</li>
</ul></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
</div>
  </div></div></div></div>																																			</div>
								<!--front panel regions end-->
													
											</div>
				</div>

  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-os_pages_section_nav' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><ul class="menu clearfix"><li class="first last expanded active-trail active-trail menu-depth-1 menu-item-31161"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/academics"  class="active-trail active active">Academics</a><ul class="menu clearfix"><li class="first leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-31166"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/undergraduate" >Undergraduate</a></li><li class="last collapsed menu-depth-2 menu-item-31171"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/doctoral" >Doctoral</a></li></ul></li></ul></div></div></div>
  </div></div><section id="block-boxes-1472238788" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_html"  module="boxes" delta="1472238788"><div class="block-inner clearfix">

  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1472238788' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><a href="https://docs.google.com/document/d/139pqOBBoI0KkYhpsZAZiNDa0VU4E-uOZInpygx-Mco8/edit?usp=sharing" target="_blank" title="">Ph.D. Student Handbook</a><br /><a href="http://handbook.gsas.harvard.edu/gsas-handbook" title="">GSAS Student Handbook</a><br /><a href="http://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/files/religion/files/thd_handbook_2016.pdf">Th.D.   <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1476823074' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><p>These forms are for students who are *enrolled* in the Ph.D. program. <strong>Do *not* request access</strong> if you are applying to the Ph.D. program.</p><ul><li><a href="https://docs.google.com/a/harvard.edu/document/d/16wlb4LD2NgMteJ7X0q_9d418vFBUBU1qjjcrFOXdP2I/edit?usp=sharing" title="">Plan of Study</a></li><li><a href="https://goo.gl/forms/w80b6mQGPVRBOIi33" title="">Intent to Take the Second Year Review</a></li><li><a href="https://goo.gl/forms/qrVDPsjLzTIIeWM32" title="">Intent to Take General Exams</a></li><li><a href="https://docs.google.com/a/harvard.edu/document/d/1uLO2yz184gawZctHd6uawOwB4auSDdueAnmytjk3TGY/edit?usp=sharing" title="">Dissertation Prospectus Checklist</a></li></ul></div></div></div>

		<div id="columns" class="clearfix">
			<div class="hg-container">
				<div id="content-column" role="main">
					<div class="content-inner">
					  <div class="breadcrumb"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/" >HOME</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/undergraduate" >UNDERGRADUATE</a> <span>&#47;</span> </div>
													              <a name="main-content"></a>
															<header id="main-content-header">
									<a name="main-content"></a>
                    <h1 id="page-title">
                      Concentrating                    </h1>
                </header>
														
															<!--front panel regions beg-->
								<div id="content-panels" class="at-panel gpanel panel-display content clearfix">
									<div class="region region-content-top"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-os-pages-main-content" class="block block-os-pages no-title"  module="os_pages" delta="main_content"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><article id="node-63121" class="node node-page article clearfix" role="article">
  
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><h2>Primary Concentration</h2>
<p>The Comparative Study of Religion Concentration is open to all undergraduate students currently enrolled in the college - an application to the concentration is not required. Students may choose the honors or non-honors track. Students considering the concentration are encouraged to contact the Director of Undergraduate Studies. Plans of study follow one of two forms, Option A or Option B.</p>
<h2>Joint Concentration</h2>
<p>Joint concentrations are possible in two configurations with differing degree requirements. In both cases, students must complete a senior honors thesis.</p>
<ol><li>Religion as the primary field (Option C) - the thesis and oral exam are administered by the Study of Religion.</li>
<li>Religion as the secondary field (Option D) - procedures for undertaking and completing the thesis (including oral exams) are dictated by the primary department.</li>
</ol><p>Previous Religion concentrators have joined with Social Studies, English, History, History of Art and Architecture, Music, Government, and Philosophy, among others.</p>
<h2>Religion as a Secondary Field</h2>
<p>Religion as a Secondary Field is also open to enrolled students alike, but does not require the writing of an honors thesis. The secondary field does require six courses, two of which are comparative or methodological courses .</p>
<p>Students pursuing a Secondary Field in Religion are also asked to complete a <strong>Plan of Study</strong> and discuss it with the Director of Undergraduate Studies.</p></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
</div>
  </div></div></div></div>									<div class="region region-content-first"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><section id="block-boxes-1374178945" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_html"  module="boxes" delta="1374178945"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
      <h2 class="block-title">Plan of Study Forms for Undergraduates</h2>
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1374178945' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><ul><li><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/files/religion/files/ab_option_a_2014-15_writeable.doc">Option A: Two Major Traditions in Comparative Context</a></li>
<li><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/files/religion/files/ab_option_b_2014-15_writeable.doc">Option B: One Major Tradition in Comparative Context</a></li>
<li><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/files/religion/files/ab_option_c_2014-15_writeable.doc">*Option C: Joint Concentration with Religion as the Primary Field</a></li>
<li><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/files/religion/files/ab_option_d_2014-15_writeable.doc">*Option D: Joint Concentration with Religion as a Allied Field</a></li>
<li><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/files/religion/files/ab_secondary_field_2014-15_writeable.doc">Religion as a Secondary Field</a></li>
</ul><p>*Students pursuing a Joint Concentration must also complete the college form<a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/files/religion/files/joint_conc_app_2_-_without_list_of_programs.pdf"> "Joint Concentration Application".</a></p></div></div></div>
  </div></section></div></div>									<div class="region region-content-second"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><section id="block-boxes-1374163646" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_html"  module="boxes" delta="1374163646"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
      <h2 class="block-title">Guides &amp; Handbooks</h2>
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1374163646' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><ul><li><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/files/religion/files/religious_studies_guide_print_10-1-13.pdf">Guide to Writing in the Study of Religion</a></li>
<li><a href="http://writing.fas.harvard.edu/" target="_blank">Writing Resources at Harvard</a></li>
<li><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/files/religion/files/ab_handbook_2016-7_final_0.pdf">Undergraduate Handbook</a> (2016-17)</li>
<li><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/files/religion/files/senior_thesis_handbook_2015-16_student.pdf">Senior Thesis Handbook</a> (2015-16)</li>
</ul></div></div></div>
  </div></section></div></div>																	</div>
								<!--front panel regions end-->
													
											</div>
				</div>

				
								  <!--sidebar second region beg-->
				  <div class="region region-sidebar-second sidebar"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-boxes-os-pages-section-nav" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_sectionnav section-nav no-title"  module="boxes" delta="os_pages_section_nav"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-os_pages_section_nav' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><ul class="menu clearfix"><li class="first last expanded active-trail active-trail menu-depth-1 menu-item-146421"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/undergraduate"  class="active-trail active">Undergraduate</a><ul class="menu clearfix"><li class="first leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-32966"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/faqs-undergraduate-program" >FAQ&#039;s: Undergraduate Program</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-35426"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/courses" >Courses</a></li><li class="leaf active-trail active-trail menu-depth-2 menu-item-32561"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/admission"  class="active-trail active active">Concentrating</a></li><li class="collapsed menu-depth-2 menu-item-32581"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/advising" >Advising</a></li><li class="collapsed menu-depth-2 menu-item-32596"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/coursework" >Coursework</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-33086"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/links-undergraduates" >Resources for Undergraduates</a></li><li class="last leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-39351"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/beyond-harvard-0" >Beyond Harvard</a></li></ul></li></ul></div></div></div>
  </div></div><section id="block-boxes-1373989095" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_html"  module="boxes" delta="1373989095"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
      <h2 class="block-title">Concentration Questions?</h2>
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1373989095' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><p><a href="http://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/people/courtney-bickel-lamberth">Director of Undergraduate Studies, Courtney Lamberth</a></p>
<p><a href="mailto:kstreet@fas.harvard.edu">Assistant Director of Undergraduate Studies, Kera Street</a></p></div></div></div>
  </div></section><section id="block-boxes-1364321266" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_html"  module="boxes" delta="1364321266"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
      <h2 class="block-title">Words from our Students</h2>
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1364321266' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><address>"The structure of the concentration gives students a lot of flexibility and freedom to explore the religions and themes they're interested in. In my experience, the professors are also very involved and want to get to know you on a personal level, which is something you don't get in the larger concentrations." – Hebert, '13</address></div></div></div>
  </div></section></div></div>				  <!--sidebar second region end-->
        
			</div>
		</div>
		<!--footer region beg-->
		<footer id="footer" class="clearfix" role="contentinfo">
		<!-- Three column 3x33 Gpanel -->

  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1371845153' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><div id="file-53886" class="file file-image file-image-png">

<meta name="description" content="Every religion concentrator has a faculty adviser who signs his/her study card and is available for consultation. In most cases, academic advisers share intellectual interests with their advisees. Concentrators meet with their advisers at the start of each term to discuss their concentration plan and intellectual interests. The Director of Undergraduate Studies makes all advising assignments and manages all advising relationships. If you would like to request a specific adviser, or if you have general questions about advising, please contact the Director of Undergraduate Studies." />

Concentrators meet with their advisers at the start of each term to discuss their concentration plan and intellectual interests. The Director of Undergraduate Studies makes all advising assignments and manages all advising relationships. If you would like to request a specific adviser, or if you have general questions about advising, please contact the Director of Undergraduate Studies." />

					<!--header regions beg-->
			<header id="header" class="clearfix" role="banner">
			 <div id="header-container">
				 <div id="header-panels" class="at-panel gpanel panel-display three-col clearfix">
					  					  <div class="region region-header-second"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-boxes-site-info" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_site_info no-title"  module="boxes" delta="site_info"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-site_info' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><h1><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/" >Committee on the Study of Religion</a></h1>
    
    <p>
    </p></div></div></div>
  </div></div></div></div>					  					  <div class="region region-header-third"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-os-secondary-menu" class="block block-os no-title"  module="os" delta="secondary-menu"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><ul class="nice-menu nice-menu-down nice-menu-secondary-menu" id="nice-menu-secondary-menu"><li class="menu-22511 menu-path-faq  first   odd  "><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/faq"  title="List of FAQs">FAQ</a></li><li class="menu-2605 menu-path-node-63151   even  "><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/apply-phd" >Apply PhD</a></li><li class="menu-6668 menu-path-studyofreligionfasharvardedu-pages-forms   odd  "><a href="http://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/forms"  title="For Current Students &amp; Faculty">Forms</a></li><li class="menu-2603 menu-path-node-57086   even   last "><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/contact" >Contact</a></li></ul>

menu-path-node-61716   even  "><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/religions-americas"  title="">Religions of the Americas</a></li><li class="menu-3293 menu-path-node-61726   odd href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/theology"  title="">Theology</a></li></ul></li><li class="menu-2615 menu-path-people-taxonomy-term-12866   odd  "><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/people/taxonomy/term/12866" >People</a></li><li class="menu-2338 menuparent  menu-path-node-56666   even  "><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/about"  title="">About</a><span class="open-submenu"></span><ul><li class="menu-2607 menu-path-node-63446  first   odd  "><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/historical-overview" >Historical Overview</a></li><li class="menu-2360 menu-path-node-57086   even  "><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/contact" >Contact</a></li><li class="menu-2789 menu-path-node-75856   odd  "><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/courses" >Courses</a></li><li class="menu-2809 menu-path-node-63841   even  "><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/links"  title="">Related Organizations</a></li><li class="menu-2339 menu-path-node-56811   odd   last "><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/mailing-list"  title="">Mailing List</a></li></ul></li><li class="menu-17680 menu-path-node-881226   odd   last "><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/calendars"  title="">Calendar</a></li></ul>

  </nav></div>		  <!--main menu region end-->
		
    
		<div id="columns" class="clearfix">
			<div class="hg-container">
				<div id="content-column" role="main">
					<div class="content-inner">
					  <div class="breadcrumb"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/" >HOME</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/undergraduate" >UNDERGRADUATE</a> <span>&#47;</span> </div>
													              <a name="main-content"></a>
															<header id="main-content-header">
									<a name="main-content"></a>
                    <h1 id="page-title">
                      Advising                    </h1>
                </header>
														
															<!--front panel regions beg-->
								<div id="content-panels" class="at-panel gpanel panel-display content clearfix">
									<div class="region region-content-top"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-os-pages-main-content" class="block block-os-pages no-title"  module="os_pages" delta="main_content"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><article id="node-63161" class="node node-page article clearfix" role="article">
  
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p>Every religion concentrator has a faculty adviser who signs his/her study card and is available for consultation. In most cases, academic advisers share intellectual interests with their advisees. Concentrators meet with their advisers at the start of each term to discuss their concentration plan and intellectual interests. The Director of Undergraduate Studies makes all advising assignments and manages all advising relationships. If you would like to request a specific adviser, or if you have general questions about advising, please contact the Director of Undergraduate Studies.</p>
<div class="topic">
<div class="topic-wrap">
<div class="content">
<div class="wrap">
<p>All seniors have as their academic adviser, the Assistant Director of Undergraduate Studies, who oversees both the <strong>senior thesis<a href="http://isites.harvard.edu/icb/icb.do?keyword=k70796&amp;tabgroupid=icb.tabgroup108373"></a></strong> program for concentrators in the honors track and the development of cohesive plans of study for all concentrators.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
</div>
  </div></div></div></div>									<div class="region region-content-first"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><section id="block-boxes-1374178945" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_html"  module="boxes" delta="1374178945"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
      <h2 class="block-title">Plan of Study Forms for Undergraduates</h2>
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1374178945' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><ul><li><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/files/religion/files/ab_option_a_2014-15_writeable.doc">Option A: Two Major Traditions in Comparative Context</a></li>
<li><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/files/religion/files/ab_option_b_2014-15_writeable.doc">Option B: One Major Tradition in Comparative Context</a></li>
<li><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/files/religion/files/ab_option_c_2014-15_writeable.doc">*Option C: Joint Concentration with Religion as the Primary Field</a></li>
<li><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/files/religion/files/ab_option_d_2014-15_writeable.doc">*Option D: Joint Concentration with Religion as a Allied Field</a></li>
<li><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/files/religion/files/ab_secondary_field_2014-15_writeable.doc">Religion as a Secondary Field</a></li>
</ul><p>*Students pursuing a Joint Concentration must also complete the college form<a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/files/religion/files/joint_conc_app_2_-_without_list_of_programs.pdf"> "Joint Concentration Application".</a></p></div></div></div>
  </div></section></div></div>									<div class="region region-content-second"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><section id="block-boxes-1374163646" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_html"  module="boxes" delta="1374163646"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
      <h2 class="block-title">Guides &amp; Handbooks</h2>
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1374163646' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><ul><li><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/files/religion/files/religious_studies_guide_print_10-1-13.pdf">Guide to Writing in the Study of Religion</a></li>
<li><a href="http://writing.fas.harvard.edu/" target="_blank">Writing Resources at Harvard</a></li>
<li><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/files/religion/files/ab_handbook_2016-7_final_0.pdf">Undergraduate Handbook</a> (2016-17)</li>
<li><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/files/religion/files/senior_thesis_handbook_2015-16_student.pdf">Senior Thesis Handbook</a> (2015-16)</li>
</ul></div></div></div>
  </div></section><section id="block-boxes-1374077585" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_html"  module="boxes" delta="1374077585"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
      <h2 class="block-title">Courses</h2>
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1374077585' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><p></p>
<ul><li><strong><a href="https://my.harvard.edu/">my.harvard.edu</a> - for current students and faculty</strong><a href="http://coursecatalog.harvard.edu/icb/icb.do" target="_blank"></a></li>
<li><a href="http://coursecatalog.harvard.edu/icb/icb.do" target="_blank">Harvard University Course Catalog</a> - searchable database across schools</li>
<li><a href="http://www.registrar.fas.harvard.edu/faculty-staff/classrooms">FAS Course Meetings Location Report</a></li>
<li><strong>Historical: </strong><a href="http://www.registrar.fas.harvard.edu/courses-exams/courses-instruction/study-religion">FAS Registrar Courses of Instruction, The Study of Religion section</a></li>
</ul></div></div></div>
  </div></section></div></div>																	</div>
								<!--front panel regions end-->
													
											</div>
				</div>

				
								  <!--sidebar second region beg-->
				  <div class="region region-sidebar-second sidebar"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-boxes-os-pages-section-nav" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_sectionnav section-nav no-title"  module="boxes" delta="os_pages_section_nav"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-os_pages_section_nav' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><ul class="menu clearfix"><li class="first last expanded active-trail   </div></div><section id="block-boxes-1373989095" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_html"  module="boxes" delta="1373989095"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
      <h2 class="block-title">Concentration Questions?</h2>
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1373989095' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><p><a href="http://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/people/courtney-bickel-lamberth">Director of Undergraduate Studies, Courtney Lamberth</a></p>
<p><a href="mailto:kstreet@fas.harvard.edu">Assistant Director of Undergraduate Studies, Kera Street</a></p></div></div></div>
  </div></section><section id="block-boxes-1364321266" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_html"  module="boxes" delta="1364321266"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
      <h2 class="block-title">Words from our Students</h2>
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1364321266' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><address>"The structure of the concentration gives students a lot of flexibility and freedom to explore the religions and themes they're interested in. In my experience, the professors are also very involved and want to get to know you on a personal level, which is something you don't get in the larger concentrations." – Hebert, '13</address></div></div></div>
  </div></section></div></div>				  <!--sidebar second region end-->

<!--FLEXIBLE ADMIN HEADER FOR USE BY SELECT GROUPS USING OS-->
	<div id="branding_header">
		<div  class="branding-container clearfix">

		<div id="columns" class="clearfix">
			<div class="hg-container">
				<div id="content-column" role="main">
					<div class="content-inner">
					  <div class="breadcrumb"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/" >HOME</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/research" >RESEARCH</a> <span>&#47;</span> </div>
													              <a name="main-content"></a>
															<header id="main-content-header">
									<a name="main-content"></a>
                    <h1 id="page-title">
                      African Religions                    </h1>
                </header>
														
															<!--front panel regions beg-->
								<div id="content-panels" class="at-panel gpanel panel-display content clearfix">
									<div class="region region-content-top"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-os-pages-main-content" class="block block-os-pages no-title"  module="os_pages" delta="main_content"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><article id="node-57416" class="node node-page article clearfix" role="article">
  
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p><img height="250" width="655" alt="African Religions" title="African Religions" class="media-element file-default file-os-files-xlarge" src="//static.hwpi.harvard.edu/files/styles/os_files_xlarge/public/religion/files/african-religions.jpg?m=1372187986&amp;itok=ajDQSy_Z" /></p>
<h2>Description</h2>
<p>This area of research encompasses three subfields:</p>
<ul><li>African indigenous worldviews, ritual forms, cosmologies, and religious imaginaries.</li>
<li>The African diasporas, the Trans-Atlantic, and contemporary studies of African migration and migrant experiences.</li>
<li>Islam, Christianity and new religions in Africa.</li>
</ul><h2>Requirements</h2>
<p>Students are required to take courses in method and theory in the Study of Religion. This may include the mandatory courses offered by the Committee on Religious Studies and others such as ethnography, anthropology and sociology of religion, phenomenology of religion; race, ethnicity and gender, and postcolonial theory. In addition to courses offered in the three subfields outlined above, they are also encouraged to take relevant courses in other cognate disciplines and departments such as history, ethnic studies, literature, sociology, government, etc. Students will also be required to take at least one indigenous African language such as Yoruba, Twi, Hausa, or Zulu alongside a European language useful for archival and library research such as French, German, or Portuguese. </p>
<h2>General Examinations</h2>
<p>The exam will vary according to the student’s area of concentration and should be worked out with the student’s advisor. It may be administered in four general areas including method and theory in the Study of Religion; ethnography and/or archival research; and an examination in the student’s area focus.</p></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
</div>
  </div></div></div></div>																																			</div>
								<!--front panel regions end-->
													
											</div>
				</div>

				
								  <!--sidebar second region beg-->

  </div></div><section id="block-boxes-1372188713" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_sv_list_box"  module="boxes" delta="1372188713"><div class="block-inner clearfix">

		<div id="columns" class="clearfix">
			<div class="hg-container">
				<div id="content-column" role="main">
					<div class="content-inner">
					  <div class="breadcrumb"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/" >HOME</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/academics" >ACADEMICS</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/doctoral" >DOCTORAL</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/phd-program" >PHD PROGRAM &amp; TIMELINE</a> <span>&#47;</span> </div>
													              <a name="main-content"></a>
															<header id="main-content-header">
									<a name="main-content"></a>
                    <h1 id="page-title">
                      Admissions                    </h1>
                </header>
														
															<!--front panel regions beg-->
								<div id="content-panels" class="at-panel gpanel panel-display content clearfix">
									<div class="region region-content-top"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-os-pages-main-content" class="block block-os-pages no-title"  module="os_pages" delta="main_content"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><article id="node-63151" class="node node-page article clearfix" role="article">
  
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p>Admission to the Ph.D. program in the Study of Religion at Harvard is very competitive: typically only 5-6% of all applicants are admitted. Basic requirements, as a minimum, include a bachelor's degree, or its equivalent, with an undergraduate record of outstanding quality - a previous master's degree is not required, but it is the rare, exceptional student who is admitted without one. Similarly, while a previous major in the field of religion is not required, the applicant's background in this and related subjects is a critical consideration.</p><h4><strong>Application may only be made through the Graduate School of Arts and Sciences.</strong> For detailed requirements and to apply online, please go to: <a href="http://www.gsas.harvard.edu/prospective_students/application_instructions_and_information.php">The Graduate School of Arts and Sciences, Harvard University, Religion</a>.</h4><p>Applicants must submit: current GRE scores; TOEFL scores if a non-native English speaker unless the applicant holds a B.A. degree (or equivalent degree) from an English-speaking university; note that for the Ph.D. in Religion, the minimum TOEFL scores are 620 for the paper-based test, or 105 for the Internet-based test. In addition, applicants must submit an abstract of courses, three letters of recommendation, a Statement of Purpose outlining their proposed project, and a writing sample of no more than 10 pages (2500 words).</p><p>The annual application deadline to the Study of Religion is in mid-December. Please see the Graduate School of Arts and Sciences for the exact deadline for your year of application. If you anticipate needing assistance with any portion of the application, please contact the Admissions Office well in advance of the deadline. We do not offer rolling admissions and we do not offer on-line study programs, also known as "distance learning" programs.</p><p>Please note the research fields listed on our site are the current fields of study. The Committee on the Study of Religion admits students to the doctoral program who have clearly defined intellectual interests. <strong>Applicants should choose only <em>one</em> area of specialization from the list.</strong> There may be cases where students' interests span two fields: in such a case a student - for example, interested in Buddhism in America - may be referred to readers in two fields, in this case Buddhist Studies and Religions of the Americas. Applicants must clearly explain their interdisciplinary interests in their statement of purpose and also state which field would be their primary field.  If you find your particular field of interest is not on the GSAS site please contact us.</p><p>All doctoral applicants are expected to have foundational language skills needed for primary research (textual or ethnographic) in the area of specialization (Greek, Hebrew, Latin, Sanskrit, Arabic, Chinese, etc.) at the time of application. In addition, admitted students must demonstrate reading competence in two modern languages of secondary scholarship relevant to their course of study. These languages are determined in consultation with an adviser after admission to the program.</p><p> </p><h2>FUNDING</h2><p> </p><p>All admitted students receive the same financial aid: five years of tuition and fee assistance plus stipend, including summer stipends after years one through four. The stipend in years three and four is primarily underwritten by Teaching Fellowships. The fifth year of funding is intended for a student's final year in order to complete the dissertation.</p></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
</div>
  </div></div></div></div>																																			</div>
								<!--front panel regions end-->
													
											</div>
				</div>

				
								  <!--sidebar second region beg-->
				  <div class="region region-sidebar-second sidebar"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-boxes-os-pages-section-nav" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_sectionnav section-nav no-title"  module="boxes" delta="os_pages_section_nav"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-os_pages_section_nav' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><ul class="menu clearfix"><li class="first last expanded active-trail active-trail menu-depth-1 menu-item-31161"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/academics"  class="active-trail active">Academics</a><ul class="menu clearfix"><li class="first leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-31166"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/undergraduate" >Undergraduate</a></li><li class="last expanded active-trail active-trail menu-depth-2 menu-item-31171"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/doctoral"  class="active-trail active">Doctoral</a><ul class="menu clearfix"><li class="first expanded active-trail active-trail menu-depth-3 menu-item-31306"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/phd-program"  class="active-trail active">PhD Program &amp; Timeline</a><ul class="menu clearfix"><li class="first leaf menu-depth-4 menu-item-32681"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/doctoral-advising" >Advising</a></li><li class="menu-depth-4 menu-item-32586"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/years-1-%26-2" >Years 1 &amp; 2</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-4 menu-item-32631"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/year-3-general-exams" >Year 3: General Exams</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-4 menu-item-32656"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/year-3-%26-4-teaching" >Year 3 &amp; 4: Teaching</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-4 menu-item-32661"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/year-4-dissertation-prospectus" >Year 4: Dissertation Prospectus</a></li><li class="last leaf menu-depth-4 menu-item-32666"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/year-5-the-dissertation" >Year 5 &amp; up: The Dissertation</a></li></ul></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-3 menu-item-33061"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/links-doctoral-students" >Links for Doctoral Students</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-3 menu-item-32971"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/faqs-doctoral" >FAQ&#039;s: Doctoral</a></li><li class="last collapsed menu-depth-3 menu-item-31311"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/thd-program" >ThD Program</a></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></div></div></div>
  </div></div><section id="block-boxes-1472248730" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_media"  module="boxes" delta="1472248730"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
      <h2 class="block-title">Doctoral Program Calendar</h2>
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1472248730' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><div id="file-697671" class="file file-html file-html-embed">

          <h2 class="element-invisible"><a href="">fd67661077608f54d6ac9d4470ac003a</a></h2>
      
  
  <div class="content">
    <div class="file-info"></div><div class="field field-name-field-html-code field-type-text-long field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><iframe src="https://calendar.google.com/calendar/embed?showTitle=0&amp;showNav=0&amp;showPrint=0&amp;showCalendars=0&amp;showTz=0&amp;mode=AGENDA&amp;height=600&amp;wkst=1&amp;bgcolor=%23cccccc&amp;src=harvard.edu_tdumcqt6psi863e4fqd2re2tek%40group.calendar.google.com&amp;color=%23cccccc&amp;src=9qpvg4b8brruceh6v118kbht2k%40group.calendar.google.com&amp;color=%23cccccc&amp;ctz=America%2FNew_York" style="border-width:0" width="260" height="600" frameborder="0" scrolling="no"></iframe></div></div></div>  </div>

  
</div>
</div></div></div>
  </div></section></div></div>				  <!--sidebar second region end-->
        
			</div>
		</div>

She writes briefs, conducts client depositions, and manages client relations. She is considering a career in law." />

  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-site_info' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><h1><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/" >Committee on the Study of Religion</a></h1>
    
    <p>
    </p></div></div></div>
  </div></div></div></div>					  					  <div class="region region-header-third"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-os-secondary-menu" class="block block-os no-title"  module="os" delta="secondary-menu"><div class="block-inner clearfix">

>Courses</a></li><li class="menu-2809 menu-path-node-63841   even  "><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/links"  title="">Related Organizations</a></li><li class="menu-2339 menu-path-node-56811   odd   last "><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/mailing-list"  title="">Mailing List</a></li></ul></li><li class="menu-17680 menu-path-node-881226   odd   last "><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/calendars"  title="">Calendar</a></li></ul>

  </nav></div>		  <!--main menu region end-->
		
    
		<div id="columns" class="clearfix">
			<div class="hg-container">
				<div id="content-column" role="main">
					<div class="content-inner">
					  <div class="breadcrumb"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/" >HOME</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/undergraduate" >UNDERGRADUATE</a> <span>&#47;</span> </div>
													              <a name="main-content"></a>
															<header id="main-content-header">
									<a name="main-content"></a>
                    <h1 id="page-title">
                      Beyond Harvard                    </h1>
                </header>
														
															<!--front panel regions beg-->
								<div id="content-panels" class="at-panel gpanel panel-display content clearfix">
									<div class="region region-content-top"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-os-pages-main-content" class="block block-os-pages no-title"  module="os_pages" delta="main_content"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><article id="node-98806" class="node node-page article clearfix" role="article">
  
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p>Students in the concentration go on to pursue a range of professional activities. Below are a our most recent graduates with professional information included as it is available to us.</p>
<h3>Class of 2014</h3>
<p>Meghan Brooks (2014) focused on Islam in the modern period. She is working as a legal assistant at Sanford Heisler, a public interest law firm that specializes in race and gender-based employment discrimination class action lawsuits. She writes briefs, conducts client depositions, and manages client relations. She is considering a career in law.</p>
<p>Linda Buehler (2014), a joint concentrator with Religion and Women Gender and Sexuality, focused on Christianity in the modern period. Linda is working in the Cambridge to further her research time; she plans to apply to divinity school.</p>
<p>Edward Escalon (2014) focused on Religion in America. He is pursuing a master's degree at Union Theological Seminary in New York.</p>
<p>Rachel Horn (2014) pursued comparative work on American religion, particularly Christianity and Islam. She participated in the Aladdin Project's International Summer University for Intercultural Leadership Program in 2014. She is currently exploring career options in public service, policy, the arts, and radio broadcasting.</p>
<p>Sharon Kelleher (2014), a secondary field student in religion, concentrated in Government. Sharon is working in Boston at the law firm of Wilmer Hale.</p>
<p>Kelly Maeshiro (2014) is pursuing a master's at Union Theological Seminary.</p>
<p>David Sackstein (2014) focused on Judaism, with a secondary field in Molecular and Cellular Biology. He works in Cambridge at Harvard Hillel as the Israel and Campus Engagement Coordinator.</p>
<p>Tim Seery (2014) is pursing an MDiv at the Harvard Divinity School.</p>
<p>Jacob Shack (2014) focused on religion in the modern west, with a thematic emphasis on religion and society. He is pursuing a master's degree in viola performance at The Juilliard School in New York City.</p>
<h3>Class of 2013</h3>
<p>Allison Aitken, <strong>Doctoral Candidate</strong> (2013) Thesis: <em>Reflections on Reality: Śrigupta in the Intellectual History of the Madhyamaka</em>. Allison is pursuing a Ph.D. in South Asian Studies at Harvard.</p>
<p>Shao Min Chia Chew, <strong>Teacher</strong> (2013) Thesis: <em>Making Oneself Muslim: Creative Construction of Autonomy in America</em>. Shao Min is working for Vegas Magazine. <br /> Blair Gullick (2013) Thesis: <em>Barriers to the Safe Delivery of African Mothers: On the Relationship between Religion and Maternal Health in Western Kenya</em>. Blair is working with Teach for America in San Francisco.</p>
<p>Isabel Hebert (2013), <strong>Doctoral Candidate</strong> Thesis:<em> Art between Man and God: Grünewald's Crucifixion and Religion in the Modern West</em>. Isabel completed an internship this past summer with the Peabody Essex Museum and is currently pursuing doctoral work in Art History at the University of Cambridge. As an undergraduate, Isabel researched South Asian Religions and Art and Architecture.</p>
<p>Sara Lytle, <strong>Pastoral Care Intern</strong> at Bishop Anderson House (2013, Buddhism and Modern West/Religions of the Americas, secondary concentration in Psychology) Thesis: <em>Walking the Path Together, Crossing Alone: The Practice of Care in Buddhist Hospices</em>. Within Psychology, Sara is particularly interested in the interaction of Buddhist psychology and philosophy with psychotherapy and modern psychology. During her undergraduate studies, Sara taught English in Bosnia-Herzegovina as an intern for the Tuzla Summer Institute, a multicultural educational program that is a joint partnership between Bosnia Initiatives for Local Development and the Tuzla Muftiate.</p>
<p>Kate Zavadski (2013) Thesis: <em>Spiritual Wheaties: Tradition, Prayer, and Power in the Nation's Oldest Daily Prayer Service</em>. Katie is currently working with New York Magazine.</p>
<h3>Class of 2012</h3>
<p>Paula Bu, <strong>Med Student</strong> (2012, Christianity and Judaism) Thesis: <em>Redefining What is Fit to Eat in the 21st Century: Sustainable Eating and Contemporary American Jewish Identity</em>. Paula is currently pursuing a Doctor of Medicine at Jefferson Medical College of Thomas Jefferson University. Paula’s various passions include: interfaith work, 'all things food', indie-folk music and travel. As a student, she spent a semester interning in Israel with the Interreligious Coordinating Council and spent a summer volunteering with CitySprouts to mentor middle school youth and help plan and lead lessons related to urban gardens, food and nutrition, and community service. She plans to pursue a degree in medicine upon graduation.</p>
<p>Avery Erwin (2012, Modern West) Thesis: <em>To Steal the Sun from the Sky</em></p>
<p>Alexander Gerson (2012, South Asia) Thesis: <em>Relishing Aestheticized Emotion in Cinema: Tom Ford’s A Single Man through the Lens of Abhinavagupta’s Theological Aesthetics</em></p>
<p>Noam Hassenfeld (2012, South Asian Religions-Hinduism and the Arts, secondary concentration in Music) Thesis: <em>Flexible Conservatism: Authority and Ambiguity in the Thought of Vivekananda and Schechter</em>. Noam’s thesis compares specific modern Hindu and Jewish approaches to tradition. Noam is currently teaching 3rd grade in New Orleans with Teach For America. As a student, Noam directed, composed and performed for The Harvard Undergraduate Drummers (THUD) and has played with the Pan-African Dance and Music Ensemble, as well as Gamelan Galak-Tika, the Balinese gamelan at MIT. He interned with ASCAP in the film/TV music division in L.A.</p>
<p>Aneliese Palmer (2012, Christianity) Thesis: <em>The World as a Divine Symphony: Art and Self at Kylemore Abbey</em></p>
<p>Alyssa Yamamoto, <strong>Collaboration Catalyst</strong> at Village Health Works (2012, Modern West, secondary concentration in Government) Thesis: <em>Constellations of Friendship: Justice Illuminated by Affinities and Affections.</em> Her thesis blended ethnographic participation at a local HIV/AIDS center with a theoretical analysis of the existential, ethical encounter with the Other. As a student, Alyssa was active with the Global Health and AIDS Coalition and worked as a global health governance research assistant analyzing technology transfers, intellectual property rights, and local medicines production. As a student, she interned at the Clinton Foundation's Clinton Global Initiative.</p>
<h3>Class of 2011</h3>
<p>Tobyn Aaron (2011, Islam and Judaism) Her previous interests brought her to Japan to live in a Buddhist Temple and to Ethiopia on a summer travel grant to work with the Human Capital Foundation as a teaching fellow to AIDS orphans. Tobyn is currently an intern with No Peace Without Justice in Belgium, where she builds on her interests in traditional notions of, and mechanisms for, justice.</p>
<p>Meghan Cleary, <strong>Law Student</strong> (2011, Philosophy of Religion and Modern West, secondary concentration in Women and Gender Studies) Thesis: <em>Woman and Her Body, Me and Mine.</em> Meghan worked with the Sex Crimes Unit of the New York County District Attorney’s Office since graduation and is currently attending Harvard Law School. As an undergraduate, she worked at the Arthur and Elizabeth Schlesinger Library on the History of Women in American, was a member of Harvard's track/cross country teams and was very involved with ECHO, a peer-counseling group.</p>
<p>Danielle Gram, <strong>Client Development Associate</strong> with Axiom in NYC (2011, Focus on Christian enculturation in non-western societies, secondary concentration in Sociology) Thesis: <em>Child Witches and Witch Hunts: New Images of the Occult in the Democratic Republic of Congo</em>, awarded the Hoopes Prize. As a Sheldon Prize Travelling Fellowship recipient, Danielle worked in Northern Uganda on post-conflict rehabilitation projects and research geared towards war-affected women and children. Danielle co-founded Kids for Peace in 2006, she is a Resolution Guide with The Resolution Project, a member of the Youth Award Review Committee for World of Children and previously worked as an Analyst for J.T. Gram &amp; Associates, Inc. As a student, her research interests included studying cases of mass violence, war, disaster, and human rights challenges.</p>
<p>Jamie Olson, <strong>Instructor</strong> at Capstone Prep in Hong Kong (2011, Islam) Thesis: <em>Harmony or Harm? Sama and the Law in 18th Century Islam</em>. Jamie is currently teaching English at Bilkent University in Ankara, Turkey. As a student, Jamie studied Arabic and was a middle distance and cross-country runner for Harvard Track and Field.</p>
<p><a href="http://stories.harvard.edu/videos/236">Kelly Quinlan</a>, <strong>Legal Intern</strong> at Advocates for Children of New York (2011, Modern West, secondary concentration in Sociology) Thesis: ’<em>Because We’re Catholic’: Conflict and Challenge in Urban Catholic Schools.</em> This year, Kelly has been in Memphis teaching with Teach for America and in Thailand on a Fulbright English Teaching Assistantship. As a student, she was a Yale Law School Fellow with the Advocates for Children of New York City, Inc. in NYC.</p>
<h3>Class of 2010 and earlier – soon to come!</h3></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
</div>
  </div></div></div></div>																																			</div>
								<!--front panel regions end-->
													
											</div>
				</div>

  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-os_pages_section_nav' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><ul class="menu clearfix"><li class="first last expanded active-trail active-trail menu-depth-1 menu-item-146421"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/undergraduate"  class="active-trail active">Undergraduate</a><ul class="menu clearfix"><li class="first leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-32966"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/faqs-undergraduate-program" >FAQ&#039;s: Undergraduate Program</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-35426"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/courses" >Courses</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-32561"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/admission" >Concentrating</a></li><li class="collapsed menu-depth-2 menu-item-32581"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/advising" >Advising</a></li><li class="collapsed menu-depth-2 menu-item-32596"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/coursework" >Coursework</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-33086"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/links-undergraduates" >Resources for Undergraduates</a></li><li class="last leaf active-trail active-trail menu-depth-2 menu-item-39351"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/beyond-harvard-0"  class="active-trail active active">Beyond Harvard</a></li></ul></li></ul></div></div></div>
  </div></div><section id="block-boxes-1373989095" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_html"  module="boxes" delta="1373989095"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
      <h2 class="block-title">Concentration Questions?</h2>
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1373989095' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><p><a href="http://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/people/courtney-bickel-lamberth">Director of Undergraduate Studies, Courtney Lamberth</a></p>
<p><a href="mailto:kstreet@fas.harvard.edu">Assistant Director of Undergraduate Studies, Kera Street</a></p></div></div></div>
  </div></section><section id="block-boxes-1364321266" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_html"  module="boxes" delta="1364321266"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
      <h2 class="block-title">Words from our Students</h2>
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1364321266' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><address>"The structure of the concentration gives students a lot of flexibility and freedom to explore the religions and themes they're interested in. In my experience, the professors are also very involved and want to get to know you on a personal level, which is something you don't get in the larger concentrations." – Hebert, '13</address></div></div></div>
  </div></section></div></div>				  <!--sidebar second region end-->
        
			</div>
		</div>

<body class="html not-front not-logged-in one-sidebar sidebar-second page-node page-node- page-node-57436 node-type-page og-context og-context-node og-context-node-56551  navbar-on">

    <div id="page_wrap" class="page_wrap">

				<div id="content-column" role="main">
					<div class="content-inner">
					  <div class="breadcrumb"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/" >HOME</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/research" >RESEARCH</a> <span>&#47;</span> </div>
													              <a name="main-content"></a>
															<header id="main-content-header">
									<a name="main-content"></a>
                    <h1 id="page-title">
                      Buddhist Studies                    </h1>
                </header>
														
															<!--front panel regions beg-->
								<div id="content-panels" class="at-panel gpanel panel-display content clearfix">
									<div class="region region-content-top"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-os-pages-main-content" class="block block-os-pages no-title"  module="os_pages" delta="main_content"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><article id="node-57436" class="node node-page article clearfix" role="article">
  
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p><img height="246" width="645" class="media-element file-default file-os-files-xlarge" src="//static.hwpi.harvard.edu/files/styles/os_files_xlarge/public/religion/files/tibetan_books_copy.jpg?m=1374762909&amp;itok=u7TVlRHB" alt="" title="" /></p>
<p></p>
<h2>Description</h2>
<p>In doctoral work in Buddhist Studies at Harvard, it is possible to investigate ideas, practices, experiences, institutions, and life-worlds created by Buddhists in all times and places. Projects in this field can be focused on a single tradition or on interactions among religious groups, in a particular geographical area or across areas, and in either premodern or contemporary settings. The disciplinary range of the field is broad; the faculty welcomes projects in textual and intellectual history, cultural history, anthropology and ethnography, philosophy, literature, the arts, gender studies, and ethics. Comparative work is also welcomed. Projects regarding any corner of the Buddhist world are possible, but the field has particular strength in South Asia, East Asia, Inner Asia, and Tibet. Work in this field requires expertise in the classical and/or modern languages relevant to the specific project.<br /><br /><em>Recent and current dissertation topics include:</em></p>
<ul><li>Patrul Rinpoch on Self-Cultivation: The Rhetoric of Nineteenth-Century Tibetan Buddhist Spiritual Advice</li>
<li>The Unlikely Buddhologist: Mou Zongsan (1909-1995)</li>
<li>Memory, Rhetoric, and Education in the Great Lamp of the Dharma Dhāranī Scripture</li>
<li>Anarchy in the Pure Land: Tradition, Modernity, and the Reinvention of the Cult of Maitreya in Republican China</li>
<li>Differentiating the Pearl From the Fish Eye: Ouyang Jingwu (1871-1943) and the Revival of Scholastic Buddhism</li>
<li>Yogacara Buddhism Transmitted and Transformed? Paramartha (499-569) and His Chinese Interpreters</li>
<li>How does a Chan Buddhist Practice what he Preaches: A Study of the Works of Layman Ruru</li>
<li>Logic, Lives and Lineage: Jetsun Chokyi Gyaltsen's Ascension and the Secret Biography of Khedrup Geleg Pelzang</li>
<li>Toward a New History of Japanese and Korean Buddhist Relations, 1877-1912</li>
<li>The Politics of Materiality: Sokdokpa Lodro Gyaltsan’s Literary Representations of Material Religion and the Formation of Tibetan Buddhist Politics in the 17th c</li>
<li>Recontextualization, Exegesis, and Logic: Kuiji's (632-682) Methodological Restructuring of Chinese Buddhism</li>
<li>Kakuno and the Making of Shinran and Shin Buddhism</li>
<li>Secrets of the Vajra Body: Dngos po'I gnas lugs and the Apotheosis of the Body in the Work of Rgyal ba Yang dgon pa</li>
</ul></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
</div>
  </div></div></div></div>																																			</div>
								<!--front panel regions end-->
													
											</div>
				</div>

  </div></div><section id="block-boxes-1374004028" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_sv_list_box"  module="boxes" delta="1374004028"><div class="block-inner clearfix">

		<div id="columns" class="clearfix">
			<div class="hg-container">
				<div id="content-column" role="main">
					<div class="content-inner">
					  <div class="breadcrumb"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/" >HOME</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/research" >RESEARCH</a> <span>&#47;</span> </div>
													              <a name="main-content"></a>
															<header id="main-content-header">
									<a name="main-content"></a>
                    <h1 id="page-title">
                      Comparative Studies                    </h1>
                </header>
														
															<!--front panel regions beg-->
								<div id="content-panels" class="at-panel gpanel panel-display content clearfix">
									<div class="region region-content-top"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-os-pages-main-content" class="block block-os-pages no-title"  module="os_pages" delta="main_content"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><article id="node-57471" class="node node-page article clearfix" role="article">
  
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p><strong><img height="250" width="655" alt="Comparative Studies" title="Comparative Studies" class="media-element file-default file-os-files-xlarge" src="//static.hwpi.harvard.edu/files/styles/os_files_xlarge/public/religion/files/comp-studies.jpg?m=1374007381&amp;itok=H3xygTeZ" /></strong></p>
<h2>Description</h2>
<p>“Comparative Studies” includes reference to aesthetics, anthropology, archaeology, ethnography, ethics, gender studies, history, linguistics, literature, philosophy, phenomenology, religion, the social sciences, theology and, as appropriate, other related areas and disciplines that are utilized in the larger field of the study of religion.</p>
<h2>Requirements</h2>
<p>In any of these areas and disciplinary approaches, comparative studies will normally be pursued with reference to two religious traditions, in accord with a carefully specified and fruitful theme or themes; exceptions will be made when circumstances indicate. Our hope is to introduce care and rigor into the field, while yet not precluding interests potential students may bring with them to our programs. A doctoral student will work with a scholar expert in each of the chosen traditions, and will in addition be advised in comparative theory and the construction of a sound comparative methodological framework throughout her or his program by one of the scholars listed below, or by another scholar serving on the CSR working in comparative studies who would be willing to serve in such a role.</p>
<p>Applicants should already be reasonably familiar with at least one of the religious traditions to be studied, and possess a solid background in one or more of the languages relevant to the study of that tradition.</p>
<h2>General Examinations</h2>
<ol><li>The theory and method exam required of all PhD candidates in the study of religion.</li>
<li>A three-hour exam in one of the religious traditions being compared, with emphasis first on historical and conceptual knowledge (including major ideas and concepts within the tradition, themes, ideologies, ritual, political, and social forms, and their evolution), and second on some specific and linguistically-grounded focused area of study within that tradition.</li>
<li>A three-hour exam in the other tradition, again with a double emphasis on historical and conceptual knowledge of the tradition, and on some appropriate specific and linguistically-grounded focused area of study within that tradition.</li>
<li>A three-hour exam (or substituted exam paper in lieu of an exam, following the guidelines outlined in the doctoral degree requirements) on the student's special focus, to be determined by the student in consultation with her or his advisors. In the case of an exam, there would be required at least one hour-long essay question on the comparative approach or approaches the student is deploying, giving the criteria for the selection of that method in the context of the larger range of comparative theories and method; in the case of the choice of an exam paper in lieu of the special focus three-hour exam, at least one third of the paper must be devoted to this topic.</li>
</ol><p></p></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
</div>
  </div></div></div></div>																																			</div>
								<!--front panel regions end-->
													
											</div>
				</div>

				
								  <!--sidebar second region beg-->
				  <div class="region region-sidebar-second sidebar"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-boxes-os-pages-section-nav" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_sectionnav section-nav no-title"  module="boxes" delta="os_pages_section_nav"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-os_pages_section_nav' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><ul class="menu clearfix"><li class="first last expanded active-trail active-trail menu-depth-1 menu-item-31391"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/research"  class="active-trail active">Research</a><ul class="menu clearfix"><li class="first leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-31396"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/african-religions" >African Religions</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-31401"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/buddhist-studies" >Buddhist Studies</a></li><li class="leaf active-trail active-trail menu-depth-2 menu-item-31416"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/comparative-studies"  class="active-trail active active">Comparative Studies</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-31446"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/east-asian-religions" >East Asian Religions</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-31451"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/ethics" >Ethics</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-31456"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/greco-roman-religions" >Greco-Roman Religions</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-31461"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/hebrew-bibleold-testament" >Hebrew Bible/Old Testament</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-32316"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/history-christianity" >History of Christianity</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-32321"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/islamic-studies" >Islamic Studies</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-32326"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/jewish-studies" >Jewish Studies </a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-32331"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/new-testament-and-early-christianity" >New Testament and Early Christianity</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-32336"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/philosophy-religion" >Philosophy of Religion</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-32341"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/religion-and-society" >Religion and Society</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-32346"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/religion-gender-and-culture" >Religion, Gender and Culture</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-32356"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/religions-late-antiquity-judaism-and-christianity" >Religions of Late Antiquity: Judaism and Christianity</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-32351"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/religions-americas" >Religions of the Americas</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-32361"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/south-asian-religions" >South Asian Religions</a></li><li class="last leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-32366"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/theology" >Theology</a></li></ul></li></ul></div></div></div>
  </div></div><section id="block-boxes-1374004303" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_sv_list_box"  module="boxes" delta="1374004303"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
      <h2 class="block-title">Affiliated Faculty</h2>
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1374004303' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><div id='box-1374004303-page' data-page='0' data-delta='1374004303' class='os-sv-list os_sv_list_box sv-list-person sv-list-view-title sv-list-layout-list sv-grid-3'><div class="item-list"><ul><li><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/people/diana-eck"  target="_top">Diana Eck</a></li><li><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/people/francis-x-clooney"  target="_top">Francis X. Clooney</a></li><li><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/people/luis-m-gir%C3%B3n-negr%C3%B3n"  target="_top">Luis M. Girón Negrón</a></li><li><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/people/william-graham"  target="_top">William A. Graham</a></li><li><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/people/michael-d-jackson"  target="_top">Michael D. Jackson</a></li><li><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/people/anne-e-monius"  target="_top">Anne E.  Monius</a></li><li><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/people/parimal-g-patil"  target="_top">Parimal G. Patil</a></li><li><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/people/kimberley-patton"  target="_top">Kimberley Patton</a></li><li><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/people/michael-james-puett"  target="_top">Michael James Puett</a></li></ul></div></div></div></div></div>
  </div></section><section id="block-boxes-1377027096" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_sv_list_box"  module="boxes" delta="1377027096"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
      <h2 class="block-title">Doctoral Students in Comparative Studies</h2>
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1377027096' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><div id='box-1377027096-page' data-page='0' data-delta='1377027096' class='os-sv-list os_sv_list_box sv-list-person sv-list-view-title sv-list-layout-list sv-grid-3'><div class="item-list"><ul><li><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/people/nariman-aavani"  target="_top">Nariman Aavani</a></li><li><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/people/bennett-comerford"  target="_top">Bennett Comerford</a></li><li><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/people/daniel-frim"  target="_top">Daniel Frim</a></li><li><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/people/shoshana-gordon-guedalia"  target="_top">Shoshana Razel Gordon-Guedalia</a></li><li><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/people/rong-huang"  target="_top">Rong Huang</a></li><li><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/people/nougoutna-litoing"  target="_top">Norbert Litoing</a></li><li><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/people/munjed-murad"  target="_top">Munjed Murad</a></li><li><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/people/leah-rumsey"  target="_top">Leah Parsell Rumsey</a></li><li><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/people/jason-smith"  target="_top">Jason Smith</a></li><li><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/people/axel-takacs"  target="_top">Axel Takács</a></li></ul></div></div><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/people"  class="more-link">More</a></div></div></div>
  </div></section></div></div>				  <!--sidebar second region end-->

<meta name="description" content="Concentrators draw up a concentration plan and statement of focus under the supervision of the Director of Undergraduate Studies and their adviser in consultation with appropriate members of the Committee on the Study of Religion. There are five concentration options – all require general, methodological, or comparative courses outside of the major religious tradition(s) being studied. These courses provide analytical tools and knowledge of other traditions that enable students to think with comparative and theoretical imagination about diverse phenomena in religion." />
<meta property="og:description" content="Concentrators draw up a concentration plan and statement of focus under the supervision of the Director of Undergraduate Studies and their adviser in consultation with appropriate members of the Committee on the Study of Religion. There are five concentration options – all require general, methodological, or comparative courses outside of the major religious tradition(s) being studied. These courses provide analytical tools and knowledge of other traditions that enable students to think with comparative and theoretical imagination about diverse phenomena in religion." />
