				<div id="content-column" role="main">
					<div class="content-inner">
					  <div class="breadcrumb"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/" >HOME</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/academics" >ACADEMICS</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/doctoral" >DOCTORAL</a> <span>&#47;</span> </div>
													              <a name="main-content"></a>
															<header id="main-content-header">
									<a name="main-content"></a>
                    <h1 id="page-title">
                      FAQ's: Doctoral                    </h1>
                </header>
														
															<!--front panel regions beg-->
								<div id="content-panels" class="at-panel gpanel panel-display content clearfix">
									<div class="region region-content-top"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-boxes-1374174018" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_sv_list_box no-title"  module="boxes" delta="1374174018"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1374174018' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><div id='box-1374174018-page' data-page='0' data-delta='1374174018' class='os-sv-list os_sv_list_box sv-list-faq sv-list-view-teaser sv-list-layout-list sv-grid-3'><article id="node-64156" class="node node-faq node-teaser article clearfix" role="article" target="_top">
  
      <header class="toggle node-header">
              <h1 class="node-title" rel="nofollow">
          <a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/faq/what-required-application-doctoral-program" rel="bookmark" target="_top">What is required for application to the Ph.D. program?</a>
        </h1>
          </header>
  
  
  <div class="os-slider node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-teaser"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p><strong>T</strong>he program is highly competitive – we can accept only 5-7% of applicants to the PhD. For that reason, we look for the most capable applicants, with excellent credentials in all areas.</p>&#13;
<ul><li>A <strong>writing sample</strong> of no more than 10 pages in length.</li>&#13;
<li><strong>Transcripts</strong> from all undergraduate and graduate programs attended.</li>&#13;
<li><strong>Recommendations</strong> from three faculty members who can speak to your academic capabilities.</li>&#13;
<li><strong>GRE's</strong>. The basic exams (verbal, analytical, and math), but not any</li></ul><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/faq/what-required-application-doctoral-program" class="node-readmore" target="_top">Read more <span class="element-invisible"> about What is required for application to the Ph.D. program?</span></a></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
<article id="node-64161" class="node node-faq node-teaser article clearfix" role="article" target="_top">
  
      <header class="toggle node-header">
              <h1 class="node-title" rel="nofollow">
          <a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/faq/masters-degree-required-application-doctoral-programs" rel="bookmark" target="_top">Is a Master's degree required for application?</a>
        </h1>
          </header>
  
  
  <div class="os-slider node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-teaser"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p>While a master's degree is not a requirement, it is a distinct advantage in the application process, and in fact, most students admitted to the Ph.D. program have already earned master's degrees. The background gained from one or two years of study beyond the undergraduate level allows a student to enter a doctoral program prepared to do the advanced work required for a Ph.D. Students with an undergraduate record of <em>high quality</em> and <em>extensive academic preparation relevant to their statement of purpose</em> may be admitted with only a B.A.</p></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
<article id="node-64171" class="node node-faq node-teaser article clearfix" role="article" target="_top">
  
      <header class="toggle node-header">
              <h1 class="node-title" rel="nofollow">
          <a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/faq/what-most-important-application-process" rel="bookmark" target="_top">What is most important in the Ph.D. application process?</a>
        </h1>
          </header>
  
  
  <div class="os-slider node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-teaser"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p>It is very important that you write a clear and informative <strong>statement of purpose</strong>. You should be able to talk in some detail about your academic interests, what led you to them, and what you envision the focus of your program at Harvard would be. As much as possible, you should familiarize yourself with the faculty and resources at Harvard in your proposed area of study. Reviewers of your application will look for a good "fit" between what you want to do and what Harvard has to offer.<br /><br /><strong>Academic preparation</strong> is also extremely important, and reviewers</p> <a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/faq/what-most-important-application-process" class="node-readmore" target="_top">Read more <span class="element-invisible"> about What is most important in the Ph.D. application process?</span></a></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
<article id="node-64176" class="node node-faq node-teaser article clearfix" role="article" target="_top">
  
      <header class="toggle node-header">
              <h1 class="node-title" rel="nofollow">
          <a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/faq/what-about-financial-aid" rel="bookmark" target="_top">What financial aid is available for doctoral students?</a>
        </h1>
          </header>
  
  
  <div class="os-slider node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-teaser"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p>All admissions decisions are made without knowing the financial need of the applicants, so that financial status plays no role in the assessment of one's suitability for admission. <a data-url="https://gsas.harvard.edu/financial-support/funding-aid" href="https://gsas.harvard.edu/financial-support/funding-aid" target="_blank" title="" target="_top">Please see the current standard funding package on the Graduate School of Arts and Sciences website.</a></p> <a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/faq/what-about-financial-aid" class="node-readmore" target="_top">Read more <span class="element-invisible"> about What financial aid is available for doctoral students?</span></a></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
<article id="node-64181" class="node node-faq node-teaser article clearfix" role="article" target="_top">
  
      <header class="toggle node-header">
              <h1 class="node-title" rel="nofollow">
          <a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/faq/addition-harvards-financial-aid-are-there-other-fellowships-available" rel="bookmark" target="_top">In addition to Harvard's financial aid, are there other fellowships available?</a>
        </h1>
          </header>
  
  
  <div class="os-slider node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-teaser"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p>Yes. Once you are a student, you are eligible to apply for a range of fellowships at various stages in your program, for example, summer language study grants, traveling fellowships for research abroad, other research grants, and dissertation completion fellowships.</p></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
<article id="node-64186" class="node node-faq node-teaser article clearfix" role="article" target="_top">
  
      <header class="toggle node-header">
              <h1 class="node-title" rel="nofollow">
          <a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/faq/what-are-opportunities-teaching" rel="bookmark" target="_top">What are the opportunities for teaching?</a>
        </h1>
          </header>
  
  
  <div class="os-slider node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-teaser"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p>As part of the funding offered to admitted students, teaching fellowships are made available beginning in year three. Teaching experience is integral to the doctoral program. Teaching Fellowship positions are most often found through the Divinity School and in the Faculty of Arts and Sciences. Additional teaching opportunities include work as junior and senior tutors with small groups or individuals majoring in religion, as well as work with HarvardX and the Harvard Extension School. Every effort is made to give students the best information for securing these teaching</p> <a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/faq/what-are-opportunities-teaching" class="node-readmore" target="_top">Read more <span class="element-invisible"> about What are the opportunities for teaching?</span></a></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
<article id="node-64191" class="node node-faq node-teaser article clearfix" role="article" target="_top">
  
      <header class="toggle node-header">
              <h1 class="node-title" rel="nofollow">
          <a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/faq/what-average-length-doctoral-programs-study-religion" rel="bookmark" target="_top">What is the average length of study for doctoral candidates?</a>
        </h1>
          </header>
  
  
  <div class="os-slider node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-teaser"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p>Program guidelines stipulate that students should complete their degrees in seven years. Some students may complete their doctoral programs sooner. Various factors, such as language study or research abroad, will affect the length of a student's program.</p></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
<article id="node-86751" class="node node-faq node-teaser article clearfix" role="article" target="_top">
  
      <header class="toggle node-header">
              <h1 class="node-title" rel="nofollow">
          <a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/faq/do-i-need-submit-my-gre-scores-application-deadline" rel="bookmark" target="_top">Do I need to submit my GRE scores by the application deadline?</a>
        </h1>
          </header>
  
  
  <div class="os-slider node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-teaser"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p>Yes. Applications that do not have GRE scores are considered incomplete. Refer to the <a href="http://www.gsas.harvard.edu/prospective_students/application_instructions_and_information.php" data-url="http://www.gsas.harvard.edu/prospective_students/application_instructions_and_information.php" target="_top">GSAS Application Instructions</a> for more details on submitting scores.</p> <a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/faq/do-i-need-submit-my-gre-scores-application-deadline" class="node-readmore" target="_top">Read more <span class="element-invisible"> about Do I need to submit my GRE scores by the application deadline?</span></a></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
<article id="node-476446" class="node node-faq node-teaser article clearfix" role="article" target="_top">
  
      <header class="toggle node-header">
              <h1 class="node-title" rel="nofollow">
          <a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/faq/do-i-need-mail-my-transcripts" rel="bookmark" target="_top">Do I need to mail my transcripts by the application deadline?</a>
        </h1>
          </header>
  
  
  <div class="os-slider node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-teaser"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p>When applying to the Doctoral Program, the Graduate School of Arts and Sciences requires that you upload a copy of your transcript from each college/university attended with your online application. An official transcript showing the conferral of the undergraduate degree is required to register in the Graduate School. An official transcript that differs from the application copy may bar an admitted candidate from registering.</p></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
<article id="node-598186" class="node node-faq node-teaser article clearfix" role="article" target="_top">
  
      <header class="toggle node-header">
              <h1 class="node-title" rel="nofollow">
          <a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/faq/can-i-pursue-degree-law-and-study-religion" rel="bookmark" target="_top">Can I pursue a degree in Law and the Study of Religion?</a>
        </h1>
          </header>
  
  
  <div class="os-slider node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-teaser"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p>Harvard offers a coordinated JD/PhD Program which is designed for students interested in completing interdisciplinary work and is founded on the belief that students’ legal studies and their arts and sciences graduate studies can be mutually enriched through this pursuit. Students completing the coordinated program receive a JD from Harvard Law School (HLS) and a PhD from the <a href="http://www.gsas.harvard.edu/" target="_top">Graduate School of Arts and Sciences</a> (GSAS). It is expected that these students will be strong candidates for teaching posts at law schools and in arts and sciences programs</p> <a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/faq/can-i-pursue-degree-law-and-study-religion" class="node-readmore" target="_top">Read more <span class="element-invisible"> about Can I pursue a degree in Law and the Study of Religion?</span></a></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
<article id="node-892626" class="node node-faq node-teaser article clearfix" role="article" target="_top">
  
      <header class="toggle node-header">
              <h1 class="node-title" rel="nofollow">
          <a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/faq/when-are-stipends-disbursed" rel="bookmark" target="_top">When are stipends disbursed?</a>
        </h1>
          </header>
  
  
  <div class="os-slider node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-teaser"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p>Incoming new graduate students receive their stipend disbursement on orientation day. Returning graduate students are issued stipend the first of September for the fall term. If you have not set up direct deposit, the check will be mailed on that date.</p></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
<article id="node-892836" class="node node-faq node-teaser article clearfix" role="article" target="_top">
  
      <header class="toggle node-header">
              <h1 class="node-title" rel="nofollow">
          <a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/faq/how-does-my-advisor-lift-hold" rel="bookmark" target="_top">How does my advisor lift the "hold"?</a>
        </h1>
          </header>
  
  
  <div class="os-slider node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-teaser"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p>Faculty advisors can<a href="http://about.my.harvard.edu/study-card-advisors" data-url="http://about.my.harvard.edu/study-card-advisors" target="_top"> review instruction here for lifting a registration hold</a>.</p> <a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/faq/how-does-my-advisor-lift-hold" class="node-readmore" target="_top">Read more <span class="element-invisible"> about How does my advisor lift the "hold"?</span></a></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
<article id="node-892841" class="node node-faq node-teaser article clearfix" role="article" target="_top">
  
      <header class="toggle node-header">
              <h1 class="node-title" rel="nofollow">
          <a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/faq/what-are-family-accommodations-graduate-students" rel="bookmark" target="_top">What are "Family Accommodations" for graduate students?</a>
        </h1>
          </header>
  
  
  <div class="os-slider node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-teaser"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p>The Graduate School of Arts and Sciences offers accommodations to students who are anticipating the birth or adoption of a child. You may review the policy here: <strong><a href="https://gsas.harvard.edu/student-life/harvard-resources/parental-accommodation-and-financial-support" data-url="https://gsas.harvard.edu/student-life/harvard-resources/parental-accommodation-and-financial-support" target="_top">https://gsas.harvard.edu/student-life/harvard-resources/parental-accommodation-and-financial-support</a></strong></p> <a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/faq/what-are-family-accommodations-graduate-students" class="node-readmore" target="_top">Read more <span class="element-invisible"> about What are "Family Accommodations" for graduate students?</span></a></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
<article id="node-896466" class="node node-faq node-teaser article clearfix" role="article" target="_top">
  
      <header class="toggle node-header">
              <h1 class="node-title" rel="nofollow">
          <a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/faq/can-doctoral-students-defer-funding" rel="bookmark" target="_top">Can doctoral students defer funding?</a>
        </h1>
          </header>
  
  
  <div class="os-slider node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-teaser"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p>The GSAS made some changes to their funding structure for doctoral students entering 2016-17 and beyond. These allow for some deferrals of teaching fellowships to later G years and other enhancements. <a href="https://gsas.harvard.edu/news/stories/gsas-implements-enhancements-funding-packages" data-url="https://gsas.harvard.edu/news/stories/gsas-implements-enhancements-funding-packages" target="_top">Read more.</a></p> <a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/faq/can-doctoral-students-defer-funding" class="node-readmore" target="_top">Read more <span class="element-invisible"> about Can doctoral students defer funding?</span></a></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
<article id="node-916981" class="node node-faq node-teaser article clearfix" role="article" target="_top">
  
      <header class="toggle node-header">
              <h1 class="node-title" rel="nofollow">
          <a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/faq/how-do-i-apply-phd-program-study-religion-harvard-university" rel="bookmark" target="_top">How do I apply to the Ph.D. Program in the Study of Religion at Harvard University?</a>
        </h1>
          </header>
  
  
  <div class="os-slider node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-teaser"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p>Please go to <a data-url="http://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/apply-phd" href="http://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/apply-phd" target="_blank" title="" target="_top">"Apply PhD"</a> and follow instructions on applying to the Graduate School of Arts and Sciences at Harvard University.</p> <a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/faq/how-do-i-apply-phd-program-study-religion-harvard-university" class="node-readmore" target="_top">Read more <span class="element-invisible"> about How do I apply to the Ph.D. Program in the Study of Religion at Harvard University?</span></a></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
<article id="node-932736" class="node node-faq node-teaser article clearfix" role="article" target="_top">
  
      <header class="toggle node-header">
              <h1 class="node-title" rel="nofollow">
          <a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/faq/do-you-require-writing-sample" rel="bookmark" target="_top">Is a writing sample required for applicants?</a>
        </h1>
          </header>
  
  
  <div class="os-slider node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-teaser"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p>For applicants to the Ph.D. program in the Study of Religion, a writing sample is required. The 10-page limit/2500-word limit refers to the main body of the paper and does not include bibliographies.</p></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
<article id="node-982876" class="node node-faq node-teaser article clearfix" role="article" target="_top">
  
      <header class="toggle node-header">
              <h1 class="node-title" rel="nofollow">
          <a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/faq/can-i-teach-years-g5-and-g6-priority-student" rel="bookmark" target="_top">Can I teach in years G5 and G6, as a priority student?</a>
        </h1>
          </header>
  
  
  <div class="os-slider node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-teaser"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p>GSAS made some recent changes which allow students to shift their priority years to any combination within G3, G4, G5, and G6 years. This allows students in the Study of Religion to do research work earlier in their program, if they have secured alternative sources of funding. Read the guidance here: https://gsas.harvard.edu/news/stories/gsas-implements-enhancements-funding-packages.</p> <a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/faq/can-i-teach-years-g5-and-g6-priority-student" class="node-readmore" target="_top">Read more <span class="element-invisible"> about Can I teach in years G5 and G6, as a priority student?</span></a></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
<article id="node-1000166" class="node node-faq node-teaser article clearfix" role="article" target="_top">
  
      <header class="toggle node-header">
              <h1 class="node-title" rel="nofollow">
          <a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/faq/what-latest-information-unionization-graduate-students-harvard" rel="bookmark" target="_top">What is the latest information on the unionization of graduate students at Harvard?</a>
        </h1>
          </header>
  
  
  <div class="os-slider node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-teaser"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p>&#13;
	To keep current on the unionization of graduate students at Harvard, please refer to <a data-url="https://provost.harvard.edu/studentvote" href="https://provost.harvard.edu/studentvote" title="" target="_top">the page managed by the Office of the Provost.</a> Please note that the provost also sends direct communications to graduate students, faculty, and other members of the Harvard community.&#13;
</p>&#13;
 <a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/faq/what-latest-information-unionization-graduate-students-harvard" class="node-readmore" target="_top">Read more <span class="element-invisible"> about What is the latest information on the unionization of graduate students at Harvard?</span></a></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
</div></div></div></div>
  </div></div></div></div>																																			</div>
								<!--front panel regions end-->
													
											</div>
				</div>

				
								  <!--sidebar second region beg-->
				  <div class="region region-sidebar-second sidebar"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-boxes-os-pages-section-nav" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_sectionnav section-nav no-title"  module="boxes" delta="os_pages_section_nav"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-os_pages_section_nav' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><ul class="menu clearfix"><li class="first last expanded active-trail active-trail menu-depth-1 menu-item-31161"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/academics"  class="active-trail active">Academics</a><ul class="menu clearfix"><li class="first leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-31166"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/undergraduate" >Undergraduate</a></li><li class="last expanded active-trail active-trail menu-depth-2 menu-item-31171"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/doctoral"  class="active-trail active">Doctoral</a><ul class="menu clearfix"><li class="first collapsed menu-depth-3 menu-item-31306"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/phd-program" >PhD Program &amp; Timeline</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-3 menu-item-33061"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/links-doctoral-students" >Links for Doctoral Students</a></li><li class="leaf active-trail active-trail menu-depth-3 menu-item-32971"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/faqs-doctoral"  class="active-trail active active">FAQ&#039;s: Doctoral</a></li><li class="last collapsed menu-depth-3 menu-item-31311"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/thd-program" >ThD Program</a></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></div></div></div>
  </div></div><section id="block-boxes-1472248730" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_media"  module="boxes" delta="1472248730"><div class="block-inner clearfix">

<div id="page" class="container page os_pages-section-893786 header-main header-right content-top content-left content-right footer-left">
	<div id="page-wrapper">

		
					<!--header regions beg-->
			<header id="header" class="clearfix" role="banner">
			 <div id="header-container">
				 <div id="header-panels" class="at-panel gpanel panel-display three-col clearfix">
					  					  <div class="region region-header-second"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-boxes-site-info" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_site_info no-title"  module="boxes" delta="site_info"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-site_info' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><h1><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/" >Committee on the Study of Religion</a></h1>
    
    <p>
    </p></div></div></div>
  </div></div></div></div>					  					  <div class="region region-header-third"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-os-secondary-menu" class="block block-os no-title"  module="os" delta="secondary-menu"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><ul class="nice-menu nice-menu-down nice-menu-secondary-menu" id="nice-menu-secondary-menu"><li class="menu-22511 menu-path-faq  first   odd  "><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/faq"  title="List of FAQs">FAQ</a></li><li class="menu-2605 menu-path-node-63151   even  "><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/apply-phd" >Apply PhD</a></li><li class="menu-6668 menu-path-studyofreligionfasharvardedu-pages-forms   odd  "><a href="http://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/forms"  title="For Current Students &amp; Faculty">Forms</a></li><li class="menu-2603 menu-path-node-57086   even   last "><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/contact" >Contact</a></li></ul>
</div>
  </div></div><div id="block-boxes-solr-search-box" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_search_solr_search_box no-title"  module="boxes" delta="solr_search_box"><div class="block-inner clearfix">

		<div id="columns" class="clearfix">
			<div class="hg-container">
				<div id="content-column" role="main">
					<div class="content-inner">
					  <div class="breadcrumb"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/" >HOME</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/undergraduate" >UNDERGRADUATE</a> <span>&#47;</span> </div>
													              <a name="main-content"></a>
															<header id="main-content-header">
									<a name="main-content"></a>
                    <h1 id="page-title">
                      FAQ's: Undergraduate Program                    </h1>
                </header>
														
															<!--front panel regions beg-->
								<div id="content-panels" class="at-panel gpanel panel-display content clearfix">
									<div class="region region-content-top"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><section id="block-boxes-1374164267" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_sv_list_box"  module="boxes" delta="1374164267"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
      <h2 class="block-title">FAQs for Undergraduates</h2>
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1374164267' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><div id='box-1374164267-page' data-page='0' data-delta='1374164267' class='os-sv-list os_sv_list_box sv-list-faq sv-list-view-full sv-list-layout-list sv-grid-3'><article id="node-57536" class="node node-faq article clearfix" role="article" target="_top">
  
      <header class="toggle node-header">
              <h1 class="node-title" rel="nofollow">
          <a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/faq/do-people-who-concentrate-religion-also-practice-certain-religion-do-you-have-believe" rel="bookmark" target="_top">Do people who concentrate in religion also practice a religion?</a>
        </h1>
          </header>
  
  
  <div class="os-slider node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p>Some of our students are religious and some are not. Those who are religious practice different faiths—Judaism, Islam, Christianity, Buddhism, Hinduism and others. There is no presumption that students in religion will believe in God or practice a certain faith.</p></div></div></div><div class="field field-name-og-vocabulary field-type-entityreference field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">See also: <a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/faq-taxonomy/undergraduate"  target="_top">Undergraduate</a></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
<article id="node-63851" class="node node-faq article clearfix" role="article" target="_top">
  
      <header class="toggle node-header">
              <h1 class="node-title" rel="nofollow">
          <a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/faq/why-should-i-concentrate-religion-0" rel="bookmark" target="_top">Why should I concentrate in Religion?</a>
        </h1>
          </header>
  
  
  <div class="os-slider node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">In the religion program students study a range of human experiences that have produced much of the greatest literature of the world, inspired its art and philosophy and shaped its moral consciousness. As a small concentration at Harvard, the Study of Religion is an intimate community within the larger university. Religion students regularly interact with faculty members and graduate students who share their interests. Tutorials are small (frequently one-on-one) and tailored to student interests. Student satisfaction with our program is consistently very high.</div></div></div><div class="field field-name-og-vocabulary field-type-entityreference field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">See also: <a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/faq-taxonomy/undergraduate"  target="_top">Undergraduate</a></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
<article id="node-63891" class="node node-faq article clearfix" role="article" target="_top">
  
      <header class="toggle node-header">
              <h1 class="node-title" rel="nofollow">
          <a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/faq/can-i-concentrate-religion-and-still-go-law-or-medical-school" rel="bookmark" target="_top">Can I concentrate in religion and still go to law or medical school?</a>
        </h1>
          </header>
  
  
  <div class="os-slider node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">Yes! Many of our concentrators do. Prepare to take the classes necessary for graduate school in your chosen field in addition to fulfilling our concentration requirements.</div></div></div><div class="field field-name-og-vocabulary field-type-entityreference field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">See also: <a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/faq-taxonomy/undergraduate"  target="_top">Undergraduate</a></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
<article id="node-63896" class="node node-faq article clearfix" role="article" target="_top">
  
      <header class="toggle node-header">
              <h1 class="node-title" rel="nofollow">
          <a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/faq/can-courses-%E2%80%9Cdouble-count%E2%80%9D-meet-both-gen-ed-and-concentration-requirements" rel="bookmark" target="_top">Can courses “double-count” for both Gen Ed and Religion requirements?</a>
        </h1>
          </header>
  
  
  <div class="os-slider node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p>Yes!</p></div></div></div><div class="field field-name-og-vocabulary field-type-entityreference field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">See also: <a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/faq-taxonomy/undergraduate"  target="_top">Undergraduate</a></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
<article id="node-63921" class="node node-faq article clearfix" role="article" target="_top">
  
      <header class="toggle node-header">
              <h1 class="node-title" rel="nofollow">
          <a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/faq/if-i-transfer-religion-another-concentration-sophomore-or-junior-can-i-get-credit" rel="bookmark" target="_top">Can I transfer from another concentration as a sophomore or junior and get credit for tutorials taken in other departments?</a>
        </h1>
          </header>
  
  
  <div class="os-slider node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p>Yes, this is possible. Make an appointment to see the Director of Undergraduate Studies, and be sure to bring with you syllabi from your other tutorials and a completed <a href="pages/concentration-plans" target="_top">Plan of Study from the Study of Religion</a>.</p></div></div></div><div class="field field-name-og-vocabulary field-type-entityreference field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">See also: <a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/faq-taxonomy/undergraduate"  target="_top">Undergraduate</a></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
<article id="node-63991" class="node node-faq article clearfix" role="article" target="_top">
  
      <header class="toggle node-header">
              <h1 class="node-title" rel="nofollow">
          <a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/faq/what-happens-if-i%E2%80%99ve-been-away-harvard-and-requirements-my-field-changed-while-i-was" rel="bookmark" target="_top">What happens if I’ve been away from Harvard and the requirements for my field changed while I was gone?</a>
        </h1>
          </header>
  
  
  <div class="os-slider node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p>Normally you will be allowed to complete your work in the Study of Religion under the guidelines that existed when you entered the program. See the <a href="pages/coursework" target="_top">Coursework section for historical handbooks</a>.</p></div></div></div><div class="field field-name-og-vocabulary field-type-entityreference field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">See also: <a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/faq-taxonomy/undergraduate"  target="_top">Undergraduate</a></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
</div></div></div></div>
  </div></section></div></div>									<div class="region region-content-first"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><section id="block-boxes-1374163646" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_html"  module="boxes" delta="1374163646"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
      <h2 class="block-title">Guides &amp; Handbooks</h2>
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1374163646' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><ul><li><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/files/religion/files/religious_studies_guide_print_10-1-13.pdf">Guide to Writing in the Study of Religion</a></li>
<li><a href="http://writing.fas.harvard.edu/" target="_blank">Writing Resources at Harvard</a></li>
<li><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/files/religion/files/ab_handbook_2016-7_final_0.pdf">Undergraduate Handbook</a> (2016-17)</li>
<li><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/files/religion/files/senior_thesis_handbook_2015-16_student.pdf">Senior Thesis Handbook</a> (2015-16)</li>
</ul></div></div></div>
  </div></section><section id="block-boxes-1374515432" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_html"  module="boxes" delta="1374515432"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
      <h2 class="block-title">Undergraduate Resources</h2>
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1374515432' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><ul><li><a href="http://osl.fas.harvard.edu/icb/icb.do?keyword=k65178&amp;pageid=icb.page305611">Office of Student Life – Student Organizations</a></li>
<li><a href="http://www.ocs.fas.harvard.edu/">Office of Career Services</a></li>
<li><a href="http://www.funding.fas.harvard.edu/">Harvard College Funding Sources</a></li>
<li><a href="http://www.college.harvard.edu/icb/icb.do?keyword=k61161&amp;pageid=icb.page257820">Harvard College</a></li>
<li><a href="http://oie.fas.harvard.edu/">Office of International Education</a></li>
<li><a href="http://cuhs.harvard.edu/">Harvard’s Committee on the Use of Human Subjects</a></li>
</ul><p>Register your travel abroad for emergency support:<br /><a href="https://www.globalsupport.harvard.edu/travel-tools">www.globalsupport.harvard.edu/travel-tools</a></p></div></div></div>
  </div></section></div></div>									<div class="region region-content-second"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><section id="block-boxes-1374178945" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_html"  module="boxes" delta="1374178945"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
      <h2 class="block-title">Plan of Study Forms for Undergraduates</h2>
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1374178945' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><ul><li><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/files/religion/files/ab_option_a_2014-15_writeable.doc">Option A: Two Major Traditions in Comparative Context</a></li>
<li><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/files/religion/files/ab_option_b_2014-15_writeable.doc">Option B: One Major Tradition in Comparative Context</a></li>
<li><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/files/religion/files/ab_option_c_2014-15_writeable.doc">*Option C: Joint Concentration with Religion as the Primary Field</a></li>
<li><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/files/religion/files/ab_option_d_2014-15_writeable.doc">*Option D: Joint Concentration with Religion as a Allied Field</a></li>
<li><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/files/religion/files/ab_secondary_field_2014-15_writeable.doc">Religion as a Secondary Field</a></li>
</ul><p>*Students pursuing a Joint Concentration must also complete the college form<a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/files/religion/files/joint_conc_app_2_-_without_list_of_programs.pdf"> "Joint Concentration Application".</a></p></div></div></div>
  </div></section></div></div>																	</div>
								<!--front panel regions end-->
													
											</div>
				</div>

				
								  <!--sidebar second region beg-->
				  <div class="region region-sidebar-second sidebar"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-boxes-os-pages-section-nav" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_sectionnav section-nav no-title"  module="boxes" delta="os_pages_section_nav"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-os_pages_section_nav' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><ul class="menu clearfix"><li class="first last expanded active-trail active-trail menu-depth-1 menu-item-146421"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/undergraduate"  class="active-trail active">Undergraduate</a><ul class="menu clearfix"><li class="first leaf active-trail active-trail menu-depth-2 menu-item-32966"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/faqs-undergraduate-program"  class="active-trail active active">FAQ&#039;s: Undergraduate Program</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-35426"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/courses" >Courses</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-32561"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/admission" >Concentrating</a></li><li class="collapsed menu-depth-2 menu-item-32581"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/advising" >Advising</a></li><li class="collapsed menu-depth-2 menu-item-32596"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/coursework" >Coursework</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-33086"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/links-undergraduates" >Resources for Undergraduates</a></li><li class="last leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-39351"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/beyond-harvard-0" >Beyond Harvard</a></li></ul></li></ul></div></div></div>
  </div></div><section id="block-boxes-1373989095" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_html"  module="boxes" delta="1373989095"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
      <h2 class="block-title">Concentration Questions?</h2>
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1373989095' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><p><a href="http://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/people/courtney-bickel-lamberth">Director of Undergraduate Studies, Courtney Lamberth</a></p>
<p><a href="mailto:kstreet@fas.harvard.edu">Assistant Director of Undergraduate Studies, Kera Street</a></p></div></div></div>
  </div></section><section id="block-boxes-1364321266" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_html"  module="boxes" delta="1364321266"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
      <h2 class="block-title">Words from our Students</h2>
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1364321266' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><address>"The structure of the concentration gives students a lot of flexibility and freedom to explore the religions and themes they're interested in. In my experience, the professors are also very involved and want to get to know you on a personal level, which is something you don't get in the larger concentrations." – Hebert, '13</address></div></div></div>
  </div></section></div></div>				  <!--sidebar second region end-->
        
			</div>
		</div>
		<!--footer region beg-->
		<footer id="footer" class="clearfix" role="contentinfo">
		<!-- Three column 3x33 Gpanel -->
		
			<div class="at-panel gpanel panel-display footer clearfix">
								<div class="region region-footer-first"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-boxes-1371845153" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_media no-title"  module="boxes" delta="1371845153"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1371845153' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><div id="file-53886" class="file file-image file-image-png">

          <h2 class="element-invisible"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/files/religion/files/religion-footer.png?m=1479879567">religion-footer.png</a></h2>
      
  
  <div class="content">
    <img class="image-style-os-files-xxlarge" src="//static.hwpi.harvard.edu/files/styles/os_files_xxlarge/public/religion/files/religion-footer.png?m=1499733428&amp;itok=K-pEO8QM" width="300" height="63" alt="" title="" />  </div>

  
</div>
</div></div></div>
  </div></div><div id="block-boxes-1372101242" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_html no-title"  module="boxes" delta="1372101242"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1372101242' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><p><strong>Committee on the Study of Religion</strong><br />Barker Center, Cambridge, MA 02138<br />Telephone: (617) 495-5781<br /><a href="mailto:csrel@fas.harvard.edu">csrel@fas.harvard.edu</a></p></div></div></div>
  </div></div></div></div>															</div>

		<div id="columns" class="clearfix">
			<div class="hg-container">
				<div id="content-column" role="main">
					<div class="content-inner">
					  <div class="breadcrumb"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/" >HOME</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/academics" >ACADEMICS</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/doctoral" >DOCTORAL</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/thd-program" >THD PROGRAM</a> <span>&#47;</span> </div>
													              <a name="main-content"></a>
															<header id="main-content-header">
									<a name="main-content"></a>
                    <h1 id="page-title">
                      The First Two Years: ThD Pre-Generals                    </h1>
                </header>
														
															<!--front panel regions beg-->
								<div id="content-panels" class="at-panel gpanel panel-display content clearfix">
									<div class="region region-content-top"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-os-pages-main-content" class="block block-os-pages no-title"  module="os_pages" delta="main_content"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><article id="node-63336" class="node node-page article clearfix" role="article">
  
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><h2>Th.D. Requirements</h2><h3><br />Th.D. Plan of Study</h3><ul><li>The student must, in consultation with the advisor, submit a Plan of Study during their first term by early November to the program administrator. This plan will be reviewed by the Director of ThD studies.</li></ul><h3>Languages</h3><ul><li>two modern languages of secondary scholarship</li><li>other languages as required for specialization</li></ul><h3>Coursework</h3><ul><li>courses required for specialization</li><li>Common Doctoral Seminar (first semester)</li></ul><h3>Second Year Review</h3><ul><li>to occur by the end of the fourth semester<br /> </li></ul><h2>Th.D. Coursework and Residency</h2><p>Two years of doctoral study in residence are required. During those two years, students must register for and complete at least four credit courses per term. A student must have achieved the minimum grade point average of “B in each academic year and have met the regulations governing enrollment with incompletes.<br /><br />The Common Doctor of Theology Seminar (Divinity 4599) is required for every Th.D. student. It is offered in the fall term each year in conjunction with the Ph.D. Common Seminar (Religion 2001) for entering Th.D. and Ph.D. students in the Study of Religion. This course is intended to examine various theories and methods, themes and problems common to religious scholarship.<br /><br />In addition, candidates must take the graduate seminars required for their field concentration. Other required courses will be determined in consultation with the academic advisor. Students may continue to take courses as long as they are registered as students at the Divinity School.<br /><br />Additional information:<br /><br />Doctoral students who have completed course work may register in absentia if they reside and work outside the greater Boston area. They also may waive the health fee by filing the appropriate waiver form in the Registrar’s Office each semester. In absentia registration materials must be requested at least four weeks in advance of the start of the semester.<br /><br />Part-Time Th.D. Candidates:<br /><br />Once admitted and under certain circumstances, a Th.D. candidate may petition the Committee on the Study of Religion to work as a part-time student in order to take less than four credit courses per term during the first two years. Part-time students are charged at a per-course rate.<br /><br />Students must petition the Committee on the Study of religion prior to registration. Separate petitions must be filed for each academic year. On the petition, Th.D. candidates should indicate the reasons part-time status is sought and the number of courses for which they wish to register each term. Part-time study ordinarily is approved for the following reasons:</p><ul><li>pregnancy or having to care for small children at home</li><li>personal ill health</li><li>severe illness of other family members</li><li>outside employment (but ordinarily not until after one year of full-time study)</li><li>extreme financial strain in cases which the student has dependents</li></ul><p>Part-time students are subject to the same requirements and regulations as full-time students.<br /> </p><h2>Th.D. Language Requirements</h2><ol><li>All doctoral students—in consultation with their advisors—must achieve at least intermediate reading competence in two modern languages of secondary scholarship relevant to their course of study (such as French, German, Japanese), <em>in addition</em> to whatever primary source languages are required in their field. (Note that languages needed for ethnographic or other research, requiring verbal competence, are for primary scholarship and thus may not be used as one of the modern languages of secondary scholarship.)</li><li>The requirement in modern languages of scholarship commonly taught and examined at Harvard University (French, German, Spanish, etc.) can be met either by achieving a grade of B+ or better in two semesters of a second-year language course (in either HDS or FAS); by receiving a grade of A- or better in the Harvard Divinity School one-semester advanced intermediate language reading courses in French, Spanish, and German; or by achieving a “high pass” on an HDS qualifying exam. Students whose first language is not English may meet the requirement with a “pass” on the language exam.</li><li>In the case of modern languages of scholarship for which there is not an intermediate 2-semester course at Harvard or a qualifying exam at HDS, the number of years required to achieve “intermediate reading competence” and the equivalent of “high pass” on language examinations will be determined by faculty in the relevant field. This involves an exam comparable to the HDS qualifying exam: translating a text of moderate difficulty in a one-hour exam with one dictionary, using a text of religious or historical significance or a scriptural text. The student will arrange the administration of the exam with the HDS Registrar, and consult with the Faculty Director of Language Studies about the academic guidelines for the exam.</li><li>All language requirements must be met before General Examinations are taken.</li></ol><p><em>Passed by HDS Faculty 4/23/2012. Reported to Standing Committee 5/11/2102.</em></p><h4><a href="http://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/guidelines-foreign-language-certification-course-div-4999" target="_blank" title="">Guidelines for the Foreign Language Certification Course, HDS 4999</a></h4><h3><br />Additional information about languages:</h3><p>Students having extraordinary difficulty in passing language requirements are encouraged to contact both their program administrator and the Director of Language Testing.<br /><br />Language exams taken while a doctoral student was in a masters program at HDS may be used to fulfill the language requirement if the required grade has been achieved. However, final exam results for the language courses in the Summer Language Program or the full-year German tutorial are not acceptable: doctoral students must take the official language exam.<br /><br />Language Exams: Language competency exams are given three times a year, in early September, early February and late April. A passing level on a language exam attests that a student has sufficient knowledge and skill to use the language in scholarship. Some mistakes in recognizing grammar or vocabulary are allowed if they do not seriously undermine the student's ability to understand the language in question.<br /><br />During the one-hour exam, students are asked to translate a one to two page text of intermediate difficulty. Students may use a dictionary. Language exams are normally given for Hebrew, Greek, Latin, German, French, and Spanish. Students wishing to be tested in another language should consult the Director of Language Studies at HDS.<br /><br />If you have any preparation in the required languages, you are strongly urged to sign up for and take one (or more) of the language qualifying exams given in early September of your first year. You may find that you pass the exam, but even if you do not, you will be much better prepared to choose an appropriate course or study on your own before trying again. A failure is recorded on your internal record sheet, but is never released on a transcript.<br /><br />Th.D. students may take summer language courses without paying extra tuition during the summers immediately preceding and following their first year.<br /> </p><h2>Second Year Review</h2><p>All Th.D. students are required to participate in a Second-Year Review with at least two faculty members. The Th.D. administrator will remind all first year students before the beginning of their second year of this requirement. An “Intent to Take Second Year Review” will be sent to the students and must be returned as soon as possible. Ideally, this review will take place fall semester of the second year.<br /><br />The main purposes of the Second-Year Review are to consider and clarify the overall design and progress of a student’s academic program and to assess the student’s academic progress in general. Two weeks in advance of the Second-Year Review students must submit to the 2 participating faculty members the following: 1) a two-page statement of academic purpose, and 2) two major course papers, one of which should be in the student’s major field and the other in a different field or discipline.<br /> </p><h3>Guidelines for Second Year Review</h3><p>The main purpose of the Second Year Review is to consider and clarify the overall design and progress of a student’s academic program. To this end, a student participating in the Second Year Review must prepare a 2-page statement of academic purpose, to be shared in advance with the faculty who will participate in the review. A copy of this statement should be submitted to the Th.D. Program Administrator with the “Intent to take Second Year Review Form.”<br /><br />A second purpose of the review is to assess the student’s academic progress in general but also in regard to the degree requirements, including foreign languages. A student participating in the Second Year Review must submit two major course papers to their reviewers two weeks in advance. One of these papers should be in the student’s major field and the other in a different field or discipline.<br /><br />A third purpose of the Second Year Review is to review the fields that the student is proposing to cover on the General Examinations.<br /><br />The Second Year Review is to occur either in the third or at the latest, in the fourth semester of study. At the end of a student’s second semester, the program administrator will write a letter to the student and the advisor reminding them of when the Second Year Review should take place.<br /><br />The Second Year Review should, as needed, lead to any or some of the following recommendations: clarifying the timetable for completing any remaining requirements, specifying any further coursework to be taken, the addressing of any issues in advising, clarifying the fields and timetable for General Examinations. A written summary of all such recommendations should be sent to the student as soon as possible after the review, with a copy also sent to the program administrator.<br /><br /><em>March 2004</em></p><p> </p><p> </p></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
</div>
  </div></div></div></div>																																			</div>
								<!--front panel regions end-->
													
											</div>
				</div>

Dissertation Prospectus</a></li><li class="last leaf menu-depth-4 menu-item-32776"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/year-five-and-following-dissertation-and-graduationupon-formal-approval-prospectus" >Year Five and Following: The Dissertation and Graduation</a></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></div></div></div>
  </div></div><section id="block-boxes-1472238788" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_html"  module="boxes" delta="1472238788"><div class="block-inner clearfix">

<meta name="description" content="Grants and Fellowships In preparing for senior thesis work, concentrators in the Study of Religion have often chosen to conduct research in the summer. For example, one student studying Buddhism lived in a Zen monastery in southern Japan for three months; another student working on modern Christianity did fieldwork among Christian activists in Nicaragua; still another student spent a summer tracing the headwaters of the Ganges and studying popular Hinduism." />
<meta property="og:description" content="Grants and Fellowships In preparing for senior thesis work, concentrators in the Study of Religion have often chosen to conduct research in the summer. For example, one student studying Buddhism lived in a Zen monastery in southern Japan for three months; another student working on modern Christianity did fieldwork among Christian activists in Nicaragua; still another student spent a summer tracing the headwaters of the Ganges and studying popular Hinduism." />

<title>Funding for Thesis Research | Committee on the Study of Religion</title>

					<div class="content-inner">
					  <div class="breadcrumb"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/" >HOME</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/undergraduate" >UNDERGRADUATE</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/coursework" >COURSEWORK</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/senior-thesis" >SENIOR HONORS THESIS</a> <span>&#47;</span> </div>
													              <a name="main-content"></a>
															<header id="main-content-header">
									<a name="main-content"></a>
                    <h1 id="page-title">
                      Funding for Thesis Research                    </h1>
                </header>
														
															<!--front panel regions beg-->
								<div id="content-panels" class="at-panel gpanel panel-display content clearfix">
									<div class="region region-content-top"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-os-pages-main-content" class="block block-os-pages no-title"  module="os_pages" delta="main_content"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><article id="node-63486" class="node node-page article clearfix" role="article">
  
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><div class="content">
<div class="wrap">
<div>
<h2>Grants and Fellowships</h2>
<p>In preparing for senior thesis work, concentrators in the Study of Religion have often chosen to conduct research in the summer. For example, one student studying Buddhism lived in a Zen monastery in southern Japan for three months; another student working on modern Christianity did fieldwork among Christian activists in Nicaragua; still another student spent a summer tracing the headwaters of the Ganges and studying popular Hinduism.</p>
<p>Harvard has a number of institutes and centers that provide summer research grants for undergraduate fieldwork and research. Depending upon the project, a student may apply for grants from, among others, the Center for African Studies, the Center for Middle Eastern Studies, the Edwin O. Reischauer Institute of Japanese Studies, the Henry Rosovsky Undergraduate Research Fund, the David Rockefeller Center for Latin American and Iberian Studies, the Center for International Affairs, and the Josephine Murray Traveling Fellowship Program of Radcliffe College. For more information students should consult the Harvard College Funding Sources database, listed below.</p>
<h2>Prizes</h2>
<p><strong>Study of Religion Senior Thesis Prize</strong>. This small monetary prize is given out for a Religion thesis of highest distinction and is presented at the end of the academic year.</p>
<p><strong>Thomas T. Hoopes Prize</strong>. This is a prize open to all undergraduates doing outstanding scholarly work on any topic. The fund provides undergraduate thesis prizes that are given with the purpose of "promoting, improving and enhancing the quality of education." Undergraduates must be nominated by their thesis supervisors.</p>
<p>There are other Harvard College prizes available for outstanding theses and essays. For more information: <a href="http://prizes.fas.harvard.edu" target="_blank">http://prizes.fas.harvard.edu</a>.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
</div>
  </div></div></div></div>									<div class="region region-content-first"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><section id="block-boxes-1374515432" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_html"  module="boxes" delta="1374515432"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
      <h2 class="block-title">Undergraduate Resources</h2>
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1374515432' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><ul><li><a href="http://osl.fas.harvard.edu/icb/icb.do?keyword=k65178&amp;pageid=icb.page305611">Office of Student Life – Student Organizations</a></li>
<li><a href="http://www.ocs.fas.harvard.edu/">Office of Career Services</a></li>
<li><a href="http://www.funding.fas.harvard.edu/">Harvard College Funding Sources</a></li>
<li><a href="http://www.college.harvard.edu/icb/icb.do?keyword=k61161&amp;pageid=icb.page257820">Harvard College</a></li>
<li><a href="http://oie.fas.harvard.edu/">Office of International Education</a></li>
<li><a href="http://cuhs.harvard.edu/">Harvard’s Committee on the Use of Human Subjects</a></li>
</ul><p>Register your travel abroad for emergency support:<br /><a href="https://www.globalsupport.harvard.edu/travel-tools">www.globalsupport.harvard.edu/travel-tools</a></p></div></div></div>
  </div></section></div></div>									<div class="region region-content-second"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><section id="block-boxes-1374163646" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_html"  module="boxes" delta="1374163646"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
      <h2 class="block-title">Guides &amp; Handbooks</h2>
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1374163646' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><ul><li><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/files/religion/files/religious_studies_guide_print_10-1-13.pdf">Guide to Writing in the Study of Religion</a></li>
<li><a href="http://writing.fas.harvard.edu/" target="_blank">Writing Resources at Harvard</a></li>
<li><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/files/religion/files/ab_handbook_2016-7_final_0.pdf">Undergraduate Handbook</a> (2016-17)</li>
<li><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/files/religion/files/senior_thesis_handbook_2015-16_student.pdf">Senior Thesis Handbook</a> (2015-16)</li>
</ul></div></div></div>
  </div></section></div></div>																	</div>

		<div id="columns" class="clearfix">
			<div class="hg-container">
				<div id="content-column" role="main">
					<div class="content-inner">
					  <div class="breadcrumb"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/" >HOME</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/research" >RESEARCH</a> <span>&#47;</span> </div>
													              <a name="main-content"></a>
															<header id="main-content-header">
									<a name="main-content"></a>
                    <h1 id="page-title">
                      Greco-Roman Religions                    </h1>
                </header>
														
															<!--front panel regions beg-->
								<div id="content-panels" class="at-panel gpanel panel-display content clearfix">
									<div class="region region-content-top"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-os-pages-main-content" class="block block-os-pages no-title"  module="os_pages" delta="main_content"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><article id="node-57516" class="node node-page article clearfix" role="article">
  
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p><img height="246" width="645" class="media-element file-default file-os-files-xlarge" src="//static.hwpi.harvard.edu/files/styles/os_files_xlarge/public/religion/files/800px-the_temple_of_olympi_copy_0.jpg?m=1374763375&amp;itok=eA2FNG0p" alt="" title="" /></p>
<h2>Description</h2>
<p><br />Doctoral studies in this field focus primarily on the religions of the ancient Mediterranean, particularly those originating or developing in the civilizations of ancient Greece and ancient Rome, especially from the Minoan to the Late Imperial periods. In approaching the study of the many religious traditions in this arc, students will be encouraged to use a variety of methodologies, attending especially to ritual studies, theological or meaning-making practices of ancient communities, gender analysis, and political, social, and economic contexts. The program trains students to gain facility with a variety of evidentiary sources, including material culture; literature; and archaeological, epigraphic, and papyrological materials. The program includes the expectation of language competency in either Greek or Latin at admission, as well as continued study of languages during the program.</p>
<p></p></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
</div>
  </div></div></div></div>																																			</div>
								<!--front panel regions end-->
													
											</div>
				</div>

				
								  <!--sidebar second region beg-->
				  <div class="region region-sidebar-second sidebar"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-boxes-os-pages-section-nav" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_sectionnav section-nav no-title"  module="boxes" delta="os_pages_section_nav"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-os_pages_section_nav' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><ul class="menu clearfix"><li class="first last expanded active-trail active-trail menu-depth-1 menu-item-31391"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/research"  class="active-trail active">Research</a><ul class="menu clearfix"><li class="first leaf href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/ethics" >Ethics</a></li><li class="leaf active-trail active-trail menu-depth-2 menu-item-31456"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/greco-roman-religions"  class="active-trail active active">Greco-Roman Religions</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-31461"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/jewish-studies" >Jewish Studies </a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-32331"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/new-testament-and-early-christianity" >New Testament and Early Christianity</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-32336"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/philosophy-religion" >Philosophy of Religion</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-32341"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/religion-and-society" >Religion and Society</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-32346"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/religion-gender-and-culture" >Religion, Gender and Culture</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-32356"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/religions-late-antiquity-judaism-and-christianity" >Religions of Late Antiquity: Judaism and Christianity</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-32351"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/religions-americas" >Religions of the Americas</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-32361"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/south-asian-religions" >South Asian Religions</a></li><li class="last leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-32366"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/theology" >Theology</a></li></ul></li></ul></div></div></div>
  </div></div><section id="block-boxes-1374004524" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_sv_list_box"  module="boxes" delta="1374004524"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
      <h2 class="block-title">Affiliated Faculty</h2>
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1374004524' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><div id='box-1374004524-page' data-page='0' data-delta='1374004524' class='os-sv-list os_sv_list_box sv-list-person sv-list-view-title sv-list-layout-list sv-grid-3'><div class="item-list"><ul><li><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/people/john-duffy"  target="_top">John Duffy</a></li><li><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/people/kimberley-patton"  target="_top">Kimberley Patton</a></li></ul></div></div></div></div></div>
  </div></section></div></div>				  <!--sidebar second region end-->
        
			</div>
		</div>
		<!--footer region beg-->
		<footer id="footer" class="clearfix" role="contentinfo">

				<div id="content-column" role="main">
					<div class="content-inner">
					  <div class="breadcrumb"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/" >HOME</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/research" >RESEARCH</a> <span>&#47;</span> </div>
													              <a name="main-content"></a>
															<header id="main-content-header">
									<a name="main-content"></a>
                    <h1 id="page-title">
                      Hebrew Bible/Old Testament                    </h1>
                </header>
														
															<!--front panel regions beg-->
								<div id="content-panels" class="at-panel gpanel panel-display content clearfix">
									<div class="region region-content-top"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-os-pages-main-content" class="block block-os-pages no-title"  module="os_pages" delta="main_content"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><article id="node-57521" class="node node-page article clearfix" role="article">
  
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p><img height="246" width="645" alt="Image Megallit_Esther" title="Megallit_Esther" class="media-element file-default file-os-files-xlarge" src="//static.hwpi.harvard.edu/files/styles/os_files_xlarge/public/religion/files/megillat_esther_1.jpg?m=1376419183&amp;itok=kgUEdoxF" /></p>
<p></p>
<h2>Description</h2>
<p><br />The principal focus of this program lies on the culture of biblical Israel (ca. 1200-150 BCE) within its ancient Near Eastern context. The methods of study are many and diverse. They include the rigorous study of Biblical Hebrew and its historical development within the Semitic family; the recovery of the historical development of the religion of Israel; the literary methods by which the artistry of the prose and poetry of the literature can be analyzed and appreciated; the theological dimensions of the literary corpus, within their original contexts and their recontexualizations in Judaism and Christianity, especially Judaism in the late Second Temple and rabbinic periods (ca. 200 BCE-500 CE) and Christianity in its first several centuries, and within modern religious discourse; and the hermeneutical questions that the interpretation of this ancient corpus in these various frames of reference necessarily raises.<br /><br /></p>
<h2>Requirements</h2>
<p><br />The field of Hebrew Bible/Old Testament requires students to pursue a number of languages to attain the requisite proficiency of a scholar in the field. These include biblical Hebrew, Aramaic, Greek, and German. Students often study others, such as Akkadian, Ugaritic, Egyptian, Modern Hebrew, and French, as well.<br /><br />There are two pre-general doctoral examinations, one in Biblical Hebrew and one in the content of the Hebrew Bible. These are usually taken at the end of the first or beginning of the second year in the program.</p>
<h2>General Examinations</h2>
<p><br />The field requires four general examinations:</p>
<p></p>
<ol><li>The language and textual criticism of the Hebrew Bible/Old Testament.</li>
<li>Issue in Biblical Scholarship, which concentrates on literary, historical, theological, and hermeneutical issues.</li>
<li>An area of concentration, of which the most common are (a) the religion of ancient Israel and the comparative study of religion, (b) pre-exilic history, (c) post-exilic Second Temple history, (d) late Second Temple, early rabbinic, and early Christian interpretation of the Hebrew Bible, and (d) theology of the Hebrew Bible. Students work out their area of concentration with the faculty.</li>
<li>A special topic, to be worked out in consultation with the relevant faculty.</li>
</ol><p>In addition, there are several faculty members from cognate fields who offer invaluable assistance to the program.</p>
<p><br /><em>Recent and current dissertation topics include:</em></p>
<ul><li>An Intellectual and Spiritual Biography of Rabbi Avraham Yitzhaq Ha-Cohen Kook from 1865 to 1904</li>
<li>The Story of David’s Rise as Political Apology: A Reconsideration</li>
<li>A Study of the Neo-Assyrian Intelligence Services and Their Significance for 2 Kings 18-19</li>
<li>The Name of the Ritual: Investigating Ancient Mesopotamian “Hand-lifting” Rituals with Implications for the Interpretation of Genre in the Psalms</li>
<li>Out of the Whirlwind: Creation Theology in the Book of Job</li>
<li>Anti-cultic Theology in Biblical Interpretation: A Study of Isaiah 66:1-4 and Its Reception</li>
<li>The Gendered Language of Warfare in the Israelite/Assyrian Encounter</li>
<li>Harnessing the Prophetic Voice: Studies in Prophetic Expansion in the Second Temple Period</li>
</ul></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
</div>
  </div></div></div></div>																																			</div>
								<!--front panel regions end-->
													
											</div>
				</div>

It is a field that spans the older tradition of the humanities, as well as the younger ones of the social sciences. At Harvard, it has been traditionally rooted in the study of history, languages, and philosophy, and if a bias still exists today, it is in the direction of these fields, in all of which the university is particularly strong." />

	<div id="branding_header">
		<div  class="branding-container clearfix">
		  <div class="branding-left"><a href="http://www.harvard.edu" ><img src="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/profiles/openscholar/themes/hwpi_basetheme/images/harvard-logo.png" width="235" height="32" alt="Harvard Logo" /></a></div><div class="branding-right"><a href="http://www.harvard.edu" >HARVARD.EDU</a></div>		</div>

<div id="page" class="container page os_pages-section-56666 header-main header-right content-top footer-left">
	<div id="page-wrapper">

		
					<!--header regions beg-->
			<header id="header" class="clearfix" role="banner">
			 <div id="header-container">
				 <div id="header-panels" class="at-panel gpanel panel-display three-col clearfix">
