					<div class="content-inner">
					  <div class="breadcrumb"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/" >HOME</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/academics" >ACADEMICS</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/doctoral" >DOCTORAL</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/thd-program" >THD PROGRAM</a> <span>&#47;</span> </div>
													              <a name="main-content"></a>
															<header id="main-content-header">
									<a name="main-content"></a>
                    <h1 id="page-title">
                      Th.D. Program Requirements                    </h1>
                </header>
														
															<!--front panel regions beg-->
								<div id="content-panels" class="at-panel gpanel panel-display content clearfix">
									<div class="region region-content-top"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-os-pages-main-content" class="block block-os-pages no-title"  module="os_pages" delta="main_content"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><article id="node-63326" class="node node-page article clearfix" role="article">
  
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p>Study for the degree of Doctor of Theology extends through four stages: course-work, general examinations, prospectus, and dissertation. Candidates for this degree must fulfill the following:</p><h3>Residence</h3><p>Two years of doctoral study in residence are required. During those two years, students must register for and complete at least four credit courses per term. A student must have achieved the minimum grade point average of "B" in each academic year and meet all regulations governing enrollment of incompletes.</p><h3>Supervision</h3><p>Student progress will be monitored by the doctoral subcommittee of the Committee on the Study of Religion in cooperation with each student’s advisor. Once the prospectus for the dissertation is approved, the dissertation shall be written under the supervision of one or more advisers approved by the Committee.</p><h3>Language Requirements</h3><p>All doctoral students must achieve at least intermediate reading competence in two modern languages of secondary scholarship relevant to their course of study (such as French, German, Japanese), in addition to whatever primary source languages are required in their field, either for textual or ethnographic study. The student and advisor shall consult to decide upon the two modern languages. All language requirements must be met before General Examinations are taken</p><h3>Seminars</h3><p>First-year students are required to take the Common Doctoral Seminar (HDS 4599). Its purpose is to introduce major questions and/or problems in the study of religion and to offer an opportunity for critical reflection on the nature and boundaries of religious and theological inquiry. In addition, students must take the graduate seminars required by their field of concentration, as well as other courses and seminars determined in consultation with an academic adviser.</p><h3>Second Year Review</h3><p>An oral second year review (one-and-one-half hours) occurs in the third, or at the latest, in the fourth semester of study. The purpose of this review is to consider and clarify the overall design and progress of a student’s academic program and to assess the student’s academic progress in general.</p><h3>General Examinations</h3><p>After the satisfactory completion of two years of full-time study, all language requirements, required coursework, and the second year-review, a student prepares for the General Examinations. Th.D. students are normally expected take their General examinations by the end of their third year, except in special cases (e.g., Hebrew Bible and Comparative Religion) where deferment has been previously formally granted. The examination process includes three written exams and one oral exam arranged according to the student’s context of study and specialization. Students in Comparative Religion are required to sit for an additional written examination in Theory and Methods. Students in Hebrew Bible/Old Testament follow the exam rubric required by the Near Eastern Languages and Civilization Department.</p><h3>Prospectus and Dissertation</h3><p>Within twelve months of passing the General Examinations, all candidates must submit a written dissertation prospectus of not more than 3000 words (plus bibliography), formulating a project. Upon formal approval of the prospectus, the student commences the writing of the dissertation. The length is limited to 300 pages. Once the dissertation is completed and approved by the adviser, the candidate must pass an oral dissertation defense with a committee of at least three faculty members before the Th.D. degree is awarded</p><h3>Thesis Defense</h3><p>If the thesis is deemed acceptable by the student's advisor and the Director of Th.D. Studies, the Standing Committee will appoint a committee for the oral defense. If the examining committee accepts the thesis and its defense, and the examination is sustained by the Standing Committee, the original and the first copy of the thesis in bound form, together with their abstracts, and an unbound, boxed copy for University Microfilms International, should be submitted to the Registrar, and a short summary, prepared for publication, should be submitted to the Editor of the Harvard Theological Review, prior to the awarding of the degree.</p><h3>Leaves of Absence</h3><p>At the discretion of the Doctoral Subcommittee, the calendar of requirements as noted above may be interrupted by a maximum of one year's leave of absence. The candidate must pay a $100 program fee during a year on leave.</p><h3>Extensions</h3><p>A student who has not met degree requirements or an established deadline may with the endorsement of the Director of Th.D. Studies be granted an extension, normally for one year.</p><p> </p><p> </p><h2>Satisfactory Progress Requirements for the Th.D. Program</h2><h3><em>(Revised May 2008)</em><br /> </h3><p>Study for Degree of Doctor of Theology extends through four stages: General Examinations, Prospectus, Dissertation, and Dissertation Defense. All students in the Th.D. program at Harvard Divinity School must be making satisfactory progress in order to be eligible for any type of financial aid. [Note: Satisfactory progress includes being on “grace”, or warning, and students may keep their financial aid. Unsatisfactory progress, commonly known as “probation”, would lead to ineligibility for financial aid.] All candidates for this degree must fulfill the following provisions of satisfactory progress to be considered in good standing:</p><p>Residence: Two years of doctoral study in residence with payment of full tuition are normally required. During those two years, students are required to register for and complete at least four credit courses per term. A student must have achieved the minimum grade point average of "B" in each academic year and have met the regulations governing enrollment with incompletes. Following payment of full tuition for two years, the student remains in residence but pays reduced tuition for the next two years. A student subsequently will be charged a Guidance and Facilities Fee for the remainder of his or her studies for the degree. During these periods of residence the student will be considered to be a full time enrolled student unless she or he is paying an Active File Fee for residence outside the Boston area. Supervision: During the student's residency up to approval of the Thesis Prospectus, his or her progress will be monitored by the Doctoral Subcommittee of the Standing Committee on the Study of Religion. Once the Prospectus is approved, the Dissertation shall be written under the supervision of one or more advisors approved by the Standing Committee.<br /><br />Language Requirements: A reading knowledge of two modern languages of scholarship and either Greek, Latin, of Hebrew is required before taking General Examinations. Courses and/or examinations in additional languages may be required by the department of field of concentration or for specific topics of the student's research and thesis. It is possible in some cases, upon petition to the Doctoral Subcommittee, for students to substitute another classical language for one of the above, if it is deemed crucial to the pursuit of their program.<br /><br /><em>Modern Languages</em> -- All doctoral students must achieve at least intermediate reading competence in two modern languages of secondary scholarship relevant to their course of study (such as French, German, Japanese), in addition to whatever primary source languages are required in their field. The student and adviser shall consult to decide upon the two modern languages.<br /><br /><em>Classical Languages</em> -- Candidates are expected to demonstrate their reading proficiency at an intermediate level in one fo the classical languages of scholarship relevant to the student's course of study (normally, Latin, Greek, Hebrew or Arabic). Please refer to the Student Handbook for specific language requirements and detailed information about language examinations.<br /><br />Second-Year Review: All students must participate in a Second-Year Review with at least two faculty members, to occur either in the third or, at the latest, in the fourth semester of study. The main purposes of the Second-Year Review are to consider and clarify the overall design and progress of a student’s academic program and to assess the student’s academic progress in general. Students participating in the Second-Year Review must submit the following, two weeks in advance, to the faculty participating in the review: 1) a two-page statement of academic purpose, and 2) two major course papers, one of which should be in the student’s major field and the other in a different field or discipline.<br /><br />Seminars: One graduate seminar in general theological studies (normally DIV 4599: Common<br />Doctor of Theology Seminar), directed by one or more members of the faculty and focusing on the reading and interpretation of theological literature is required before the General Examinations. In addition, candidates must take the one to three graduate seminars required for their field of concentration, as well as other courses and seminars determined in consultation with an academic advisor.<br /><br />General Examinations: By the end of the third year a student will ordinarily have passed general examinations or the departmental equivalent. Candidates are required to take General Examinations as follows: 1) Two three-hour written examinations in their field of concentration. 2) One three-hour written examination in a special topic chosen and defined by the candidate in consultation with faculty members. This special topic may lie within the area of concentration or may engage other fields of disciplines of academic studies. 3) An oral examination before a committee consisting normally of at least three members of the faculty. Except in special cases (e.g., Old Testament and Comparative Religion) where deferment has been previously formally granted, a prospective fourth-year student must have passed the General Examinations by the end of the third year. (Students in the field of Comparative Religion are required to take a fourth exam in Theory and Methods. Hebrew Bible students must take their General Exams in the Near Easter Languages and Civilization Department of the Faculty of Arts and Sciences. See field guidelines for additional information.)<br /><br />Prospectus: Each candidate's prospectus must be submitted and approved by the standing committee within one year after passing the general examination. Twenty-five copies of the 3000-word prospectus, stating clearly the argument of the thesis and showing why it gives promise of making a contribution to learning, must be presented to the Standing Committee for its approval. The context of the problem and the student's acquaintance with the literature in the field should be indicated. The Standing Committee may vote to accept the prospectus, it may vote to accept the Prospectus provisional upon certain additions to be submitted to the full Committee, or it may ask to student to resubmit a drastically revised Prospectus. The Committee, unless it has reason to reject the prospectus, will then appoint a Prospectus Subcommittee, which will meet with the student and report back to the Standing Committee.<br /><br />Dissertation: The degree shall be awarded on the basis of the successful completion of a doctoral dissertation and its defense before a committee of the faculty. The dissertation shall be written under the supervision of an advisor approved by the Doctoral Subcommittee.<br />Within twelve months of approval of the prospectus and each subsequent year during which a student is allowed to register, she or he must have produced at least one acceptable chapter of the dissertation, or the equivalent. Normally, a thesis should be submitted within two years of approval of the prospectus, but it must be submitted within seven years from the date of admission to the program. After seven years in the program, students may petition the Th.D. director for a one-year extension of time to complete the dissertation. No more than three such petitions for each student will be accepted. The length of the thesis is limited to a maximum of 300 pages, exclusive of bibliography. Three or more unbound copies of the thesis, typed in its final form, must be submitted in spring binders, by August 15 for receipt of the degree in<br />November, by December 1 for its receipt in March, and by April 1 for its receipt at Commencement. A dissertation abstract, with a maximum length of 350 words, must be submitted with each copy.<br /><br />Thesis Defense: If the thesis is deemed acceptable by the Advisor and the Director of Th.D.<br />Studies, the Standing Committee will appoint a Committee for the oral defense. If the examining committee accepts the thesis and its defense, and the examination is sustained by the Standing Committee, the original and first copy of the thesis in bound form should be submitted to the Registrar of Harvard Divinity School, prior to the awarding of the degree. (Please contact the HDS Registrar regarding requirements for electronic submission of a copy to the UMI Dissertation publishing site.)<br /><br />Leaves of Absence: At the discretion of the Doctoral Subcommittee the calendar of requirements as noted above may be interrupted by a maximum of one year's leave of absence.<br />The candidate must pay a $100 program fee during a year on leave.<br /><br />Extensions: A student who has not met degree requirements or an established deadline may with the endorsement of the Director of Th.D. Studies be granted an extension, normally for one year.</p><p> </p><p> </p></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
</div>
  </div></div></div></div>																																			</div>

Program Requirements</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-4 menu-item-32691"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/timeline-0" >Th.D. General Exams</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-4 menu-item-32781"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/year-three-thd-teaching-0" >Year Three: Th.D. Teaching</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-4 menu-item-32761"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/year-four-thd-dissertation-prospectus-0" >Year Four: Th.D. Dissertation Prospectus</a></li><li class="last leaf menu-depth-4 menu-item-32776"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/year-five-and-following-dissertation-and-graduationupon-formal-approval-prospectus" >Year Five and Following: The Dissertation and Graduation</a></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></div></div></div>
  </div></div><section id="block-boxes-1472238788" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_html"  module="boxes" delta="1472238788"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
      <h2 class="block-title">Doctoral Student Handbooks</h2>
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1472238788' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><a href="https://docs.google.com/document/d/139pqOBBoI0KkYhpsZAZiNDa0VU4E-uOZInpygx-Mco8/edit?usp=sharing" target="_blank" title="">Ph.D. Student Handbook</a><br /><a href="http://handbook.gsas.harvard.edu/gsas-handbook" title="">GSAS Student Handbook</a><br /><a href="http://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/files/religion/files/thd_handbook_2016.pdf">Th.D. Student Handbook</a><a href=""  class="os-embed-link" data-delta="1472238788">&lt;embed&gt;</a><div id="embed-popup-1472238788" class="embed-popup"><ul class="links num-links-2"><li class="link-count-iframe first"><a href="#1472238788-iframe" >Iframe</a></li><li class="link-count-oembed last"><a href="#1472238788-oembed" >URL</a></li></ul><div id="1472238788-iframe"><div class="form-item form-type-textarea form-item-web-widgets">

  </div></section><section id="block-boxes-1476823712" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_html"  module="boxes" delta="1476823712"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
      <h2 class="block-title">Forms for Th.D. Program</h2>
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1476823712' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><p><strong>For Th.D. Program Forms, <a href="http://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/thd-program" title="">click here</a>.</strong></p></div></div></div>
  </div></section><section id="block-boxes-1472248730" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_media"  module="boxes" delta="1472248730"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
      <h2 class="block-title">Doctoral Program Calendar</h2>
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1472248730' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><div id="file-697671" class="file file-html file-html-embed">

          <h2 class="element-invisible"><a href="">fd67661077608f54d6ac9d4470ac003a</a></h2>
      
  
  <div class="content">
    <div class="file-info"></div><div class="field field-name-field-html-code field-type-text-long field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><iframe src="https://calendar.google.com/calendar/embed?showTitle=0&amp;showNav=0&amp;showPrint=0&amp;showCalendars=0&amp;showTz=0&amp;mode=AGENDA&amp;height=600&amp;wkst=1&amp;bgcolor=%23cccccc&amp;src=harvard.edu_tdumcqt6psi863e4fqd2re2tek%40group.calendar.google.com&amp;color=%23cccccc&amp;src=9qpvg4b8brruceh6v118kbht2k%40group.calendar.google.com&amp;color=%23cccccc&amp;ctz=America%2FNew_York" style="border-width:0" width="260" height="600" frameborder="0" scrolling="no"></iframe></div></div></div>  </div>

			 <div id="header-container">

					  					  <div class="region region-header-second"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-boxes-site-info" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_site_info no-title"  module="boxes" delta="site_info"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-site_info' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><h1><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/" >Committee on the Study of Religion</a></h1>
    
    <p>
    </p></div></div></div>
  </div></div></div></div>					  					  <div class="region region-header-third"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-os-secondary-menu" class="block block-os no-title"  module="os" delta="secondary-menu"><div class="block-inner clearfix">

"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/south-asian-religions"  title="">South Asian Religions</a></li><li class="menu-3294 menu-path-node-61731   even   last  active-trail"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/theology"  title="" class="active active">Theology</a></li></ul></li><li class="menu-2615 menu-path-people-taxonomy-term-12866   odd  "><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/people/taxonomy/term/12866" >People</a></li><li class="menu-2338 menuparent  menu-path-node-56666   even  "><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/about"  title="">About</a><span class="open-submenu"></span><ul><li class="menu-2607 menu-path-node-63446  first   odd  "><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/historical-overview" >Historical Overview</a></li><li class="menu-2360 menu-path-node-57086   even  "><a   </nav></div>		  <!--main menu region end-->
		
    
		<div id="columns" class="clearfix">
			<div class="hg-container">
				<div id="content-column" role="main">
					<div class="content-inner">
					  <div class="breadcrumb"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/" >HOME</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/research" >RESEARCH</a> <span>&#47;</span> </div>
													              <a name="main-content"></a>
															<header id="main-content-header">
									<a name="main-content"></a>
                    <h1 id="page-title">
                      Theology                    </h1>
                </header>
														
															<!--front panel regions beg-->
								<div id="content-panels" class="at-panel gpanel panel-display content clearfix">
									<div class="region region-content-top"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-os-pages-main-content" class="block block-os-pages no-title"  module="os_pages" delta="main_content"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><article id="node-61731" class="node node-page article clearfix" role="article">
  
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p><img height="246" width="645" class="media-element file-default file-os-files-xlarge" src="//static.hwpi.harvard.edu/files/styles/os_files_xlarge/public/religion/files/vier_apostel_albrecht_duerer.jpg?m=1376419416&amp;itok=J62vkpBl" alt="" title="" /></p>
<p></p>
<h2></h2>
<h2>Description</h2>
<p><br />The field of theology involves the self-understandings of faith and practice in historical, contemporary and comparative contexts. The faculty at Harvard has particular strength in Christianity, comparative theology and modern religious thought. Special attention is given to: analyses of the contexts, constraints, methods and genres of theological reflection; relationships among religious traditions; and modern critiques of religion.</p>
<p></p>
<p><em>Recent and current dissertation topics include:</em></p>
<ul><li>The Ladder of Thorns: Søren Kierkegaard on the Varieties of Suffering</li>
<li>The Doctrine of the Soul’s Immortality in Sixteenth-Century German Lutheran Theology</li>
<li>Perceiving Splendor: The “Doctrine of the Spiritual Senses” in Hans Urs von Balthasar’s Theological Aesthetics</li>
<li>Leaning over the Abyss: Raissa Maritain (1883-1960) and the French Catholic Revival</li>
<li>Cosmic Theodicy: Origen on the Problem of Evil</li>
<li>The Humanity of Christ in Karl Barth’s Church Dogmatics</li>
<li>Hume and Hope: A Study in David Hume’s Philosophy of Religion</li>
<li>The Workshop of Being: A Comparative Study of Jonathan Edwards and William James</li>
<li>Between Irony and Witness: Kierkegaard’s Poetics of Faith, Hope and Love</li>
<li>Veiled and Unveiled Others: Revisiting Karl Barth’s Gender Trouble</li>
<li>THOU ART On Representation of the Word and the Incarnation of the Human Subject: A Christological Aesthetics</li>
<li>The Subject of Emancipation: Critique, Reason and Religion in the Thought of Theodor Adorno, Max Horkheimer, and Paul Tillich</li>
<li>The Frail Agony of Grace: Story, Act, and Sacrament in the Fiction of Cormac McCarthy</li>
</ul></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
</div>
  </div></div></div></div>																																			</div>
								<!--front panel regions end-->
													
											</div>
				</div>

				
								  <!--sidebar second region beg-->
				  <div class="region region-sidebar-second sidebar"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-boxes-os-pages-section-nav" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_sectionnav section-nav no-title"  module="boxes" delta="os_pages_section_nav"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-os_pages_section_nav' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><ul class="menu clearfix"><li class="first last expanded active-trail   </div></div><section id="block-boxes-1374005705" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_sv_list_box"  module="boxes" delta="1374005705"><div class="block-inner clearfix">

				<div id="content-column" role="main">
					<div class="content-inner">
					  <div class="breadcrumb"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/" >HOME</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/academics" >ACADEMICS</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/doctoral" >DOCTORAL</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/thd-program" >THD PROGRAM</a> <span>&#47;</span> </div>
													              <a name="main-content"></a>
															<header id="main-content-header">
									<a name="main-content"></a>
                    <h1 id="page-title">
                      Th.D. Timeline                    </h1>
                </header>
														
															<!--front panel regions beg-->
								<div id="content-panels" class="at-panel gpanel panel-display content clearfix">
									<div class="region region-content-top"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-os-pages-main-content" class="block block-os-pages no-title"  module="os_pages" delta="main_content"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><article id="node-63276" class="node node-page article clearfix" role="article">
  
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><h2>SUMMARY OF REQUIREMENTS<br /> </h2><h3>The First Two Years: Pre-Generals Requirements</h3><h4>Th.D. Plan of Study</h4><ul><li>The student must, in consultation with the advisor, submit a Plan of Study during their first term by early November to the program administrator. This plan will be reviewed by the Director of ThD studies.</li></ul><h4>Coursework</h4><ul><li>Courses required for specialization</li><li>Common Doctoral Seminar (first semester)</li></ul><h4>Languages</h4><ul><li>Two modern languages of secondary scholarship</li><li>Other languages as required for specialization</li></ul><h4>Second Year Review</h4><ul><li>To occur by the end of the fourth semester</li></ul><h3><br />Year Three: Generals</h3><h4>General Examinations</h4><ul><li>to be completed by the end of the third year</li></ul><h3><br />Year Four: Prospectus</h3><h4>Dissertation Prospectus</h4><ul><li>To be completed and accepted within one year of taking of the general exams</li></ul><h3><br />Year Five and Following: Dissertation</h3><h4>The Dissertation</h4><ul><li>To be completed normally within seven years of entrance to the program</li><li>After approval of the prospectus, at least one chapter per year must be submitted to the advisor</li></ul></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
</div>
  </div></div></div></div>																																			</div>
								<!--front panel regions end-->
													
											</div>
				</div>

				
								  <!--sidebar second region beg-->
				  <div class="region region-sidebar-second sidebar"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-boxes-os-pages-section-nav" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_sectionnav section-nav no-title"  module="boxes" delta="os_pages_section_nav"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-os_pages_section_nav' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><ul class="menu clearfix"><li class="first last expanded active-trail active-trail menu-depth-1 menu-item-31161"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/academics"  class="active-trail active">Academics</a><ul class="menu clearfix"><li class="first leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-31166"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/undergraduate" >Undergraduate</a></li><li class="last expanded active-trail active-trail menu-depth-2 menu-item-31171"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/doctoral"  class="active-trail active">Doctoral</a><ul class="menu clearfix"><li class="first collapsed menu-depth-3 menu-item-31306"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/phd-program" >PhD Program &amp; Timeline</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-3 menu-item-33061"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/links-doctoral-students" >Links for Doctoral Students</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-3 menu-item-32971"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/faqs-doctoral" >FAQ&#039;s: Doctoral</a></li><li class="last expanded active-trail active-trail menu-depth-3 menu-item-31311"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/thd-program"  class="active-trail active">ThD Program</a><ul class="menu clearfix"><li class="first leaf menu-depth-4 menu-item-32706"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/thd-program-requirements" >Th.D. Program Requirements</a></li><li class="leaf active-trail active-trail menu-depth-4 menu-item-32691"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/timeline-0"  class="active-trail active active">Th.D. Timeline</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-4 menu-item-32716"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/first-two-years-pre-generals-requirements" >The First Two Years: ThD Pre-Generals</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-4 menu-item-32756"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/year-three-thd-general-exams-0" >Year Three: Th.D. General Exams</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-4 menu-item-32781"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/year-three-thd-teaching-0" >Year Three: Th.D. Teaching</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-4 menu-item-32761"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/year-four-thd-dissertation-prospectus-0" >Year Four: Th.D. Dissertation Prospectus</a></li><li class="last leaf menu-depth-4 menu-item-32776"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/year-five-and-following-dissertation-and-graduationupon-formal-approval-prospectus" >Year Five and Following: The Dissertation and Graduation</a></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></div></div></div>
  </div></div><section id="block-boxes-1472238788" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_html"  module="boxes" delta="1472238788"><div class="block-inner clearfix">

		<div id="columns" class="clearfix">

				<div id="content-column" role="main">
					<div class="content-inner">
					  <div class="breadcrumb"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/" >HOME</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/undergraduate" >UNDERGRADUATE</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/coursework" >COURSEWORK</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/tutorial-system" >TUTORIAL SYSTEM</a> <span>&#47;</span> </div>
													              <a name="main-content"></a>
															<header id="main-content-header">
									<a name="main-content"></a>
                    <h1 id="page-title">
                      Sophmore                    </h1>
                </header>
														
															<!--front panel regions beg-->
								<div id="content-panels" class="at-panel gpanel panel-display content clearfix">
									<div class="region region-content-top"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-os-pages-main-content" class="block block-os-pages no-title"  module="os_pages" delta="main_content"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><article id="node-63441" class="node node-page article clearfix" role="article">
  
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p></p>
<p><strong>The Sophomore Tutorial</strong> (Rel. 97) is a required seminar for all sophomores and new junior concentrators. Its purpose is to introduce students to different methods and theories in the Study of Religion. The course covers major themes and arguments that have defined the field—including, for example, arguments about the nature of religion, ritual, myth, scripture and culture. The sophomore tutorial will also help students narrow their range of interests, preparing them for more in-depth work in their junior and senior years. By the end of the sophomore year, students will have been introduced to the field and to the analytical tools scholars use to interpret religious phenomena.</p>
<p>In the sophomore tutorial students will have opportunities to raise general questions and test ideas in a congenial, collaborative atmosphere. Responsibility for leading discussion is shared. The tutorial also helps to develop an <em>esprit de corps</em> among new members of the concentration.</p>
<p>Writing is a key component of work in the sophomore tutorial; students submit short and medium-length papers and receive detailed feedback on style and content. Of course, the pursuit of clear expository writing will continue in later years, but the process begins in earnest sophomore year. Students should devote their full energies to keeping up with readings and assignments, and they should participate actively in discussions.</p></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
</div>
  </div></div></div></div>									<div class="region region-content-first"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><section id="block-boxes-1374178945" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_html"  module="boxes" delta="1374178945"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
      <h2 class="block-title">Plan of Study Forms for Undergraduates</h2>
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1374178945' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><ul><li><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/files/religion/files/ab_option_a_2014-15_writeable.doc">Option A: Two Major Traditions in Comparative Context</a></li>
<li><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/files/religion/files/ab_option_b_2014-15_writeable.doc">Option B: One Major Tradition in Comparative Context</a></li>
<li><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/files/religion/files/ab_option_c_2014-15_writeable.doc">*Option C: Joint Concentration with Religion as the Primary Field</a></li>
<li><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/files/religion/files/ab_option_d_2014-15_writeable.doc">*Option D: Joint Concentration with Religion as a Allied Field</a></li>
<li><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/files/religion/files/ab_secondary_field_2014-15_writeable.doc">Religion as a Secondary Field</a></li>
</ul><p>*Students pursuing a Joint Concentration must also complete the college form<a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/files/religion/files/joint_conc_app_2_-_without_list_of_programs.pdf"> "Joint Concentration Application".</a></p></div></div></div>
  </div></section></div></div>									<div class="region region-content-second"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><section id="block-boxes-1374163646" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_html"  module="boxes" delta="1374163646"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
      <h2 class="block-title">Guides &amp; Handbooks</h2>
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1374163646' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><ul><li><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/files/religion/files/religious_studies_guide_print_10-1-13.pdf">Guide to Writing in the Study of Religion</a></li>
<li><a href="http://writing.fas.harvard.edu/" target="_blank">Writing Resources at Harvard</a></li>
<li><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/files/religion/files/ab_handbook_2016-7_final_0.pdf">Undergraduate Handbook</a> (2016-17)</li>
<li><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/files/religion/files/senior_thesis_handbook_2015-16_student.pdf">Senior Thesis Handbook</a> (2015-16)</li>
</ul></div></div></div>
  </div></section></div></div>																	</div>
								<!--front panel regions end-->
													
											</div>
				</div>

				
								  <!--sidebar second region beg-->
				  <div class="region region-sidebar-second sidebar"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-boxes-os-pages-section-nav" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_sectionnav section-nav no-title"  module="boxes" delta="os_pages_section_nav"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-os_pages_section_nav' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><ul class="menu clearfix"><li class="first last expanded active-trail active-trail menu-depth-1 menu-item-146421"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/undergraduate"  class="active-trail active">Undergraduate</a><ul class="menu clearfix"><li class="first leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-32966"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/faqs-undergraduate-program" >FAQ&#039;s: Undergraduate Program</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-35426"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/courses" >Courses</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-32561"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/admission" >Concentrating</a></li><li class="collapsed menu-depth-2 menu-item-32581"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/advising" >Advising</a></li><li class="expanded active-trail active-trail menu-depth-2 menu-item-32596"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/coursework"  class="active-trail active">Coursework</a><ul class="menu clearfix"><li class="first leaf menu-depth-3 menu-item-32711"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/coursework/introductory" >Introductory Courses</a></li><li class="expanded active-trail active-trail menu-depth-3 menu-item-32771"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/tutorial-system"  class="active-trail active">Tutorial System</a><ul class="menu clearfix"><li class="first leaf active-trail active-trail menu-depth-4 menu-item-32811"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/tutorial-sophmore"  class="active-trail active active">Sophmore</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-4 href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/beyond-harvard-0" >Beyond Harvard</a></li></ul></li></ul></div></div></div>
  </div></div><section id="block-boxes-1373989095" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_html"  module="boxes" delta="1373989095"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
      <h2 class="block-title">Concentration Questions?</h2>
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1373989095' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><p><a href="http://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/people/courtney-bickel-lamberth">Director of Undergraduate Studies, Courtney Lamberth</a></p>
<p><a href="mailto:kstreet@fas.harvard.edu">Assistant Director of Undergraduate Studies, Kera Street</a></p></div></div></div>
  </div></section><section id="block-boxes-1364321266" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_html"  module="boxes" delta="1364321266"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
      <h2 class="block-title">Words from our Students</h2>
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1364321266' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><address>"The structure of the concentration gives students a lot of flexibility and freedom to explore the religions and themes they're interested in. In my experience, the professors are also very involved and want to get to know you on a personal level, which is something you don't get in the larger concentrations." – Hebert, '13</address></div></div></div>
  </div></section></div></div>				  <!--sidebar second region end-->
        
			</div>
		</div>
		<!--footer region beg-->
		<footer id="footer" class="clearfix" role="contentinfo">
		<!-- Three column 3x33 Gpanel -->
		
			<div class="at-panel gpanel panel-display footer clearfix">

They are our most important courses, and students should treat them as such. The Sophomore tutorial is usually taught by faculty members; junior tutorials are taught by advanced graduate students; and the senior tutorial involves faculty, graduate students, and the Assistant Director of Undergraduate Studies." />

					<!--header regions beg-->
			<header id="header" class="clearfix" role="banner">
			 <div id="header-container">
				 <div id="header-panels" class="at-panel gpanel panel-display three-col clearfix">
					  					  <div class="region region-header-second"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-boxes-site-info" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_site_info no-title"  module="boxes" delta="site_info"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-site_info' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><h1><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/" >Committee on the Study of Religion</a></h1>
    
    <p>
    </p></div></div></div>
  </div></div></div></div>					  					  <div class="region region-header-third"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-os-secondary-menu" class="block block-os no-title"  module="os" delta="secondary-menu"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><ul class="nice-menu nice-menu-down nice-menu-secondary-menu" id="nice-menu-secondary-menu"><li class="menu-22511 menu-path-faq  first   odd  "><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/faq"  title="List of FAQs">FAQ</a></li><li class="menu-2605 menu-path-node-63151   even  "><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/apply-phd" >Apply PhD</a></li><li class="menu-6668 menu-path-studyofreligionfasharvardedu-pages-forms   odd  "><a href="http://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/forms"  title="For Current Students &amp; Faculty">Forms</a></li><li class="menu-2603 menu-path-node-57086   even   last "><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/contact" >Contact</a></li></ul>
</div>

href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/religion-and-society"  title="">Religion and Society</a></li><li class="menu-3300 menu-path-node-61721   odd  "><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/religions-late-antiquity-judaism-and-christianity"  title="">Religions of Late Antiquity: Judaism and Christianity</a></li><li class="menu-3292 menu-path-node-61716   even  "><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/religions-americas"  title="">Religions of the Americas</a></li><li class="menu-3293 menu-path-node-61726   odd  "><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/south-asian-religions"  title="">South Asian Religions</a></li><li class="menu-3294 menu-path-node-61731   even   last "><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/theology"  title="">Theology</a></li></ul></li><li class="menu-2615 menu-path-people-taxonomy-term-12866   odd  "><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/people/taxonomy/term/12866" >People</a></li><li class="menu-2338 menuparent  menu-path-node-56666   even  "><a   </nav></div>		  <!--main menu region end-->
		
    
		<div id="columns" class="clearfix">
			<div class="hg-container">
				<div id="content-column" role="main">
					<div class="content-inner">
					  <div class="breadcrumb"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/" >HOME</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/undergraduate" >UNDERGRADUATE</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/coursework" >COURSEWORK</a> <span>&#47;</span> </div>
													              <a name="main-content"></a>
															<header id="main-content-header">
									<a name="main-content"></a>
                    <h1 id="page-title">
                      Tutorial System                    </h1>
                </header>
														
															<!--front panel regions beg-->
								<div id="content-panels" class="at-panel gpanel panel-display content clearfix">
									<div class="region region-content-top"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-os-pages-main-content" class="block block-os-pages no-title"  module="os_pages" delta="main_content"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><article id="node-63391" class="node node-page article clearfix" role="article">
  
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p>Tutorials are the core of our program. They are designed as a sequence of small seminars focused on critical thinking and writing skills. They are our most important courses, and students should treat them as such. The Sophomore tutorial is usually taught by faculty members; junior tutorials are taught by advanced graduate students; and the senior tutorial involves faculty, graduate students, and the Assistant Director of Undergraduate Studies.</p>
<div class="topic">
<div class="topic-wrap">
<div class="content">
<div class="wrap">
<div>
<p>Students entering the concentration late can make up Religion tutorials. Only in rare instances can they be replaced by other courses.</p>
<h3>Tutorial Staff</h3>
<p>The tutorial staff consists of faculty members and advanced graduate students who offer tutorials to juniors and seniors in the Study of religion. Because junior tutorials provide specialized, in-depth study of particular themes, texts, traditions, or time periods, tutors can offer tutorials in their expertise. An undergraduate may work with a junior tutor, or encounter a section leader in a large religion course, someone who shares his or her interests, and approach that person about being their senior thesis advisor.</p>
<p>Along with members of the tutorial staff, teaching fellows and house tutors in religion gather regularly during the semester to discuss the teaching process and related issues like advising and grading. Occasionally, resource persons from the Writing Center, Bureau of Study Counsel, and the Bok Center for Teaching and Learning are invited to conduct these meetings and offer advice. All graduate students teaching in the religion concentration are requested to participate in workshops sponsored by the Bok Center for Teaching and Learning. In general, tutors and teaching fellows are an important resource for undergraduate concentrators, and we encourage students to seek their counsel.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
</div>
  </div></div></div></div>									<div class="region region-content-first"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><section id="block-boxes-1374178945" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_html"  module="boxes" delta="1374178945"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
      <h2 class="block-title">Plan of Study Forms for Undergraduates</h2>
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1374178945' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><ul><li><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/files/religion/files/ab_option_a_2014-15_writeable.doc">Option A: Two Major Traditions in Comparative Context</a></li>
<li><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/files/religion/files/ab_option_b_2014-15_writeable.doc">Option B: One Major Tradition in Comparative Context</a></li>
<li><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/files/religion/files/ab_option_c_2014-15_writeable.doc">*Option C: Joint Concentration with Religion as the Primary Field</a></li>
<li><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/files/religion/files/ab_option_d_2014-15_writeable.doc">*Option D: Joint Concentration with Religion as a Allied Field</a></li>
<li><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/files/religion/files/ab_secondary_field_2014-15_writeable.doc">Religion as a Secondary Field</a></li>
</ul><p>*Students pursuing a Joint Concentration must also complete the college form<a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/files/religion/files/joint_conc_app_2_-_without_list_of_programs.pdf"> "Joint Concentration Application".</a></p></div></div></div>
  </div></section></div></div>									<div class="region region-content-second"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><section id="block-boxes-1374163646" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_html"  module="boxes" delta="1374163646"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
      <h2 class="block-title">Guides &amp; Handbooks</h2>
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1374163646' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><ul><li><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/files/religion/files/religious_studies_guide_print_10-1-13.pdf">Guide to Writing in the Study of Religion</a></li>
<li><a href="http://writing.fas.harvard.edu/" target="_blank">Writing Resources at Harvard</a></li>
<li><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/files/religion/files/ab_handbook_2016-7_final_0.pdf">Undergraduate Handbook</a> (2016-17)</li>
<li><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/files/religion/files/senior_thesis_handbook_2015-16_student.pdf">Senior Thesis Handbook</a> (2015-16)</li>
</ul></div></div></div>
  </div></section></div></div>																	</div>
								<!--front panel regions end-->
													
											</div>
				</div>

  </div></div><section id="block-boxes-1364321266" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_html"  module="boxes" delta="1364321266"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
      <h2 class="block-title">Words from our Students</h2>
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1364321266' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><address>"The structure of the concentration gives students a lot of flexibility and freedom to explore the religions and themes they're interested in. In my experience, the professors are also very involved and want to get to know you on a personal level, which is something you don't get in the larger concentrations." – Hebert, '13</address></div></div></div>
  </div></section><section id="block-boxes-1373989095" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_html"  module="boxes" delta="1373989095"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
      <h2 class="block-title">Concentration Questions?</h2>
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1373989095' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><p><a href="http://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/people/courtney-bickel-lamberth">Director of Undergraduate Studies, Courtney Lamberth</a></p>
<p><a href="mailto:kstreet@fas.harvard.edu">Assistant Director of Undergraduate Studies, Kera Street</a></p></div></div></div>
  </div></section></div></div>				  <!--sidebar second region end-->

		<div id="columns" class="clearfix">
			<div class="hg-container">
				<div id="content-column" role="main">
					<div class="content-inner">
					  <div class="breadcrumb"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/" >HOME</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/academics" >ACADEMICS</a> <span>&#47;</span> </div>
													              <a name="main-content"></a>
															<header id="main-content-header">
									<a name="main-content"></a>
                    <h1 id="page-title">
                      Undergraduate                    </h1>
                </header>
														
															<!--front panel regions beg-->
								<div id="content-panels" class="at-panel gpanel panel-display content clearfix">
									<div class="region region-content-top"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-os-pages-main-content" class="block block-os-pages no-title"  module="os_pages" delta="main_content"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><article id="node-56826" class="node node-page article clearfix" role="article">
  
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p>Harvard’s concentration in the Comparative Study of Religion is a vibrant community comprised of dynamic, devoted students and the nation’s most distinguished teaching faculty in the study of religion.  Students interact regularly with faculty and graduate students who share their interests. The program provides students with an understanding of the religious traditions of the world through study of sacred texts and rituals; philosophy, literature and theology; and the lived experiences and history of participants in the tradition.  Courses engage life’s biggest questions including the meaning of life and death, humanity and divinity, good and evil, sacrifice and community.  Course work exposes students to central concepts in the field such as god(s), ritual, gender, authority, orthodoxy, scripture and prophecy.  Anthropological, historical, philosophical, phenomenological, sociological and literary approaches open religion to closer analysis and deeper understanding.</p>
<p>Students consistently rate our concentration and courses very highly.  Tutorials are small, tailored to student interests and designed to develop and refine students’ ability to analyze texts closely and to write coherently.  Close attention to excellent writing--through drafting, comments and revising--is a priority in our tutorial program. <em><br /><br /></em>Concentrators pursue a wide range of careers after graduation, including business, law, medicine, politics, public service, scholarship, creative art and teaching.  Recent graduates are studying at Harvard Law School, teaching with Teach for America, pursuing graduate work at Cambridge University, practicing medicine and starring in television roles.  Our students consistently report back to us that the understanding of religion, the critical thinking skills, and the refined writing ability they gained in this concentration have been significantly important in making sense of current events and global politics, and in succeeding in their workplaces and local communities.  Most of our graduates have a strong interest in service to their communities and are committed to working in their chosen profession to make the world a better place. </p>
<p><em>The Undergraduate section of this site reflects the information found in the Undergraduate Handbook, which is the standard reference work for requirements, rules, and advising procedures in the Study of Religion and it updated annually. Faculty advisers and tutorial leaders will assume students are familiar with it. Please read its contents carefully.</em></p></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
</div>
  </div></div><div id="block-boxes-1469475875" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_media no-title"  module="boxes" delta="1469475875"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1469475875' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><div id="file-678781" class="file file-html file-html-embed">

          <h2 class="element-invisible"><a href="">A.B. Study of Religion Calendar</a></h2>
      
  
  <div class="content">
    <div class="file-info"></div><div class="field field-name-field-html-code field-type-text-long field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><iframe src="https://calendar.google.com/calendar/embed?title=A.B.%20Study%20of%20Religion%20Calendar&amp;mode=AGENDA&amp;height=400&amp;wkst=1&amp;bgcolor=%23FFFFFF&amp;src=harvard.edu_gknbrjcsb0f1j1sjif3rua58l8%40group.calendar.google.com&amp;color=%23711616&amp;ctz=America%2FNew_York" style="border-width:0" width="600" height="400" frameborder="0" scrolling="no"></iframe></div></div></div>  </div>

  
</div>
</div></div></div>
  </div></div></div></div>									<div class="region region-content-first"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><section id="block-boxes-1374163646" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_html"  module="boxes" delta="1374163646"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
      <h2 class="block-title">Guides &amp; Handbooks</h2>
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1374163646' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><ul><li><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/files/religion/files/religious_studies_guide_print_10-1-13.pdf">Guide to Writing in the Study of Religion</a></li>
<li><a href="http://writing.fas.harvard.edu/" target="_blank">Writing Resources at Harvard</a></li>
<li><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/files/religion/files/ab_handbook_2016-7_final_0.pdf">Undergraduate Handbook</a> (2016-17)</li>
<li><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/files/religion/files/senior_thesis_handbook_2015-16_student.pdf">Senior Thesis Handbook</a> (2015-16)</li>
</ul></div></div></div>
  </div></section><section id="block-boxes-1374515432" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_html"  module="boxes" delta="1374515432"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
      <h2 class="block-title">Undergraduate Resources</h2>
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1374515432' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><ul><li><a href="http://osl.fas.harvard.edu/icb/icb.do?keyword=k65178&amp;pageid=icb.page305611">Office of Student Life – Student Organizations</a></li>

  </div></section></div></div>									<div class="region region-content-second"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><section id="block-boxes-1374178945" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_html"  module="boxes" delta="1374178945"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
      <h2 class="block-title">Plan of Study Forms for Undergraduates</h2>
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1374178945' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><ul><li><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/files/religion/files/ab_option_a_2014-15_writeable.doc">Option A: Two Major Traditions in Comparative Context</a></li>
<li><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/files/religion/files/ab_option_b_2014-15_writeable.doc">Option B: One Major Tradition in Comparative Context</a></li>
<li><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/files/religion/files/ab_option_c_2014-15_writeable.doc">*Option C: Joint Concentration with Religion as the Primary Field</a></li>
<li><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/files/religion/files/ab_option_d_2014-15_writeable.doc">*Option D: Joint Concentration with Religion as a Allied Field</a></li>
<li><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/files/religion/files/ab_secondary_field_2014-15_writeable.doc">Religion as a Secondary Field</a></li>
</ul><p>*Students pursuing a Joint Concentration must also complete the college form<a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/files/religion/files/joint_conc_app_2_-_without_list_of_programs.pdf"> "Joint Concentration Application".</a></p></div></div></div>
  </div></section></div></div>																	</div>

				  <div class="region region-sidebar-second sidebar"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-boxes-os-pages-section-nav" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_sectionnav section-nav no-title"  module="boxes" delta="os_pages_section_nav"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-os_pages_section_nav' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><ul class="menu clearfix"><li class="first last expanded active-trail active-trail menu-depth-1 menu-item-31161"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/academics"  class="active-trail active">Academics</a><ul class="menu clearfix"><li class="first leaf active-trail active-trail menu-depth-2 menu-item-31166"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/undergraduate"  class="active-trail active active">Undergraduate</a></li><li class="last collapsed menu-depth-2 menu-item-31171"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/doctoral" >Doctoral</a></li></ul></li></ul></div></div></div>
  </div></div><section id="block-boxes-1373989095" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_html"  module="boxes" delta="1373989095"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
      <h2 class="block-title">Concentration Questions?</h2>
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1373989095' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><p><a href="http://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/people/courtney-bickel-lamberth">Director of Undergraduate Studies, Courtney Lamberth</a></p>
<p><a href="mailto:kstreet@fas.harvard.edu">Assistant Director of Undergraduate Studies, Kera Street</a></p></div></div></div>
  </div></section><section id="block-boxes-1472238788" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_html"  module="boxes" delta="1472238788"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
      <h2 class="block-title">Doctoral Student Handbooks</h2>
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1472238788' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><a href="https://docs.google.com/document/d/139pqOBBoI0KkYhpsZAZiNDa0VU4E-uOZInpygx-Mco8/edit?usp=sharing" target="_blank" title="">Ph.D. Student Handbook</a><br /><a href="http://handbook.gsas.harvard.edu/gsas-handbook" title="">GSAS Student Handbook</a><br /><a href="http://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/files/religion/files/thd_handbook_2016.pdf">Th.D. Student Handbook</a><a href=""  class="os-embed-link" data-delta="1472238788">&lt;embed&gt;</a><div id="embed-popup-1472238788" class="embed-popup"><ul class="links num-links-2"><li class="link-count-iframe first"><a href="#1472238788-iframe" >Iframe</a></li><li class="link-count-oembed last"><a href="#1472238788-oembed" >URL</a></li></ul><div id="1472238788-iframe"><div class="form-item form-type-textarea form-item-web-widgets">

  </div></section><section id="block-boxes-1476823074" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_html"  module="boxes" delta="1476823074"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
      <h2 class="block-title">Forms for Current Students in Ph.D. Program</h2>
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1476823074' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><p>These forms are for students who are *enrolled* in the Ph.D. program. <strong>Do *not* request access</strong> if you are applying to the Ph.D. program.</p><ul><li><a href="https://docs.google.com/a/harvard.edu/document/d/16wlb4LD2NgMteJ7X0q_9d418vFBUBU1qjjcrFOXdP2I/edit?usp=sharing" title="">Plan of Study</a></li><li><a href="https://goo.gl/forms/w80b6mQGPVRBOIi33" title="">Intent to Take the Second Year Review</a></li><li><a href="https://goo.gl/forms/qrVDPsjLzTIIeWM32" title="">Intent to Take General Exams</a></li><li><a href="https://docs.google.com/a/harvard.edu/document/d/1uLO2yz184gawZctHd6uawOwB4auSDdueAnmytjk3TGY/edit?usp=sharing" title="">Dissertation Prospectus Checklist</a></li></ul></div></div></div>
  </div></section><section id="block-boxes-1364321266" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_html"  module="boxes" delta="1364321266"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
      <h2 class="block-title">Words from our Students</h2>
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1364321266' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><address>"The structure of the concentration gives students a lot of flexibility and freedom to explore the religions and themes they're interested in. In my experience, the professors are also very involved and want to get to know you on a personal level, which is something you don't get in the larger concentrations." – Hebert, '13</address></div></div></div>
  </div></section><section id="block-boxes-1374086388" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_html"  module="boxes" delta="1374086388"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
      <h2 class="block-title">Approved Traditions and Themes</h2>
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1374086388' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><h3>Approved Traditions</h3>
<ul><li>Ancient Near Eastern / Israelite</li>
<li>Buddhist</li>
<li>Christian</li>
<li>East Asian</li>
<li>Greek-Hellenistic-Roman</li>
<li>Hindu</li>
<li>Islamic</li>
<li>Judaic</li>
<li>Modern Western / Religions of the Americas</li>
<li>South Asian</li>
<li>African and Afro-Atlantic Religions</li>
</ul><h3>Approved Themes</h3>
<ul><li>Religion and Gender</li>
<li>Religion and Society</li>
<li>Religion and the Arts</li>
<li>Philosophy of Religion</li>
</ul><p><em>It may be possible to substitute other traditions or themes depending on faculty and course offerings.</em></p></div></div></div>
  </div></section><section id="block-boxes-1476823712" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_html"  module="boxes" delta="1476823712"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
      <h2 class="block-title">Forms for Th.D. Program</h2>
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1476823712' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><p><strong>For Th.D. Program Forms, <a href="http://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/thd-program" title="">click here</a>.</strong></p></div></div></div>
  </div></section><section id="block-boxes-1472248730" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_media"  module="boxes" delta="1472248730"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
      <h2 class="block-title">Doctoral Program Calendar</h2>
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1472248730' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><div id="file-697671" class="file file-html file-html-embed">

          <h2 class="element-invisible"><a href="">fd67661077608f54d6ac9d4470ac003a</a></h2>
      
  
  <div class="content">
    <div class="file-info"></div><div class="field field-name-field-html-code field-type-text-long field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><iframe src="https://calendar.google.com/calendar/embed?showTitle=0&amp;showNav=0&amp;showPrint=0&amp;showCalendars=0&amp;showTz=0&amp;mode=AGENDA&amp;height=600&amp;wkst=1&amp;bgcolor=%23cccccc&amp;src=harvard.edu_tdumcqt6psi863e4fqd2re2tek%40group.calendar.google.com&amp;color=%23cccccc&amp;src=9qpvg4b8brruceh6v118kbht2k%40group.calendar.google.com&amp;color=%23cccccc&amp;ctz=America%2FNew_York" style="border-width:0" width="260" height="600" frameborder="0" scrolling="no"></iframe></div></div></div>  </div>

  
</div>
</div></div></div>
  </div></section></div></div>				  <!--sidebar second region end-->
        
			</div>
		</div>

As part of most offers of admission, doctoral students are guaranteed teaching fellowships in the third and fourth year for their living expenses. Students are encouraged to take advantage of these opportunities in courses found in the Study of Religion and other FAS departments, as well as in the Harvard Divinity School." />

As part of most offers of admission, doctoral students are guaranteed teaching fellowships in the third and fourth year for their living expenses. Students are encouraged to take advantage of these opportunities in courses found in the Study of Religion and other FAS departments, as well as in the Harvard Divinity School." />

					  					  <div class="region region-header-second"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-boxes-site-info" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_site_info no-title"  module="boxes" delta="site_info"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-site_info' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><h1><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/" >Committee on the Study of Religion</a></h1>
    
    <p>
    </p></div></div></div>
  </div></div></div></div>					  					  <div class="region region-header-third"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-os-secondary-menu" class="block block-os no-title"  module="os" delta="secondary-menu"><div class="block-inner clearfix">

menu-path-node-61716   even  "><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/religions-americas"  title="">Religions of the Americas</a></li><li class="menu-3293 menu-path-node-61726   odd  "><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/south-asian-religions"  title="">South Asian Religions</a></li><li class="menu-3294 menu-path-node-61731   even   last "><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/theology"  title="">Theology</a></li></ul></li><li class="menu-2615 menu-path-people-taxonomy-term-12866   odd  "><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/people/taxonomy/term/12866" >People</a></li><li class="menu-2338 menuparent  menu-path-node-56666   even  "><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/about"  title="">About</a><span class="open-submenu"></span><ul><li class="menu-2607 menu-path-node-63446  first   odd  "><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/historical-overview" >Historical Overview</a></li><li class="menu-2360 menu-path-node-57086   even  "><a >Courses</a></li><li class="menu-2809 menu-path-node-63841   even  "><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/links"  title="">Related Organizations</a></li><li class="menu-2339   </nav></div>		  <!--main menu region end-->
		
    
		<div id="columns" class="clearfix">
			<div class="hg-container">
				<div id="content-column" role="main">
					<div class="content-inner">
					  <div class="breadcrumb"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/" >HOME</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/academics" >ACADEMICS</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/doctoral" >DOCTORAL</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/phd-program" >PHD PROGRAM &amp; TIMELINE</a> <span>&#47;</span> </div>
													              <a name="main-content"></a>
															<header id="main-content-header">
									<a name="main-content"></a>
                    <h1 id="page-title">
                      Year 3 &amp; 4: Teaching                    </h1>
                </header>
														
															<!--front panel regions beg-->
								<div id="content-panels" class="at-panel gpanel panel-display content clearfix">
									<div class="region region-content-top"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-os-pages-main-content" class="block block-os-pages no-title"  module="os_pages" delta="main_content"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><article id="node-63236" class="node node-page article clearfix" role="article">
  
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p><span>While teaching is not required for the degree, it is considered integral to the program. As part of most offers of admission, doctoral students are guaranteed teaching fellowships in the third and fourth year for their living expenses. Students are encouraged to take advantage of these opportunities in courses found in the Study of Religion and other FAS departments, as well as in the Harvard Divinity School.</span></p><p><span>Students are prioritized for teaching fellowship positions in years three and four. Normally first-year and second-year students may not teach. Students are expected to seek out teaching fellow positions by directly approaching faculty with whom they would like to work. Students should provide a resume and a brief statement of academic interests, as well as any experience and subject matter preferences. Students should inform the Program Administrator of courses they are pursuing and appointments offered to them.</span></p><p><strong><span>As of September 2016, GSAS updated their policy on teaching fellowships for cohort 2016 and forward. Please review the GSAS student handbook for details. </span></strong></p><p><span>Additionally, there are junior and senior tutorials in the undergraduate concentration (contact the Director of Undergraduate Studies) and other courses across Harvard, including “MOOC’s”, that offer teaching options at different schedules and compensations from routine teaching fellowship sections.</span></p><p><span>First time teaching fellows are required to participate in the Bok Center orientation week training sessions, as well as: 1) Day 1 of the Fall Teaching Conference at the Derek Bok Center for Teaching and Learning; 2) A workshop on Diversity in the Classroom such as the one on day 2 of the Bok Center for Teaching and Learning fall conference; 3) A departmental workshop on leading discussions (early in term); 4) A departmental workshop on grading and responding to student writing (early in mid-term.)The Study of Religion program workshops are organized each year by our Departmental Teaching Fellow, in addition to the training and workshops held throughout the year at the Bok Center. The Departmental Teaching Fellow maintains a website with extensive teaching information: </span><a href="http://projects.iq.harvard.edu/teachingfellows_studyofreligion/home"><span>http://projects.iq.harvard.edu/teachingfellows_studyofreligion/home</span></a><span> and works with the CSR staff to coordinate several workshops during the year, as well as attends required events with the Derek Bok Center and holds regular office hours in Barker 408. That office is also available for working TFs to meet with students during the term; it may be reserved through the CSR office.</span></p><h4><a href="http://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/teaching-fellows-cats" title="">Read about the pilot tool, Central Application for Teaching Sections or "CATS", launching now for spring 2017 select courses.</a></h4></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
</div>
  </div></div></div></div>									<div class="region region-content-first"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><section id="block-boxes-1374077585" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_html"  module="boxes" delta="1374077585"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
      <h2 class="block-title">Courses</h2>
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1374077585' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><p></p>
<ul><li><strong><a href="https://my.harvard.edu/">my.harvard.edu</a> - for current students and faculty</strong><a href="http://coursecatalog.harvard.edu/icb/icb.do" target="_blank"></a></li>
<li><a href="http://coursecatalog.harvard.edu/icb/icb.do" target="_blank">Harvard University Course Catalog</a> - searchable database across schools</li>
<li><a href="http://www.registrar.fas.harvard.edu/faculty-staff/classrooms">FAS Course Meetings Location Report</a></li>
<li><strong>Historical: </strong><a href="http://www.registrar.fas.harvard.edu/courses-exams/courses-instruction/study-religion">FAS Registrar Courses of Instruction, The Study of Religion section</a></li>
</ul></div></div></div>
  </div></section></div></div>									<div class="region region-content-second"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><section id="block-boxes-1476461984" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_html"  module="boxes" delta="1476461984"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
      <h2 class="block-title">Central Application for Teaching Sections</h2>
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1476461984' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><p><a href="http://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/teaching-fellows-cats" title="Read about the pilot tool, Central Application for Teaching Sections or &quot;CATS&quot;, launching now for spring 2017 select courses.">Central Application for Teaching Sections or "CATS"</a></p><p><a href="http://registrar.fas.harvard.edu/faculty-staffcourses/catalog-coordinator" title="">Preliminary Course Catalog Listings</a> (accessible to students and faculty)</p><p> </p></div></div></div>
  </div></section></div></div>																	</div>
								<!--front panel regions end-->
													
											</div>
				</div>

				
								  <!--sidebar second region beg-->
				  <div class="region region-sidebar-second sidebar"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-boxes-os-pages-section-nav" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_sectionnav section-nav no-title"  module="boxes" delta="os_pages_section_nav"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-os_pages_section_nav' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><ul class="menu clearfix"><li class="first last expanded active-trail active-trail menu-depth-1 menu-item-31161"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/academics"  class="active-trail active">Academics</a><ul class="menu clearfix"><li class="first leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-31166"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/undergraduate" >Undergraduate</a></li><li class="last expanded active-trail active-trail menu-depth-2 menu-item-31171"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/doctoral"  class="active-trail active">Doctoral</a><ul class="menu clearfix"><li class="first expanded active-trail active-trail menu-depth-3 menu-item-31306"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/phd-program"  class="active-trail active">PhD Program &amp; Timeline</a><ul class="menu clearfix"><li class="first leaf menu-depth-4 menu-item-32681"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/doctoral-advising" >Advising</a></li><li class="menu-depth-4 menu-item-32586"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/years-1-%26-2" >Years 1 &amp;
