up: The Dissertation</a></li></ul></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-3 menu-item-33061"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/links-doctoral-students" >Links for Doctoral Students</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-3 menu-item-32971"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/faqs-doctoral" >FAQ&#039;s: Doctoral</a></li><li class="last collapsed menu-depth-3 menu-item-31311"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/thd-program" >ThD Program</a></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></div></div></div>
  </div></div><section id="block-boxes-1472238788" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_html"  module="boxes" delta="1472238788"><div class="block-inner clearfix">

				<div id="content-column" role="main">
					<div class="content-inner">
					  <div class="breadcrumb"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/" >HOME</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/academics" >ACADEMICS</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/doctoral" >DOCTORAL</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/phd-program" >PHD PROGRAM &amp; TIMELINE</a> <span>&#47;</span> </div>
													              <a name="main-content"></a>
															<header id="main-content-header">
									<a name="main-content"></a>
                    <h1 id="page-title">
                      Year 3: General Exams                    </h1>
                </header>
														
															<!--front panel regions beg-->
								<div id="content-panels" class="at-panel gpanel panel-display content clearfix">
									<div class="region region-content-top"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-os-pages-main-content" class="block block-os-pages no-title"  module="os_pages" delta="main_content"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><article id="node-63211" class="node node-page article clearfix" role="article">
  
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p>After the satisfactory completion of two years of full-time study, the modern language requirements, the coursework outside the specialization, and the second year review, a students prepare for the General Examinations. Ph.D. students usually take these examinations by the end of the third year. All INC's should be resolved before General Examinations.</p><p>Written examinations take place in October during fall term and in April during spring term. The Committee announces the exact dates six months ahead of time, and students must submit the <a href="https://goo.gl/forms/uWnXiZpIkJ000XC03">"Notice of Intent to Take Ph.D. General Examinations in the Study of Religion"</a>, signed or confirmed via email by their advisor, by late September for spring term generals, or by late March for fall term generals. Bibliographies for each exam are also due at that time.</p><p>The overall pattern of the written general examinations required of all Ph.D. students follows. The student should consult with his or her advisor in formulating the plan for the exams and deciding upon examiner(s) for each exam.</p><p>1. Theory and Method in the Study of Religion<br />2. Context of Study Exam (Religious Tradition or Historical Complex)<br />3. Specialization within Context of Study<br />4. Specialization within Context of Study</p><p>Each examination is taken in a 3-hour period, and each examination or part offers a choice of 2-3 questions. A 2-hour oral examination will be held within the two weeks following the written general exams. The examining committee for the oral normally consists of the faculty members who prepared written exams for a given student.</p><h3>The Theory and Method Exam</h3><h4>Goals of the Exam</h4><p>Building on work done in Religion 2001 and 2002, the Theory and Method doctoral exam invites students to consider both the history of religious studies as a discipline and contemporary theoretical discussions about religion in relation to their own particular subfields. In replacing the old generic exam with this new, more theoretically driven and individually tailored exam, the Committee acts on the belief that students preparing themselves for professional lives in the study of religion need to have a clear sense of issues of current moment in the discipline; students must be able to frame the particulars of their research interests in the wider context of religious studies more generally, to enter the details of their own disciplines into broader conversations that cross particular subfields. Through this exam, we also seek to help students develop an understanding of the history of the study of religion, of the making of “religion” and “the religions” as categories of various sorts of inquiry from the early modern period to the present, in the context of wider intellectual, social and cultural history. In preparing for this exam, students are also encouraged to think about major historical and contemporary theorists of religion in the broader context of the social, cultural, and political history of knowledge from the Enlightenment to the present, and in particular in relation to the place of the construction of “religions” and “religion” in this history.</p><h4>Structure of the Exam</h4><p>The Theory and Method examination consists of three parts:</p><ol><li>a section on the History of the study of “religion” and the “religions” and/or of other concepts central to the study of religion from the enlightenment to the present.</li><li>a section on contemporary conversations in the study of religion that focuses on issues and problems of current intellectual urgency across the study of religion.</li><li>a final section on two theorists of religion or of theorists particularly useful for the study of religion. This bibliography should include both primary source material representing the major works of each theorist, as well as secondary literature on the work and contributions of each.</li></ol><h4>Preparing for the Exam</h4><p>Each student must chose a Theory and Method examiner and submit a reading list according to the Committee schedule. The student will work out in advance with the TM examiner particular problems or concerns for the student to concentrate on in his or her preparation. Examiners will be responsible for writing individually tailored examination questions, in consultation with the student.</p><p>Working with an individual faculty member serves to make room for students to bring their own interests and concerns into current conversations in the discipline and to learn to view their own areas of specialization within the wider frame of the history of the study of religion. The Committee intends that students make their substantive areas of academic concern (the development of a particular ritual in Tibetan Buddhism, a problem of interpretation in Deuteronomy, a figure in American Catholic history, or an issue in Karl Barth’s theology, to cite some examples) the pivot of the theoretical learning and engagement that characterizes the new Theory and Method examination.</p><p>Questions to pose in the task of working out specific foci for each part of the exam might include: how does a particular student’s research contribute to, participate in, or change the terms and orientations of contemporary conversations across the field? What is the specific history of their area of specialization (the intellectual history of the making of “Buddhism,” for instance) in its relationship to the broader cultural history of the study of religions? How do the theorists they have chosen to work on help them sharpen questions of religious analysis in their work?</p><p><em>Committee on the Study of Religion<br />Adopted May 22, 2009</em></p><h2>Additional Exam Policies</h2><ul><li><h4><strong><a href="http://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/substituting-paper-fourth-exam">Substituting a Paper for the Fourth Exam</a></strong></h4></li><li><h4><strong><a href="http://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/submission-of-general-exams">Submission of General Exams</a></strong></h4></li><li><h4><strong><a href="http://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/policy-failure-general-exams">Policy on Failure of General Exams</a></strong></h4></li></ul></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
</div>
  </div></div></div></div>																																			</div>
								<!--front panel regions end-->
													
											</div>
				</div>

				
								  <!--sidebar second region beg-->
				  <div class="region region-sidebar-second sidebar"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-boxes-os-pages-section-nav" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_sectionnav section-nav no-title"  module="boxes" delta="os_pages_section_nav"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-os_pages_section_nav' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><ul class="menu clearfix"><li class="first last expanded active-trail active-trail menu-depth-1 menu-item-31161"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/academics"  class="active-trail active">Academics</a><ul class="menu clearfix"><li class="first leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-31166"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/undergraduate" >Undergraduate</a></li><li class="last expanded active-trail active-trail menu-depth-2 menu-item-31171"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/doctoral"  class="active-trail active">Doctoral</a><ul class="menu clearfix"><li class="first expanded active-trail active-trail menu-depth-3 menu-item-31306"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/phd-program"  class="active-trail active">PhD Program &amp; Timeline</a><ul class="menu clearfix"><li class="first leaf menu-depth-4 menu-item-32681"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/doctoral-advising" >Advising</a></li><li class="menu-depth-4 menu-item-32586"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/years-1-%26-2" >Years 1 &amp; 2</a></li><li class="leaf active-trail active-trail menu-depth-4 menu-item-32631"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/year-3-general-exams"  class="active-trail active active">Year 3: General Exams</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-4 menu-item-32656"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/year-3-%26-4-teaching" >Year 3 &amp; 4: Teaching</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-4 menu-item-32661"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/year-4-dissertation-prospectus" >Year 4: Dissertation Prospectus</a></li><li class="last leaf menu-depth-4 menu-item-32666"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/year-5-the-dissertation" >Year 5 &amp; up: The Dissertation</a></li></ul></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-3 menu-item-33061"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/links-doctoral-students" >Links for Doctoral Students</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-3 menu-item-32971"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/faqs-doctoral" >FAQ&#039;s: Doctoral</a></li><li class="last collapsed menu-depth-3 menu-item-31311"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/thd-program" >ThD Program</a></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></div></div></div>
  </div></div><section id="block-boxes-1472238788" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_html"  module="boxes" delta="1472238788"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
      <h2 class="block-title">Doctoral Student Handbooks</h2>
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1472238788' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><a href="https://docs.google.com/document/d/139pqOBBoI0KkYhpsZAZiNDa0VU4E-uOZInpygx-Mco8/edit?usp=sharing" target="_blank" title="">Ph.D. Student Handbook</a><br /><a href="http://handbook.gsas.harvard.edu/gsas-handbook" title="">GSAS Student Handbook</a><br /><a href="http://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/files/religion/files/thd_handbook_2016.pdf">Th.D. Student Handbook</a><a href=""  class="os-embed-link" data-delta="1472238788">&lt;embed&gt;</a><div id="embed-popup-1472238788" class="embed-popup"><ul class="links num-links-2"><li class="link-count-iframe first"><a href="#1472238788-iframe" >Iframe</a></li><li class="link-count-oembed last"><a href="#1472238788-oembed" >URL</a></li></ul><div id="1472238788-iframe"><div class="form-item form-type-textarea form-item-web-widgets">
  <label for="web_widgets_1">Embed code </label>

</div></div></div></div></div>
  </div></section><section id="block-boxes-1476823074" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_html"  module="boxes" delta="1476823074"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
      <h2 class="block-title">Forms for Current Students in Ph.D. Program</h2>
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1476823074' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><p>These forms are for students who are *enrolled* in the Ph.D. program. <strong>Do *not* request access</strong> if you are applying to the Ph.D. program.</p><ul><li><a href="https://docs.google.com/a/harvard.edu/document/d/16wlb4LD2NgMteJ7X0q_9d418vFBUBU1qjjcrFOXdP2I/edit?usp=sharing" title="">Plan of Study</a></li><li><a href="https://goo.gl/forms/w80b6mQGPVRBOIi33" title="">Intent to Take the Second Year Review</a></li><li><a href="https://goo.gl/forms/qrVDPsjLzTIIeWM32" title="">Intent to Take General Exams</a></li><li><a href="https://docs.google.com/a/harvard.edu/document/d/1uLO2yz184gawZctHd6uawOwB4auSDdueAnmytjk3TGY/edit?usp=sharing" title="">Dissertation Prospectus Checklist</a></li></ul></div></div></div>
  </div></section><section id="block-boxes-1472248730" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_media"  module="boxes" delta="1472248730"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
      <h2 class="block-title">Doctoral Program Calendar</h2>
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1472248730' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><div id="file-697671" class="file file-html file-html-embed">

          <h2 class="element-invisible"><a href="">fd67661077608f54d6ac9d4470ac003a</a></h2>
      
  
  <div class="content">
    <div class="file-info"></div><div class="field field-name-field-html-code field-type-text-long field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><iframe src="https://calendar.google.com/calendar/embed?showTitle=0&amp;showNav=0&amp;showPrint=0&amp;showCalendars=0&amp;showTz=0&amp;mode=AGENDA&amp;height=600&amp;wkst=1&amp;bgcolor=%23cccccc&amp;src=harvard.edu_tdumcqt6psi863e4fqd2re2tek%40group.calendar.google.com&amp;color=%23cccccc&amp;src=9qpvg4b8brruceh6v118kbht2k%40group.calendar.google.com&amp;color=%23cccccc&amp;ctz=America%2FNew_York" style="border-width:0" width="260" height="600" frameborder="0" scrolling="no"></iframe></div></div></div>  </div>

<meta name="description" content="The prospectus is a proposal formulated by the student about the intended doctoral dissertation. Within, at most, twelve months of passing generals,the student is expected to submit a the prospectus. Acceptance of the prospectus by the Standing Committee constitutes a kind of contract by which the full Committee agrees that if the student completes a successful dissertation that is in accord with, or a reasonable development from, what the prospectus delineates, it will recommend the degree." />
<meta property="og:description" content="The prospectus is a proposal formulated by the student about the intended doctoral dissertation. Within, at most, twelve months of passing generals,the student is expected to submit a the prospectus. Acceptance of the prospectus by the Standing Committee constitutes a kind of contract by which the full Committee agrees that if the student completes a successful dissertation that is in accord with, or a reasonable development from, what the prospectus delineates, it will recommend the degree." />

  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-site_info' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><h1><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/" >Committee on the Study of Religion</a></h1>
    
    <p>
    </p></div></div></div>
  </div></div></div></div>					  					  <div class="region region-header-third"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-os-secondary-menu" class="block block-os no-title"  module="os" delta="secondary-menu"><div class="block-inner clearfix">

		<div id="columns" class="clearfix">
			<div class="hg-container">
				<div id="content-column" role="main">
					<div class="content-inner">
					  <div class="breadcrumb"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/" >HOME</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/academics" >ACADEMICS</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/doctoral" >DOCTORAL</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/phd-program" >PHD PROGRAM &amp; TIMELINE</a> <span>&#47;</span> </div>
													              <a name="main-content"></a>
															<header id="main-content-header">
									<a name="main-content"></a>
                    <h1 id="page-title">
                      Year 4: Dissertation Prospectus                    </h1>
                </header>
														
															<!--front panel regions beg-->
								<div id="content-panels" class="at-panel gpanel panel-display content clearfix">
									<div class="region region-content-top"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-os-pages-main-content" class="block block-os-pages no-title"  module="os_pages" delta="main_content"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><article id="node-63241" class="node node-page article clearfix" role="article">
  
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p>The prospectus is a proposal formulated by the student about the intended doctoral dissertation. Within, at most, twelve months of passing generals,the student is expected to submit a the prospectus. Acceptance of the prospectus by the Standing Committee constitutes a kind of contract by which the full Committee agrees that if the student completes a successful dissertation that is in accord with, or a reasonable development from, what the prospectus delineates, it will recommend the degree.</p><p>It is the responsibility of the student to formulate, with as much advice and consultation as appropriate, a signifcant and worthwhile dissertation project that others will recognize as a solid contribution both to the chosen subfield and to the study of religion more generally. <strong>Each dissertation, in making a contribution to knowledge, should also illuminate our understanding of religion.</strong></p><p>The student must choose a member of the Harvard faculty to supervise the prospectus and two or three additional faculty members to serve on the prospectus committee. The supervisor will most likely, but not necessarily, be the advisor who has been overseeing the student’s program to that point.</p><p>The prospectus is written for The Standing Committee on the Study of Religion as a whole, to whom it must be intelligible and cogent. Most Committee members will not be experts in the student's particular specialty. <strong>It should be no more than 3000 words double-spaced, excluding bibliography and notes. It is to be submitted electronically to the Program Administrator 2 weeks in advance of the Standing Committee meeting at which it will be considered.</strong></p><p>The CSR will accept prospectuses at all of its meetings up to and including the April meeting. If a larger number of prospectuses is received at the April meeting, some may be tabled and discussed at the May CSR meeting. NO NEW PROSPECTUSES WILL BE ACCEPTED FOR THE MAY MEETING.</p><h4>Advisor Responsibilities</h4><p>Advisors are expected to be involved actively in the development of the prospectus—especially with regard to its scope and purpose—and to guide the student through early drafts.</p><p>When the prospectus is ready to be submitted to the Standing Committee, the student’s advisor should confirm that all of the formal guidelines for the prospectus have been met, by signing the "Prospectus Checklist", which is attached. If the student's advisor will not be able to attend the Standing Committee meeting in which the prospectus is being discussed, he or she should write a covering letter to the Chair of the Committee, indicating an evaluation of the project and a willingness to supervise the work. This letter also proposes two or three faculty members, in addition to the advisor, to serve as members of a prospectus committee. While the majority of the prospectus committee will be scholars in the  student's particular specialty, others outside his or her field might be included as well. The advisor should ascertain that these other scholars have read the draft of the prospectus, and be prepared to represent their views at the Standing Committee meeting.</p><h4>Standing Committee Responsibilities</h4><p>The Director of Graduate Studies or other appropriate faculty meets with doctoral students at the beginning of each academic year to discuss the prospectus process in detail.</p><p>There will also be a discussion of the entire prospectus process among faculty at the beginning of each academic year in a CSR meeting. This discussion will review the ethos and culture of the process, including the responsibility of all CSR faculty to read each prospectus carefully in advance, with the larger expectation that all theses address issues in the Study of Religion. CSR members should alert the advisor to any substantive concerns one week in advance of the meeting. The advisor may suggest changes with the student before the prospectus comes before the committee. Although it is rarely necessary, the student may opt to withdraw the draft for later submission. It is important that these professors have read the draft and conveyed their thoughts to the student and main advisor before it is submitted to the CSR.</p><p>Once the prospectus is submitted it will be considered, along with comments of the advisor, by the Standing Committee at its earliest scheduled meeting. When the CSR approves the prospectus, it also approves the thesis committee, on occasion making recommendations for additions or adjustments. In every case, the advisor is a member of the prospectus committee.</p><p>Please note that additional substantive questions may be raised during the discussion of the prospectus at the CSR meeting; there is no obligation on the part of the Standing Committee to pass a prospectus. If a prospectus is turned back to the student for revisions, it will be resubmitted to the doctoral subcommittee for approval, including approval of the dissertation committee.</p><p>Once the Standing Committee approves a prospectus, it will then refer it to the prospectus committee who will meet with the student to discuss the project in depth. Normally this is a two-hour meeting. The prospectus committee then reports back to the Standing Committee, recommending final approval of the proposal. In some cases the prospectus committee may indicate that it has asked the student to make some revisions and that it will delay its formal recommendation until they have been received. The prospectus committee, once its recommendation has been approved by the Standing Committee, is disbanded.</p><h4>Drafting a Dissertation Prospectus</h4><p>The purpose of a prospectus is to enable students: (1) to clarify what they conceive to be the nature and significance of their prospective dissertation work, and (2) to receive constructive criticism, advice and approval from both the full Committee on the Study of Religion and members of a prospectus committee. Formulating a prospectus for the faculty represents a significant stage in the course of dissertation work, and its importance should not be underestimated. Not only does it allow students to come to a fuller and more adequate understanding of their own project; it also enlists the active support of the faculty who are expected to provide significant advice and criticism at this crucial stage in its development.</p><p><strong>While there are no well-established formulas or models for writing a prospectus, every prospectus should attend to the following issues:</strong></p><ol><li><p><strong>Topic and thesis</strong><br /><br />There is an important distinction between a topic and a thesis. A topic represents the issue which the dissertation addresses. A thesis constitutes the position which the student takes in relation to the topic; i.e., the central hypothesis which is to be examined.<br />For example:</p><blockquote style="margin:0 0 0 40px; border:none; padding:0px"><ul><li><em>Topic: Barth’s theological method</em></li><li><em>Thesis: Barth's theological method results from his interpretation of the Word of God as an act which is not subject to human manipulation.</em></li></ul></blockquote><p><br />In the prospectus, students should carefully circumscribe the topic of their dissertation, including historical and conceptual analyses of the topic (to the extent that such analyses clarify what the student takes to be at issue). The aim is not only to show how the dissertation will be done, but that the student is familiar enough with the topic that the project can be done and done within a reasonable timeframe. Students should be thinking about possible dissertation topics as they prepare for General exams, with the hope that the exam process will move easily into the writing of the prospectus.</p></li><li><p><strong>Sources, Method, and Theory</strong><br /><br />The prospectus must also be clear about the sources upon which the dissertation will depend, the method/s the student will be using, and where appropriate, the theoretical resources that will be relevant to their work. In discussing method, it is especially important to attend to any special problems that might occur in the course of research and to note how these problems might be addressed.</p></li><li><p><strong>Contribution to Scholarship</strong><br /><br />Students should specify as carefully as they can what they consider to be the various ways their project will contribute to the field of study in which they work. Students will include a brief statement of the current status of their topic within their larger field of study, to indicate the various problems at issue, and to show how their project will advance the discussion. Prospectuses are reviewed by the full Standing Committee and the concern of that committee includes the extent to which dissertation work can be understood to contribute not only to particular fields of study but also to the broader study of religion, continuing the intellectual work begun in Religion 2001 and 2002. Students are encouraged to articulate the contribution of their research to a future horizon of the community concerned with the study of religion in connection to the received heritage of religious studies and on contemporary discussions and debates, as topic and thesis are formulated and developed and as the worth of the project for scholarship is stated.</p></li><li><p><strong>Chapter Outline</strong><br /><br />The prospectus must provide an outline of the chapter divisions and a brief description of how the argument will be developed from chapter to chapter.</p></li><li><p><strong>Bibliography</strong><br /><br />The prospectus must include a brief bibliography indicating the principal primary and secondary sources upon which the thesis is expected to be based - it need not be exhaustive, but representative.</p></li></ol></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
</div>
  </div></div></div></div>																																			</div>
								<!--front panel regions end-->
													
											</div>
				</div>

					<div class="content-inner">
					  <div class="breadcrumb"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/" >HOME</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/academics" >ACADEMICS</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/doctoral" >DOCTORAL</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/phd-program" >PHD PROGRAM &amp; TIMELINE</a> <span>&#47;</span> </div>
													              <a name="main-content"></a>
															<header id="main-content-header">
									<a name="main-content"></a>
                    <h1 id="page-title">
                      Year 5 &amp; up: The Dissertation                    </h1>
                </header>
														
															<!--front panel regions beg-->
								<div id="content-panels" class="at-panel gpanel panel-display content clearfix">
									<div class="region region-content-top"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-os-pages-main-content" class="block block-os-pages no-title"  module="os_pages" delta="main_content"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><article id="node-63246" class="node node-page article clearfix" role="article">
  
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p><span>Upon formal approval of the prospectus, the student commences the writing of the dissertation. Following the approval of the prospectus, one chapter per year of the dissertation must be submitted to the advisor. The length of dissertations is limited to a maximum of approximately 75,000 words or 300 pages, exclusive of bibliography. Permission to exceed this length may be granted by the Doctoral Subcommittee or the Chairman at the request of the dissertation advisor. </span></p><p><span>Once the dissertation is completed and approved by the advisor, the degree candidate is examined orally by a committee of at least three faculty readers, two of whom must be members of the Faculty of Arts and Sciences. In practice, any member of HDS faculty who is eligible to serve on the Standing Committee in the Study of Religion is authorized to sign Dissertation Acceptance Certificates as FAS members. Any faculty members from other schools at Harvard who have held or currently hold appointments in the CSR are authorized to sign Dissertation Acceptance Certificates as FAS members.</span></p><p dir="ltr"><b>Please review this comprehensive guide to degree submission, form of dissertation, and electronic submisssion to Registrar: <a href="https://gsas.harvard.edu/academics/dissertations">Dissertations: A Guide to Preparing and Submitting Your Dissertation</a>.</b></p><p>The entire Ph.D. program should not exceed seven years. Students who do not complete the degree in seven years must petition the Committee for an extension of time in the program. Petitions may be made only for one year at a time. In such a petition, the student and the dissertation advisor must present evidence of reasonable and substantial progress as well as a timetable for completion of the dissertation. Extensions will not be granted beyond the tenth year.</p><h4>The Timing of Submission to the Standing Committee</h4><p>When you are within reach of completing your dissertation draft, your dissertation advisor should write a letter to the Standing Committee proposing an examining committee. <u>The advisor’s letter should be received at least one week prior to the Standing Committee meeting at which it would be considered</u>. Please check the <a href="http://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/calendars" target="_blank" title="">website calendar for meeting dates of the Standing Committee</a> or contact the office of the Study of Religion for dates in order that you and your advisor may plan the timing of submission and defense. </p><p><span>The final dissertation draft must be submitted directly to each reader and to the Study of Religion Office. Once the examining committee is in place, a date for the dissertation defense will be set. <strong>In anticipating a defense date, keep in mind that your readers may need up to <u>six weeks</u> of reading time. </strong>You will need to prepare a dissertation abstract, not to exceed 350 words, prior to the dissertation defense. This document is required for publication in Dissertation Abstracts International.</span></p><p><span><strong>Prior to your defense</strong>, the Program Administrator will prepare and deliver to the Chair of your committee your Dissertation Acceptance Certificate (DAC). If no revisions are required, or as soon as any and all revisions are completed, and all examiners have signed the DAC, it should be returned to the Study of Religion office. The completed DAC will be scanned for the student and for the office; the original will be delivered to the Registrar’s Office.</span></p><p><span>Upon submission of the electronic copy of the dissertation, you will be required to submit a signed University Microfilms International form (included in the Registrar’s online submission tool).</span></p><p><strong>Degree Applicant Deadlines</strong> - The submission and application dates are generally the same each year. Students must check for the current deadlines, as late submissions are not accepted. The previous year’s dates can be used as a guide for planning, until a current year’s deadlines are posted.</p><h4><span>Registration During Dissertation Years</span></h4><p>Throughout your doctoral program, you must be registered as a full-time student. You may register in various ways depending on your location, financial needs and progress to degree. Please review the <a href="http://handbook.gsas.harvard.edu/non-resident-students" target="_blank" title="">Non-Resident option in the GSAS Student Handbook</a>. If you need to interrupt your program, you may register for a <a href="http://handbook.gsas.harvard.edu/leave-absence" title="">Leave of Absence by application to GSAS</a>. Students may also benefit from the <a href="http://handbook.gsas.harvard.edu/exchange-scholar-program" target="_blank" title="">Exchange Scholar Program</a>, which allows for registration with a select group of schools which participate in the program with Harvard GSAS.</p><h4><b>Graduation &amp; Diplomas</b></h4><p>An application for degree must be submitted by the deadline indicated in the Degree Calendar for a student to receive a degree from a GSAS degree program on one of the three annual degree conferral dates. <a href="http://handbook.gsas.harvard.edu/application-degree">Please refer to the current guidelines for preparation and submission of the dissertation in the GSAS Handbook</a>.</p><p>Online submission of the dissertation is required by the Graduate School. Please review the <a href="http://registrar.fas.harvard.edu/registration-enrollment-degrees/graduation-diplomas/phd-dissertation-submission">submission details found on the FAS Registrar’s site.</a> No exceptions are granted for late submissions, nor are improperly formatted submissions accepted. <a href="http://dissertation.gsas.harvard.edu/formatting-guidelines">Carefully review the formatting guidelines - you are responsible for proper formatting of the required documents.</a></p><p><em>The signed, original </em>Dissertation Acceptance Certificate<em> following must be submitted to the Registrar’s Office by 5:00 PM on the dissertation deadline date. No exceptions are allowed.</em></p><p dir="ltr"></p><h4>Registration and Tuition for Graduating Students</h4><p><b>March degree candidates: </b>the last term of enrollment is the fall term; do not register for spring.<br /><b>May degree candidates:</b> the last term of enrollment is the spring term<b>.<br />November degree candidates:</b> the last term of enrollment is the previous spring term.</p><p>Students who do not deposit a dissertation by the deadline, must register for the fall term. Please see the current <a href="http://handbook.gsas.harvard.edu/ii-academic-calendar">degree calendar on in the GSAS Handbook</a>. <a href="http://handbook.gsas.harvard.edu/harvard-university-student-health-program">Deadlines for health coverage selections</a> may differ from degree submission deadlines; it is your responsibility to plan accordingly.</p><p>In addition to academic requirements, students are required to meet the financial requirements for the degree. For details please review the <a href="http://handbook.gsas.harvard.edu/viii-financial-aid-and-requirements">Financial Aid &amp; Requirements section of the GSAS Handbook</a>.</p><h5><em>Diplomas and Commencement:  </em></h5><h5><a href="http://registrar.fas.harvard.edu/registration-enrollment-degrees/graduation-diplomas">Please refer to the costs and processes outlines by the FAS Registrar for diplomas and commencement.</a> All students who receive degrees in November, March and May of the academic year of that May graduation, may participate in the Commencement celebration.</h5></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
</div>
  </div></div></div></div>																																			</div>
								<!--front panel regions end-->
													
											</div>
				</div>

				
								  <!--sidebar second region beg-->
				  <div class="region region-sidebar-second sidebar"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-boxes-os-pages-section-nav" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_sectionnav section-nav no-title"  module="boxes" delta="os_pages_section_nav"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-os_pages_section_nav' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><ul class="menu clearfix"><li class="first last expanded active-trail active-trail menu-depth-1 menu-item-31161"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/academics"  class="active-trail active">Academics</a><ul class="menu clearfix"><li class="first leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-31166"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/undergraduate" >Undergraduate</a></li><li class="last expanded active-trail active-trail menu-depth-2 menu-item-31171"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/doctoral"  class="active-trail active">Doctoral</a><ul class="menu clearfix"><li class="first expanded active-trail active-trail menu-depth-3 menu-item-31306"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/phd-program"  class="active-trail active">PhD Program &amp; Timeline</a><ul class="menu clearfix"><li class="first leaf menu-depth-4 menu-item-32681"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/doctoral-advising" >Advising</a></li><li class="menu-depth-4 menu-item-32586"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/years-1-%26-2" >Years 1 &amp; 2</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-4 menu-item-32631"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/year-3-general-exams" >Year 3: General Exams</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-4 menu-item-32656"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/year-3-%26-4-teaching" >Year 3 &amp; 4: Teaching</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-4 menu-item-32661"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/year-4-dissertation-prospectus" >Year 4: Dissertation Prospectus</a></li><li class="last leaf active-trail active-trail menu-depth-4 menu-item-32666"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/year-5-the-dissertation"  class="active-trail active active">Year 5 &amp; up: The Dissertation</a></li></ul></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-3 menu-item-33061"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/links-doctoral-students" >Links for Doctoral Students</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-3 menu-item-32971"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/faqs-doctoral" >FAQ&#039;s: Doctoral</a></li><li class="last collapsed menu-depth-3 menu-item-31311"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/thd-program" >ThD Program</a></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></div></div></div>
  </div></div><section id="block-boxes-1472238788" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_html"  module="boxes" delta="1472238788"><div class="block-inner clearfix">

      <h2 class="block-title">Forms for Current Students in Ph.D. Program</h2>
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1476823074' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><p>These forms are for students who are *enrolled* in the Ph.D. program. <strong>Do *not* request access</strong> if you are applying to the Ph.D. program.</p><ul><li><a href="https://docs.google.com/a/harvard.edu/document/d/16wlb4LD2NgMteJ7X0q_9d418vFBUBU1qjjcrFOXdP2I/edit?usp=sharing" title="">Plan of Study</a></li><li><a href="https://goo.gl/forms/w80b6mQGPVRBOIi33" title="">Intent to Take the Second Year Review</a></li><li><a href="https://goo.gl/forms/qrVDPsjLzTIIeWM32" title="">Intent to Take General Exams</a></li><li><a href="https://docs.google.com/a/harvard.edu/document/d/1uLO2yz184gawZctHd6uawOwB4auSDdueAnmytjk3TGY/edit?usp=sharing" title="">Dissertation Prospectus Checklist</a></li></ul></div></div></div>

<meta name="twitter:description" content="Year Five and Following: The Dissertation and Graduation" />
<link rel="shortlink" href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/node/63396" />
<meta name="twitter:image" content="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/" />
<meta name="twitter:title" content="Committee on the Study of Religion" />
<link rel="dns-prefetch" href="//static.hwpi.harvard.edu" />
<link rel="shortcut icon" href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/profiles/openscholar/themes/hwpi_classic/favicon.png" type="image/vnd.microsoft.icon" />
<link rel="canonical" href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/year-five-and-following-dissertation-and-graduationupon-formal-approval-prospectus" />
<meta name="twitter:card" content="summary" />
<link rel="up" href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/thd-program" />
<link rel="prev" href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/year-four-thd-dissertation-prospectus-0" />
<meta name="description" content="Upon formal approval of the prospectus, the student commences the writing of the dissertation. Following the approval of the prospectus, at least one chapter of the dissertation per year must be submitted to the advisor. The dissertation should be completed within two years after the approval of the prospectus, but not later than seven years from the date of admission to the program. The length of the dissertation is limited to a maximum of 300 pages, exclusive of bibliography.When the student is close to being ready to defend, the advisor writes a letter to the Chair of the Standing Committee proposing the dissertation examining committee. The examining committee will consist of at least three faculty readers, two of whom must be members of HDS. Members or past members of the Standing Committee of the Study of Religion are considered de facto as members of HDS. Membership of the examining committee must be approved by the Standing Committee.Once the examiners have been approved and the student has completed the dissertation, a two-hour oral defense will be arranged. It is the student’s responsibility to provide the examiners with copies of the dissertation by the dates stipulated in the current year’s Information on Submission of the Dissertation (usually around August 15 for receipt of the degree in November, by December 1 for receipt of the degree in March , and by April 1 for receipt of the degree in June).Th.D. dissertations follow the same formatting guidelines as Harvard Graduate School of Arts and Sciences dissertations.  For more information please refer to the GSAS “Form of the PhD Dissertation” page.  Note that title pages for HDS dissertations differ slightly from GSAS dissertations.  Please refer to the example in the Th.D. Handbook.Also, please see the ThD Program Administrator for the current Information on Submission of the Dissertation for Th.D. Candidates when you get close to finishing. This lists specific dates for the submission of Degree Applications, the final Draft, and the last possible defense dates for the November, March, and June Degrees.*If a student&#039;s leaves Harvard when the student is at the dissertation stage, that advisor may serve as the main advisor for one year after departure. After one year, students must find a Harvard affiliated advisor. The departed faculty member may continue to serve on the dissertation committee and informally act as co-advisor. " />
<meta property="og:title" content="Year Five and Following: The Dissertation and Graduation" />
<meta property="og:type" content="article" />
<meta property="og:description" content="Upon formal approval of the prospectus, the student commences the writing of the dissertation. Following the approval of the prospectus, at least one chapter of the dissertation per year must be submitted to the advisor. The dissertation should be completed within two years after the approval of the prospectus, but not later than seven years from the date of admission to the program. The length of the dissertation is limited to a maximum of 300 pages, exclusive of bibliography.When the student is close to being ready to defend, the advisor writes a letter to the Chair of the Standing Committee proposing the dissertation examining committee. The examining committee will consist of at least three faculty readers, two of whom must be members of HDS. Members or past members of the Standing Committee of the Study of Religion are considered de facto as members of HDS. Membership of the examining committee must be approved by the Standing Committee.Once the examiners have been approved and the student has completed the dissertation, a two-hour oral defense will be arranged. It is the student’s responsibility to provide the examiners with copies of the dissertation by the dates stipulated in the current year’s Information on Submission of the Dissertation (usually around August 15 for receipt of the degree in November, by December 1 for receipt of the degree in March , and by April 1 for receipt of the degree in June).Th.D. dissertations follow the same formatting guidelines as Harvard Graduate School of Arts and Sciences dissertations.  For more information please refer to the GSAS “Form of the PhD Dissertation” page.  Note that title pages for HDS dissertations differ slightly from GSAS dissertations.  Please refer to the example in the Th.D. Handbook.Also, please see the ThD Program Administrator for the current Information on Submission of the Dissertation for Th.D. Candidates when you get close to finishing. This lists specific dates for the submission of Degree Applications, the final Draft, and the last possible defense dates for the November, March, and June Degrees.*If a student&#039;s leaves Harvard when the student is at the dissertation stage, that advisor may serve as the main advisor for one year after departure. After one year, students must find a Harvard affiliated advisor. The departed faculty member may continue to serve on the dissertation committee and informally act as co-advisor. " />

<title>Year Five and Following: The Dissertation and Graduation | Committee on the Study of Religion</title>

<link type="text/css" rel="stylesheet" href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/files/css/css_cc7cbVHE743wRnoGokvHwyMB98EL3HtsTpA6y3d1DsQ.css?m=1506990136" media="all" />
<link type="text/css" rel="stylesheet" href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/files/css/css_nFgeoNW57KKojMceGiwxyyuJTgQUW54lRr5QkgcEPK0.css?m=1507136761" media="screen" />

				<div id="content-column" role="main">
					<div class="content-inner">
					  <div class="breadcrumb"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/" >HOME</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/academics" >ACADEMICS</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/doctoral" >DOCTORAL</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/thd-program" >THD PROGRAM</a> <span>&#47;</span> </div>
													              <a name="main-content"></a>
															<header id="main-content-header">
									<a name="main-content"></a>
                    <h1 id="page-title">
                      Year Five and Following: The Dissertation and Graduation                    </h1>
                </header>
														
															<!--front panel regions beg-->
								<div id="content-panels" class="at-panel gpanel panel-display content clearfix">
									<div class="region region-content-top"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-os-pages-main-content" class="block block-os-pages no-title"  module="os_pages" delta="main_content"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><article id="node-63396" class="node node-page article clearfix" role="article">
  
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p>Upon formal approval of the prospectus, the student commences the writing of the dissertation. Following the approval of the prospectus, at least one chapter of the dissertation per year must be submitted to the advisor. The dissertation should be completed within two years after the approval of the prospectus, but not later than seven years from the date of admission to the program. The length of the dissertation is limited to a maximum of 300 pages, exclusive of bibliography.<br /><br />When the student is close to being ready to defend, the advisor writes a letter to the Chair of the Standing Committee proposing the dissertation examining committee. The examining committee will consist of at least three faculty readers, two of whom must be members of HDS. Members or past members of the Standing Committee of the Study of Religion are considered de facto as members of HDS. Membership of the examining committee must be approved by the Standing Committee.<br /><br />Once the examiners have been approved and the student has completed the dissertation, a two-hour oral defense will be arranged. It is the student’s responsibility to provide the examiners with copies of the dissertation by the dates stipulated in the current year’s <em>Information on Submission of the Dissertation</em> (usually around August 15 for receipt of the degree in November, by December 1 for receipt of the degree in March , and by April 1 for receipt of the degree in June).<br /><br />Th.D. dissertations follow the same formatting guidelines as Harvard Graduate School of Arts and Sciences dissertations.  For more information please refer to the GSAS “<a href="http://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/year-5-the-dissertation" title="">Form of the PhD Dissertation</a>” page.  Note that title pages for HDS dissertations differ slightly from GSAS dissertations.  Please refer to the example in the Th.D. Handbook.<br /><br />Also, please see the ThD Program Administrator for the current <em>Information on Submission of the Dissertation for Th.D. Candidates</em> when you get close to finishing. This lists specific dates for the submission of Degree Applications, the final Draft, and the last possible defense dates for the November, March, and June Degrees.</p><p>*If a student's leaves Harvard when the student is at the dissertation stage, that advisor may serve as the main advisor for one year after departure. After one year, students must find a Harvard affiliated advisor. The departed faculty member may continue to serve on the dissertation committee and informally act as co-advisor.</p><p> </p><p><!--break--></p><h2>Th.D. Time to Degree Policy</h2><p>“Normally, a thesis should be submitted within two years of approval of the prospectus, but it must be submitted within seven years from the date of admission to the program.”</p><p>In spring 2002, the members of the Standing Committee of the Committee on the Study of Religion and the Faculty of the Divinity School voted to accept an addition to this policy which states:</p><p>“After seven years in the Th.D. program, students may petition the Th.D. Director for a one-year extension of time to complete the dissertation. No more than three such petitions for each student will be accepted. Th.D. students will not be permitted to register beyond their tenth year in the Divinity School. However, exceptions to this rule may be made for students who have taken maternity or parental leave or for students with other special circumstances. Students are free to apply for readmission to the Divinity School, so as to re-register for the purpose of receiving the degree, when their thesis is completed. Students no longer enrolled because of this policy will have the status of ‘withdrawn.’”</p><p><em>Please note: This regulation will indeed be strictly enforced. If you are beyond your seventh year in the program, regardless of any Leave of Absences taken, please make sure to submit your petition (addressed to the Th.D. Director, sent care of the Th.D. Administrator) as early as possible in the Spring.</em></p><p> </p><h3>Procedures for termination of candidacy</h3><p>If a student is not making "satisfactory progress" towards the fulfillment of the requirements for the Th.D. program in the Study of Religion (as this matter is understood in the Harvard Divinity School Catalog), then the Doctoral Subcommittee of the Standing Committee of the Study of Religion is charged to take the following actions which are meant to prompt the student to rectify the deficiencies in his or her program of study but which will end in the termination of the candidacy of the student in the doctoral program if these deficiencies are not rectified:</p><ol><li>When a student is not in full compliance with the Th.D. program's progress requirements, he or she will be so notified by the Doctoral Subcommittee or the Director of Th.D. Studies. This notice is meant to serve as an initial warning to the student that he or she has fallen behind in their work and that they are expected to rectify the deficiencies within a specified period of time.</li><li>If, after the specified period of time the deficiency in question is not rectified, and in the Doctoral Subcommittee's estimation the matter is deemed sufficiently serious, the student will be placed on probation for at least six months but no longer than one year. This status is designed to provide a final warning to the student that their candidacy in the doctoral program is in jeopardy of being terminated unless he or she meets the particular requirements stipulated by the Doctoral Subcommittee. The student must be notified of this decision by phone and by letter, a copy of which must be sent to the student's adviser. During this probationary period, the student will be subject to Federal regulations concerning satisfactory academic progress in the receipt of financial aid and ordinarily will not work as a teaching fellow or tutor.</li><li>If it is not clear that the student has fulfilled the requirement(s) in question, one month before the end of the probationary period the student will be invited to meet with the Director of Th.D. Studies and the student's adviser(s). This will provide the final opportunity for the student to demonstrate that he or she has completely rectified the deficiencies which led to probation. The student must present in a letter a) clear evidence that the deficiencies have been rectified and, b)an outline of a well-defined plan of action for completing the remainder of the program. This letter must be approved and signed by the student's adviser.</li><li>The Doctoral Subcommittee will carefully consider all the details relevant to the student's progress at its next meeting. If the student has completely rectified the deficiencies which led to probation, he or she will be taken off probation. If the student has not rectified the deficiencies, and if there are no compelling reasons why these deficiencies have not been rectified, the student's candidacy in the program will at that time be terminated.</li><li>If the student is to be terminated from the doctoral program but has already passed General exams, the Doctoral Subcommittee may recommend to the Divinity School faculty to grant a terminal Th.M. degree.<br /> </li></ol><h3>Procedures for reinstatement</h3><div>Termination is final. This means that a student whose candidacy in the doctoral program is terminated is no longer considered an active member of the Harvard community, and thus he or she can no longer draw upon the resources of that community. Nevertheless, the student may wish to continue his or her studies on an independent basis. If such a course is followed, and if the student is able to rectify the deficiencies which led to termination, he or she may petition the Doctoral Subcommittee for reinstatement in the Th.D. program. The procedures regulating reinstatement are as follows:</div><ol><li><div>The student must submit to the Doctoral Subcommittee: a) evidence that the deficiencies which led to termination of candidacy are completely rectified, and b) a clearly delineated plan of action which shows when and how the student will fulfill the remaining requirements of the doctoral program.</div></li><li>The student must meet with and procure the prior endorsement of his or her adviser and the Director of Th.D. Studies, both of whom must write a letter to the Doctoral Subcommittee on the student's behalf.</li><li>The Doctoral Subcommittee will act on this matter at its next meeting. Reinstatement in the doctoral program is not automatic but up to the discretion of the Doctoral Subcommittee. A decision for reinstatement will be based upon, a) the length of time it took the student to rectify the deficiencies which led to termination of candidacy, b) the clarity and reasonableness of the student's proposal to fulfill the remaining requirements of the doctoral program, and c) the likelihood that the student will fulfill the remaining requirements in the time frame which they have proposed.</li></ol><p>If the student is reinstated, his or her continued status in the doctoral program will be determined by the student's ability to follow the proposed plan of action and to keep to the time schedule which it contains. A student's candidacy in the doctoral program may be terminated again if he or she is unable to meet the stipulations of his or her proposed plan of action.</p><p> </p></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
</div>
  </div></div></div></div>																																			</div>
								<!--front panel regions end-->
													
											</div>
				</div>

  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-os_pages_section_nav' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><ul class="menu clearfix"><li class="first last expanded active-trail active-trail menu-depth-1 menu-item-31161"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/academics"  class="active-trail active">Academics</a><ul class="menu clearfix"><li class="first leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-31166"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/undergraduate" >Undergraduate</a></li><li class="last expanded active-trail active-trail menu-depth-2 menu-item-31171"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/doctoral"  class="active-trail active">Doctoral</a><ul class="menu clearfix"><li class="first collapsed menu-depth-3 menu-item-31306"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/phd-program" >PhD Program &amp; Timeline</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-3 menu-item-33061"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/links-doctoral-students" >Links for Doctoral Students</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-3 menu-item-32971"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/faqs-doctoral" >FAQ&#039;s: Doctoral</a></li><li class="last expanded active-trail active-trail menu-depth-3 menu-item-31311"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/thd-program"  class="active-trail active">ThD Program</a><ul class="menu clearfix"><li class="first leaf menu-depth-4 menu-item-32706"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/thd-program-requirements" >Th.D. Program Requirements</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-4 menu-item-32691"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/timeline-0" >Th.D. General Exams</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-4 menu-item-32781"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/year-three-thd-teaching-0" >Year Three: Th.D. Teaching</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-4 menu-item-32761"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/year-four-thd-dissertation-prospectus-0" >Year Four: Th.D. Dissertation Prospectus</a></li><li class="last leaf active-trail active-trail menu-depth-4 menu-item-32776"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/year-five-and-following-dissertation-and-graduationupon-formal-approval-prospectus"  class="active-trail active active">Year Five and Following: The Dissertation and Graduation</a></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></div></div></div>
  </div></div><section id="block-boxes-1472238788" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_html"  module="boxes" delta="1472238788"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
      <h2 class="block-title">Doctoral Student Handbooks</h2>
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1472238788' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><a href="https://docs.google.com/document/d/139pqOBBoI0KkYhpsZAZiNDa0VU4E-uOZInpygx-Mco8/edit?usp=sharing" target="_blank" title="">Ph.D. Student Handbook</a><br /><a href="http://handbook.gsas.harvard.edu/gsas-handbook" title="">GSAS Student Handbook</a><br /><a href="http://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/files/religion/files/thd_handbook_2016.pdf">Th.D. Student Handbook</a><a href=""  class="os-embed-link" data-delta="1472238788">&lt;embed&gt;</a><div id="embed-popup-1472238788" class="embed-popup"><ul class="links num-links-2"><li class="link-count-iframe first"><a href="#1472238788-iframe" >Iframe</a></li><li class="link-count-oembed last"><a href="#1472238788-oembed" >URL</a></li></ul><div id="1472238788-iframe"><div class="form-item form-type-textarea form-item-web-widgets">

  </div></section><section id="block-boxes-1476823712" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_html"  module="boxes" delta="1476823712"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
      <h2 class="block-title">Forms for Th.D. Program</h2>

      <h2 class="block-title">Doctoral Program Calendar</h2>
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1472248730' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><div id="file-697671" class="file file-html file-html-embed">

  <div class="content">
    <div class="file-info"></div><div class="field field-name-field-html-code field-type-text-long field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><iframe src="https://calendar.google.com/calendar/embed?showTitle=0&amp;showNav=0&amp;showPrint=0&amp;showCalendars=0&amp;showTz=0&amp;mode=AGENDA&amp;height=600&amp;wkst=1&amp;bgcolor=%23cccccc&amp;src=harvard.edu_tdumcqt6psi863e4fqd2re2tek%40group.calendar.google.com&amp;color=%23cccccc&amp;src=9qpvg4b8brruceh6v118kbht2k%40group.calendar.google.com&amp;color=%23cccccc&amp;ctz=America%2FNew_York" style="border-width:0" width="260" height="600" frameborder="0" scrolling="no"></iframe></div></div></div>  </div>

<meta name="description" content="Within, at most, twelve months of passing generals, every doctoral candidate is expected to submit a Dissertation Prospectus. The prospectus is a proposal formulated by the student about the doctoral dissertation that he or she intends to write. Acceptance of the prospectus by the Standing Committee constitutes a kind of contract by which the full Committee agrees that if the student completes a successful dissertation that is in accord with, or a reasonable development from, what the prospectus delineates, it will recommend the degree. " />
<meta property="og:description" content="Within, at most, twelve months of passing generals, every doctoral candidate is expected to submit a Dissertation Prospectus. The prospectus is a proposal formulated by the student about the doctoral dissertation that he or she intends to write. Acceptance of the prospectus by the Standing Committee constitutes a kind of contract by which the full Committee agrees that if the student completes a successful dissertation that is in accord with, or a reasonable development from, what the prospectus delineates, it will recommend the degree. " />
<meta property="og:title" content="Year Four: Th.D. Dissertation Prospectus" />

  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-site_info' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><h1><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/" >Committee on the Study of Religion</a></h1>
    
    <p>

  </div></div></div></div>					  					  <div class="region region-header-third"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-os-secondary-menu" class="block block-os no-title"  module="os" delta="secondary-menu"><div class="block-inner clearfix">

		<div id="columns" class="clearfix">
			<div class="hg-container">
				<div id="content-column" role="main">
					<div class="content-inner">
					  <div class="breadcrumb"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/" >HOME</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/academics" >ACADEMICS</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/doctoral" >DOCTORAL</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/thd-program" >THD PROGRAM</a> <span>&#47;</span> </div>
													              <a name="main-content"></a>
															<header id="main-content-header">
									<a name="main-content"></a>
                    <h1 id="page-title">
                      Year Four: Th.D. Dissertation Prospectus                    </h1>
                </header>
														
															<!--front panel regions beg-->
								<div id="content-panels" class="at-panel gpanel panel-display content clearfix">
									<div class="region region-content-top"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-os-pages-main-content" class="block block-os-pages no-title"  module="os_pages" delta="main_content"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><article id="node-63381" class="node node-page article clearfix" role="article">
  
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p>Within, at most, twelve months of passing generals, every doctoral candidate is expected to submit a Dissertation Prospectus. The prospectus is a proposal formulated by the student about the doctoral dissertation that he or she intends to write. Acceptance of the prospectus by the Standing Committee constitutes a kind of contract by which the full Committee agrees that if the student completes a successful dissertation that is in accord with, or a reasonable development from, what the prospectus delineates, it will recommend the degree.</p><p> </p><h2>Student Responsibilities</h2><p>The responsibility of the student to formulate, with as much advice and consultation as seem appropriate, a dissertation project that seems to him or her significant and worthwhile, and that others will recognize as a solid contribution both to his or her subfield and to the study of religion more generally. In this regard please refer to the section below, <strong><em>On Drafting a Dissertation Prospectus,</em></strong> and keep well in mind the following statement in the Supplement: "Each dissertation, in making a contribution to knowledge, should also illuminate our understanding of religion."<br /><br />Each student must choose a member of the Harvard faculty to supervise the writing of the prospectus. Such a faculty member will most likely, but not necessarily, be the advisor who has been supervising the student‘s program to that point. The student must also propose two or three other faculty members to serve on his or her prospectus committee. It is important that these professors have also READ the draft and conveyed their thoughts to the student and main advisor before it is submitted to the CSR.<br /><br />In composing the prospectus the student should be mindful that he or she is writing it for The Standing Committee on the Study of Religion as a whole, to whom it must be intelligible and cogent. Most Committee members will not be experts in the student's particular specialty.<br /><br />The prospectus should be brief (not more than 3000 words, excluding bibliography and notes; a model title page is enclosed), and must be double-spaced. It is to be submitted electronically to the Ph.D. Program Administrator 2 weeks in advance of the Standing Committee meeting at which it will be considered. The student should submit 25 hard copies of the prospectus to the CSR two days before the meeting at which it will be considered for approval.<br /><br />The CSR will accept prospectuses at all of its meetings up to and including the April meeting. If a larger number of prospectuses is received at the April meeting, some may be tabled and discussed at the May CSR meeting. No new prospectuses will be accepted for the May meeting.</p><p> </p><h2>Advisor Responsibilities</h2><p>Advisors are expected to be involved actively in the development of the prospectus—especially with regard to its scope and purpose—and to guide the student through early drafts.<br /><br />When the prospectus is ready to be submitted to the Standing Committee, the student’s advisor should confirm that all of the formal guidelines for the prospectus have been met, by signing the <a href="http://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/files/religion/files/prospectus_checklist.doc">"Prospectus Checklist"</a>. If the student's advisor will not be able to attend the CSR meeting in which the prospectus is being discussed, he or she should write a covering letter to the CSR Chair of the Committee, indicating an evaluation of the project and a willingness to supervise the work. This letter also proposes two or three faculty members, in addition to the advisor, to serve as members of a prospectus committee. While the majority of the prospectus committee will be scholars in the student's particular specialty, others outside his or her field might be included as well. The advisor should ascertain that these other scholars have read the draft of the prospectus, and be prepared to represent their views at the CSR meeting.<br /><br />The advisor may discuss changes with the student before the prospectus comes before the committee; although it is rarely necessary, the student may opt to withdraw the draft for later submission, for example.</p><p> </p><h2>Standing Committee Responsibilities</h2><p>The DGS or other appropriate faculty meets with doctoral students at the beginning of each academic year to discuss the prospectus process in detail.<br /><br />There will also be a discussion of the entire prospectus process among faculty at the beginning of each academic year in a CSR meeting. This discussion will review the ethos and culture of the process, including the responsibility of all CSR faculty to read each prospectus carefully in advance, with the larger expectation that all theses address issues in the Study of Religion.<br /><br />CSR members are strongly encouraged to alert the advisor to any substantive concerns one week in advance of the CSR meeting in which his or her advisee’s prospectus is discussed. (This recommendation does not discourage robust discussion and possible rejection of the prospectus at the CSR meeting.)<br /><br />Once the prospectus is submitted, it will be considered, along with comments of the advisor, by the Standing Committee at its earliest scheduled meeting. When the CSR approves the prospectus, it also approves the thesis committee, on occasion making recommendations for additions or adjustments. In every case, the advisor is a member of the prospectus committee.<br /><br />Please note that additional substantive questions may be raised during the discussion of the prospectus at the CSR meeting; there is no obligation on the part of the Standing Committee to pass a prospectus.<br /><br />If a prospectus is turned back to the student for revisions, it will be resubmitted to the doctoral subcommittee for approval and approval of the thesis committee.<br /><br />Once the Standing Committee approves a prospectus, it will then refer it to the prospectus committee who will meet with the student to discuss the project in depth. Normally this is a two-hour meeting. The prospectus committee then reports back to the Standing Committee, recommending final approval of the proposal. In some cases the prospectus committee may indicate that it has asked the student to make some revisions and that it will delay its formal recommendation until they have been received. The prospectus committee, once its recommendation has been approved by the Standing Committee, is disbanded.</p><p>The purpose of a prospectus is to enable students: (1) to clarify what they conceive to be the nature and significance of their prospective dissertation work, and (2) to receive constructive criticism, advice and approval from both the full Committee on the Study of Religion and members of a prospectus committee. Formulating a prospectus for the faculty represents a significant stage in the course of dissertation work, and its importance should not be underestimated. Not only does it allow students to come to a fuller and more adequate understanding of their own project; it also enlists the active support of the faculty who are expected to provide significant advice and criticism at this crucial stage in its development.<br /><br />While there are no well-established formulas or models for writing a prospectus, every prospectus should attend to the following issues:</p><table><tr><td><p>1. Topic and thesis. There is an important distinction between a topic and a thesis. A topic represents the issue which the dissertation addresses. A thesis constitutes the position which the student takes in relation to the topic; i.e., the central hypothesis which is to be examined. For example:</p><p>Topic: Barth’s theological method</p><p>Thesis: Barth's theological method results from his interpretation of the Word of God as an act which is not subject to human manipulation.</p><p>In the prospectus, students should carefully circumscribe the topic of their dissertation, including historical and conceptual analyses of the topic (to the extent that such analyses clarify what the student takes to be at issue). The aim is not only to show how the dissertation will be done, but that the student is familiar enough with the topic that the project can be done and done within a reasonable amount of time. The CSR strongly recommends that students be thinking about possible dissertation topics as they work on their General exams, with the hope that the exam process will move easily, and fairly expeditiously, into the writing of the prospectus.</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>2. Sources, Method, and Theory. The prospectus must also be clear about the sources upon which the dissertation will depend, the method(s) the student will be using, and where appropriate, the theoretical resources that will be relevant to their work. Consequently, in discussing method, it is especially important to attend to any special problems that might occur in the course of research and to note how these problems might be addressed.</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>3. Contribution to scholarship. Students should specify as carefully as they can what they consider to be the various ways their project will contribute to the field of study in which they work. In particular, it is helpful to a brief statement of the current status of their topic within their larger field of study, to indicate the various problems at issue, and to show how their project will advance the discussion. It is also important to know that prospectuses are read by the full Standing Committee before they are considered by Prospectus Committees and that the concern of the members of the full Committee, with respect to this aspect of the prospectus, is the extent to which dissertation work can be understood to contribute not only to particular fields of study but also to the broader study of religion, continuing the intellectual work begun in Religion 2001 and 2002. Students are encouraged to articulate the contribution of their research to a future horizon of the community concerned with the study of religion in connection to the received heritage of religious studies and on contemporary discussions and debates, as topic and thesis are formulated and developed and as the worth of the project for scholarship is stated.</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>4. Chapter Outline. The prospectus must also provide an outline of the projected chapter divisions and a brief description of how the argument will be developed from chapter to chapter.</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>5. Bibliography. In addition the prospectus should include a brief bibliography indicating the principal primary and secondary sources upon which the theses is expected to be based. This need not be exhaustive, but representative.</p></td></tr></table><p><em>Revised November 2011</em></p><p> </p><p> </p></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
</div>
  </div></div></div></div>																																			</div>
								<!--front panel regions end-->
													
											</div>
				</div>

Dissertation Prospectus</a></li><li class="last leaf menu-depth-4 menu-item-32776"><a href="https://studyofreligion.fas.harvard.edu/pages/year-five-and-following-dissertation-and-graduationupon-formal-approval-prospectus" >Year Five and Following: The Dissertation and Graduation</a></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></div></div></div>
  </div></div><section id="block-boxes-1472238788" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_html"  module="boxes" delta="1472238788"><div class="block-inner clearfix">
